LONDON, July 11. -- The government came to the help of its hard-pressed beef producers today by announcing that a direct subsidy, not exceeding 3,000,000, would be paid between Sept. 1 and the end of next March.

The nation-wide drive against objectionable films won another concession yesterday from the motion picture industry when the principal producers offered to cancel contracts with exhibitors on any pictures released prior to July 15 on which "there is a genuine protest on moral grounds."

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- All American marines will be removed from Haiti by Aug. 15, Secretary Swanson announced today. He said the Haitian Garde would be nationalized by Aug. 1 and that the withdrawal of the 47 officers and 517 marines now stationed in Haiti would follow.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 11. -- An action to determine whether they can operate under "closed shop" regulations in view of the NRA was brought before Supreme Court Justice Frederick P. Close today by the Scarsdale Supply Company and fifteen other building material concerns of Westchester County.

LONDON, July 11. -- During a debate in the House of Commons last night on the government's proposed subsidy to tramp shipping it was revealed that communications will be dispatched today to the governments of the dominions inviting cooperation in the defense of British shipping.

The New York Newspaper Guild announced last night that, after a conference between its representatives and United States Attorney Hickey, the latter had requested S. I. Newhouse, acting publisher of The Long Island Press, to appear at his office this morning and answer a formal complaint filed by the Guild officers.
WASHINGTON, July 11. -- The proposed basic code for all hitherto uncoded industries, announced today by General Johnson, is as follows:

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- Emergency appropriations are estimated by administration officials to be giving employment to more than 2,250,000 men and women. Mostly the jobs are of the pick-and-shovel kind.

A change in the NRA interpretations on anticipation or the deduction of a discount for the payment of bills in advance of due date will be sought by the National Retail Dry Goods Association, it was announced here yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 11. -- Phil Turnesa, the eldest of the golfing Turnesa brothers, turned in a sparkling round of 71 today in the one-day tournament at the Fenimore Country Club and annexed two first prizes.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 11 (AP). -One of the Winter book favorites for the rich Hambletonian Stake was upset tonight when Emily Stokes, driven by Fred G. Egan for C.W. Phillis of New York City won the historic Matron Stakes for 3-year-old trotters.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., July 11. -- A special committee of the Common Council of this city, appointed last March to investigate charges of irregularity in the administration of local work relief, reported tonight to the council that the handling of relief funds was "farcical" and that "special privilege" dominated the process.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

City income taxes on salaries of $50 to $60 a week or more, to finance unemployment relief, were recommended yesterday to the joint committee of the Board of Estimate and the Board of Aldermen by Rabbi Stephen S. Wise.

A waning demand for penny restaurants, founded while the depression was at its nadir by Bernarr Macfadden, publisher, is expected to result shortly in the closing of at least some of these restaurants. This was disclosed yesterday in a statement made public at the headquarters of the Bernarr Macfadden Foundation, 30 Rockefeller Foundation.

OTTAWA, Ont., July 11 (Canadian Press). -- Canada's wheat crop at the end of June was estimated at 82 per cent of average, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today. At the end of June, 1933, the crop was estimated at 77 per cent of average, showing an improvement this year.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- An early study of telephone and telegraph rates was forecast today as the new Federal Communications Commission got under way at a formal organization meeting, and the Radio Commission, its predecessor, automatically passed into the realm of history.

CHICAGO, July 11. -- Well satisfied with the recognition given to them by the elder statesmen of the party, young Republicans attending a national conclave here adjourned tonight after adopting a brief statement of principles. Their "platform," they felt, compared well in its denunciation of the New Deal with the statement of the Republican National Committee made here last month.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 11. -- Any upturn in economic conditions under the NRA since last year has operated more to the advantage of employers than to that of their employes, Dr. Carmen Haider of New York told the Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia today.

The fourth annual invitation seaplane cruise of the Aviation Country Club of Long Island is expected to get under way this morning for Wellesley Island in the St. Lawrence River. The seaplanes and amphibians will leave from the beach of the Sands Point Bath Club on Manhasset Bay and will fly above the Hudson and Mohawk Rivers, Oneida Lake, Lake Ontario and the St. Lawrence to the Thousand Islands.

BOSTON, July 12. -- Governor Ely today denied Charles Ponzi's petition for a full pardon, which would save him from deportation. The Governor made his decision after a hearing at the State House in which Ponzi pleaded tearfully to remain in this country.

BERLIN, July 12. -- Before a gathering of prosecutors of Prussia at the Prussian Ministry of Justice, attended by Dr. Franz Guertner, Reich Minister of Justice; Heinrich Himmler, head of the secret State police, and other important representatives of the German judicial machinery, General Hermann Wilhelm Goering, Prussian Premier, delivered a speech today on the sanguinary events of June 30.

Speculation concerning the purpose for which HITLER called today's meeting of the Reichstag has shifted. It is now believed that his apologia for the Storm Troop killings will be published in a White Book, while the Fuhrer devotes his Reichstag speech to foreign policy.

PHILIP LINDSAY leaves one a little breathless. In his "The Tragic King," published only a month ago, he waded quite unmercifully into Shakespeare and the historians who have seen in Richard III, the last Plantagenet King of England, merely a villiain of consummate order. So fast did the fur fly that one forgot that Richard III has been dead since the fifteenth century.

Following the advance of virtually S5 a bale from the quotations prevailing before the government issued its acreage estimate on Monday, trading on the Cotton Exchange quieted down materially yesterday and prices were set back 15 to 25 points.

Weakness developed in the leading commodity futures markets yesterday. Trading was on a moderate scale. Coffee advanced against the other staples. In the cash markets declines occurred in all the grains, cocoa, lard, cotton and rubber.

RAPID CITY. S.D., July 12. -- The men who will have the task of rigging the huge balloon which Major William E. Kepner and Captain Albert W. Stevens will take into the stratosphere as soon as favorable weather arrives went into a serious practice session today at Spring Creek Canyon, whence the flight will be made.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 12. -Giving a first-class performance over the greatly improved outside course, the veteran bay gelding Prince Charming II today was awarded first prize in the $500 hunter stake, leading event of the opening day of the eleventh annual horse show of the Fairfield County Hunt Club.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended July 7 totaled 344,092,000 barrels, an increase of 385,000 barrels over the total of 343,707,000 barrels on hand at the end of the preceding week.

The report of the Standard Gas and Electric Company and subsidiary and affiliated companies for the twelve months ended on March 31 shows a consolidated net income of $2,678,131, equivalent to $5.89 and $5.05 a share respectively on the $7 and $6 cumulative prior preference stocks of the company, comparing with $2,459,965, or $5.41 and $4.64 a share respectively on these stocks, reported for the calendar year 1933.

The New York Central Railroad reported yesterday for May a net income of $72,091 after taxes and other charges, compared with $105.708 for the same month last year. For the first five months of this year the company had a net deficit of $1,640,073 after similar deductions, against $7,970,509 in the corresponding period of 1933.

BOSTON, July 12 (AP). -- With Bill Urbanski out of the line-up due to lameness, the Braves' infield performed in weird fashion today when the Cubs scored their third straight victim over the Tribesmen, 7 -- 4. Lon Warneke hurled for the Cubs, and, although he gave ten hits, five of them doubles, he won his thirteenth game of the season.

MOSCOW, July 12. -- Soviet leadership is making it thoroughly clear that it meant literally its warning in the resolutions of the Central Executive Committee last Sunday that no interference with the fulfilment of the grain delivery quotas would be tolerated, even though accompanied by the excuse that the crop has been curtailed by last Spring's drought.
ST. PAUL, July 12. -- Alexander G. Jamie, head of Chicago's criminal fighting agency, the "Secret Six," was appointed today Chief of Police of St. Paul by H.E. Warren, Commissioner of Public Safety.

Acting upon new evidence, Harold W. Hastings, Assistant District Attorney, announced yesterday he had started an inquiry to obtain a perjury indictment as soon as possible against Captain Ivan Poderjay, now in custody in Vienna, Austria.

CHICAGO, July 12. -- The movement of stocker and feeder cattle from drought-stricken regions of the Northwest is having an unfavorable influence on the markets for cattle and dressed beef. Arrangements have been made by the government to ship 5,000 head, mostly to pastures in Tennessee and other States, where there is sufficient feed.

PORTLAND, Ore., July 12. -Declaring that advertising has done much for the common good and that its importance as a social force is growing, T.D. Palmer, national advertising manager of THE NEW YORK TIMES, told the Pacific Advertising Clubs Association today.

NEWARK, N.J., July 12. -- Picketing of the L. Bamberger Co. department store by the Anti-Nazi Minute Men of America, on the allegation that the store sold German-made goods, was halted by police this afternoon soon after it began.

SHANGHAI, July 12. -- Carl Nammacher, American representative of the United Aircraft Service Corporation, was killed in the presence of his wife and 4-year-old daughter in Shanghai this afternoon when completing an hour's demonstration of a Voight Corsair plane for the Chinese government.

Yesterday's Public Service Commission hearing into the Westchester commutation rates of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad was enlivened again by Milton Mayer, president of the Boston Post Road Association. At the June 15 hearing he broke into the procedure to assert that Westchester communities served by the line, because of the commutation rates, had lagged behind those served by the New York Central.

BERLIN, July 12. -- Elaborate preparations are being made to insure that the entire German people, including those in even the smallest villages, shall hear directly the speech of Chancellor Hitler before the Reichstag tomorrow. He is expected to include the government's case against the intended rebels of June 30 and justify the summary executions then ordered.
Money market persisted in its dullness, and on the modest amount of business involved quotations prevailed without any variation from previous levels.

Secretary WALLACE'S speech at Madison is a worthy supplement to his pamphlet, "America Must Choose." It points out the types of goods and duties on which concessions might most usefully be made under the President's tariff bargaining powers. These include minor commodities on which high rates of duties are now imposed, though we produce them in insignificant quantities or not at all.
MIAMI, Okla., July 12 (AP). -- Two bank robbers and Ealum Gregory, president of the Bank of Ketchum, were shot to death in a gun fight in the hill country near Grove, Okla., today.

Counsel representing various interests in the reorganization of the United Cigar Stores of America disagreed yesterday on certain provisions of an order to be submitted to Federal Judge Alfred G. Coxe on Tuesday morning. The order, when signed, would confirm Judge Coxe's appointment of the Irving Trust Company as permanent trustee in bankruptcy.

CHICAGO, July 12. -- A growing belief that wheat in the United States will be scarce this year and that the world's supply will be smaller and more closely adjusted to consumptive requirements than in several years is creating decidedly bullish sentiment among speculators, and the markets in most instances are displaying a pronounced upward tendency.

CLARKSBURG, W. Va., July 12 (AP). -- On charges of intimidating witnesses in the Weirton Steel-Labor Board controversy, warrants were issued today for five officials of the Clarksburg unit of the Amalgamation Association of Iron, Steel and Tin Workers.
NICE, France, July 12. -- The Beuil Hotel and Winter Sports Company, belonging to Frank Jay Gould, filed a petition in bankruptcy in the Nice court today.

No one in Wall Street seemed surprised when the market resumed yesterday its familiar lifeless movements. The commission houses, which had permitted their hopes to rise on the previous two days, took the relapse philosophically. After all, the reaction was small and the volume did not fall quite to the extremely low levels of a few days ago.
YONKERS, N.Y., July 12. -- The first and second seeded doubles teams reached the final round in the Eastern girls' sectional centre tennis tournament today at the Amackassin Club.

A decline of $10,000,000 in the total of brokers' loans as of Wednesday to $1,059,000,000 was reported in the weekly condition statement of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City, published yesterday.
WATERLOO, Iowa, July 12. -- The text of the address today by Hugh S. Johnson, the NRA administrator, was as follows:

VIENNA, July 12. -- A decree published tonight giving opponents of Chancellor Dollfuss five days in which to turn in explosives to the government or face the death penalty also announces a stern policy toward other terrorist crimes, especially if they involve damage to transportation systems or vital industries.

Negotiations between the city and the B.M.T. for unification of rapid transit lines have advanced to the point where prices to be paid for company properties are being discussed, it was indicated yesterday.

A baffling change of pace enabled Bernard Freedman of City College to upset Jack Behr of Bayside, second ranking junior in the East, to reach the final of the Greater New York junior tennis singles tournament yesterday.

At a meeting of the executive board of the United Lutheran Church in America yesterday in the Lutheran Church House, 39 East Thirty-fifth Street, Dr. E. Clarence Miller of Philadelphia, the treasurer, reported that the contributions for benevolences for the year ended June 30 exceeded similar contributions made the previous fiscal year by $18,000.

WATERLOO, Iowa, July 12. -- General Johnson, hard-talking ex-cavalryman who heads the NRA, began his round-up tour for farm support of industrial recovery measures to the cheers of an estimated 4,500 persons gathered in a hot, dirt-floored cattle show barn today.

A quest for Owen Madden, paroled convict and racketeer, as a witness in the grand jury investigation of alleged short-weighting of the city on the sales of millions of dollars worth of coal, ended last night when a newspaper correspondent interviewed him in Hot Springs, Ark.

MONTREAL, July 12 (Canadian Press). -- Fresco Thompson hit a homer and four singles in five trips up tonight and his last blow drove in the winning run as Montreal took the opener of its three-game International League baseball series from Newark, 12 -- 11.
BUFFALO, July 12 (AP). -- Buffalo's winning streak was ended by Syracuse in an International League game tonight in ten innings, 8 to 7.
VIENNA, July 12. -- A bomb outrage attributed to Nazis at Salzburg today resulted in four tourists being wounded, two of them seriously.
EDINBURGH, July 12 (AP). -- Queen Mary and Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the American President, had another private chat today similar to the one they enjoyed at Buckingham Palace recently.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- In order that $25,000,000 earmarked for low-cost housing in New York City may be used as soon as possible, Secretary Ickes announced today that Dwight L. Hoopengarner, appraiser of the PWA housing division, would go to New York next week to attempt to work out a plan of cooperation with Langdon W. Post, Tenement House Commissioner.

PANAMA, July 12. -- President Roosevelt sailed westward into the Pacific today, into a glorious tropical sunset. Over the cruiser Houston a squadron of fifteen airplanes escorted him to sea, where for eleven days before he reaches Honolulu executive cares will be reduced to a minimum as he makes the most of his vacation.

OKLAHOM CITY, July 12 (AP). -- Chick Evans, the 44-year-old veteran who won the Western amateur golf title eight times, passed his first two tests in the come-back attempt today to earn a place among the quarter-finalists.
Sales by members of the American Fur Merchants Association, Inc., during the first six months of this year totaled $15,453,000 in comparison with $14,400,000 for the corresponding period of 1933.
" Stevedore" will play its 100th performance at the Civic Repertory Theatre tonight.

Frank Haynes, Bronx Boys' Club, stopped Louis Godoy, West Side Y.M.C.A., in the first round of the 140-pound special bout at the weekly A.A.U. boxing show held at Starlight Park last night. A crowd of 1,500 saw Haynes drop his rival in 2:19.

The principal changes disclosed in this week's Federal Reserve reports, published yesterday, were a resumption, after four weeks' lapse, of deposits of "free gold" by the Treasury with the Federal Reserve Banks and a rise of $156,000,000 in member-bank reserve balances to a new high level of $3,902,000,000.

DETROIT, July 12. -- With bands blaring and seat cushions and straw hats making a veritable shower on the field, more than 20,000 Detroit fans celebrated in world's series style today after the Detroit Tigers had set the Yankees down, 4 to 2, and dislodged the McCarthymen as leaders in the scramble for the American League pennant.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 12. -- The administration's policy of compensation curtailment was vigorously assailed today before more than 51,000 State Veterans of Foreign Wars. It was indicated that General Smedley D. Butler would be sought to lead a national appeal for restoration of pension cuts.

The affairs of Motion Picture Operators Union, Local 306, which has been in a state of factional turmoil as a result of an insurgent movement against Harry Sherman, president, were taken over yesterday by the International Alliance of Stage Employes and Motion Picture Operators, the parent organization.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., July 12. -- Mrs. Russell Holman of Innis Arden today won the low gross prize in a tournament of the Westchester-Fairfield Women's Golf Association over the links of the Lawrence Farms Golf Club.

ROSEVILLE, Calif., July 12 (AP). -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, "just out vacationing," said here today she does not plan seeing her daughter, Mrs. Anna Roosevelt Dall, who has established Nevada divorce residence.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 12. -- James Lawrence Breese gave a reception this afternoon at Breese-In for Mrs. Ruxton Vanderbilt, who arrived today to visit his son and daughter-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Sydney S. Breese, at the Post House. Mr. and Mrs. Sydney Breese will give a reception for Mrs. Vanderbilt on Saturday afternoon.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 12. -- Harry East's Burnt Mills quartet from New Jersey advanced into the final round of the Hempstead Cups tournament by defeating Stewart Iglehart's Westbury riders, 14 to 7, on Cochran Field today in the Meadow Brook Club's annual 12-goal tourney.

SALEM, N.H., July 12 (AP). -Mrs. R.T. Flippen's Crazy Jane, a 4-year-old brown mare, and Mrs. M. Koerner's 3-year-old chestnut filly Mumsie won the co-features of today's Rockingham Park racing program.

PARIS, July 12. -- The Parliamentary commission of inquiry into the Stavisky scandal has again started a lively press controversy by unearthing the fact that certain important documents regarding the late Alexandre Stavisky were available as far back as 1931.

There died a few days ago in Hawaii, where he was born, a man who showed himself a true Scout to the end of his life. Stricken by paralysis in his latter years, he lost one faculty after another. When but three fingers were left to him he still "punched out" letters on the typewriter and so sent messages of cheer to his friends.

The relationship of the Communist party of the United States to the Communist International in Moscow was examined yesterday at the Bar Association by the special Congressional committee investigating "un-American activities" which has already dealt with Nazi activities here.

Producers of objectionable films have long set up the defense that they were only "giving the people what they want." Mr. DE MILLE, who is himself against demoralizing motion pictures, has just said that the box-office argument has prevailed with the producing companies.

Operations of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation and subsidiaries for the year ended April 30, after giving effect to all charges for depreciation, depletion, bond interest, income taxes and after deducting minority stockholders' share of the earnings of subsidiary companies, resulted in a consolidated net profit of $1,579,640.

CARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 12. -- The United States is too large a country to be regulated from Washington and the constitutional limits, as interpreted by the courts, should also be the practical limits of any new Federal attempt at regulation of business and industry as a permanent successor to the NRA. Henry I. Harriman, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, told the Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia tonight.
HOLLYWOOD, July 12. -- The campaign for clean films may cost the movie industry as much as $10,000,000 in booking fees, it was estimated here today.

A recommendation that the new city charter provide at least a broad outline of the function of the city schools was made yesterday to a subcommittee of the Charter Revision Commission by Dr. Leroy Bowman of the City Affairs Committee.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., July 12 (AP). -- In Massachusetts Bay, where American maritime power was established, the scouting force of the United States fleet was anchored tonight and this old Cape Cod seaport enthusiastically welcomed the sailors.

Domestic corporation bonds continued yesterday their advance on the Stock Exchange with more than twoscore issues reaching new high levels for 1934. United States Government bonds, however, turned slightly reactionary after their rapid rise in the last few days.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., July 12. -- George Reis's El Lagarto, winner of the Gold Cup, was temporarily disabled yesterday, it was disclosed today when Reis left for Detroit to obtain the necessary parts for repairs. The boat was damaged when a connecting rod broke and crashed through the side of the engine case.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 12.-Mgr. Lavelle of St. Patrick's Cathedral, New York, and Mgr. Splaine of Boston have accepted invitations of Colonel W.B. Wallace, commander of the Twenty-sixth Infantry, which has charge of the 500 C.M.T.C. boys here, to visit the camp.
Ruth Suckow's new novel, "The Folks," on which she has been at work for four years, is the Literary Guild selection for October. Farrar Rinehart will publish the book on Oct. 1.
LONDON, July 12. -- Earl Stanhope, Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, summarized this country's position in the Chaco arms embargo in the House of Lords today.
TOLEDO, July 12. -- The world's record for 4-year-old trotters was equaled tonight when Brown Berry, driven by Fred Egan, won the free-for-all trot on the Grand Circuit program.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., July 12. -- The Birmingham Players from Alabama tonight entered their second week of production at the Binney Community House here with "The Last Enemy," by Frances Nemo Greene, given under the direction of John McGee.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP). -- Organization of "clearing houses" of industry to forward self-government by business was recommended to the business advisory and planning council today by its committee on unfair trade practices in production and distribution.

SOFIA, July 12. -- For the first time since the military coup in Bulgaria last month Premier Kimon Gueorgieff appeared today before a public assembly, held in a movie theatre here. He told his audience what the new governmet desired to effect and how it proposed to set to work.

Judge Corrigan in General Sessions today, after his charge, will give to the jury the case against nine men indicted for first-degree murder in the stabbing of Archbishop Leon Tourian last Christmas Eve in the Holy Cross Armenian Church in West 187th Street.
PHILADELPHIA, July 12 (AP). -- The Cardinals and Phillies divided a double-header today, the Cards winning the first contest, 8 to 5, and the Phils taking the second, 8 to 3.
Resale by a bank of a Jersey City garage recently in foreclosure featured the New Jersey realty trading reported yesterday.

The downfall of Chancellor Hitler of Germany "within a reasonably short time" was predicted yesterday by George H. Earle, former United States Minister to Austria and Democratic nominee for Governor of Pennsylvania, on his return from Europe aboard the United States liner Manhattan.
Sentiment in Tammany that James J. Dooling, youthful leader of the Fifth Assembly District, would he elected leader of Tammany Hall on Monday continued to grow yesterday.

I read with interest Mr. Krock's article on bureaucracy at Washington. But isn't bureaucracy an almost necessary attribute of bigness? If that diaper manufacturer is of fair size, try getting in to see him some time; or make an unusual request of his salesman, or -- to make the case easy -- try to sell him something.

With four home runs and other extra-base hits bouncing over the premises while 7,000 spectators alternately cheered and jeered, the Reds and Dodgers struggled through a double-header at Ebbets Field yesterday and finished where they started.

Banks and insurance conpanies, as holders of mortgages, bought in most of the properties in Manhattan and the Bronx offered at auctioneers' stands yesterday. Fifteen parcels, in all, were put up for bidding. Eight of these went to savings banks.

The Pirates ran very much out of line at the Polo Grounds yesterday when, behind the skillful pitching of Larry French, they upset the Giants in the first game of the afternoon's double-header, 3 to 1.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- The National Recovery Administration took steps today to put an end to the practice by some large retail tobacco dealers and distributers of tobacco products of using cigarettes as "bait" and as "loss leaders." This practice, it was declared, has practically driven small tobacconists out of business.

A new issue of $3,000,000 city of Boston temporary loan notes, dated July 16, 1934, and due on Nov. 26, 1934, was awarded yesterday to a syndicate comprising Harsey, Stuart Co., Inc.; J. W. Seligman Co., Hemphill, Noyes Co., Darby Co., G.M.-P. Murphy Co. and the R.F. Griggs Company of Waterbury, Conn.

Holders of Ermita Sugar Company first mortgage 7 1/2 per cent bonds, due in 1942, in default since 1929, have been notified by the Bankers Trust Company, as trustee, that a payment is being made at the rate of $12.203 a $1,000 bond. This represents the entire net proceeds of the foreclosure sale of the property.
RYE, N.Y., July 12. -- The Leake and Watts Orphan House at Yonkers will be the beneficiary tomorrow of "A Gay Afternoon" to be celebrated at the Westchester Country Club here.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed a total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date, while the reserve note circulation reached the lowest figure of the year.

At the meeting of the Democratic State Committee in New Haven on Wednesday Governor CROSS warned the assembled sages that "it is no time for factional strife"; likewise, "no "time to pay compliments to friends, "merely as such, by nominating them "to office unless they are thoroughly "qualified for the particular office for "which they seek nomination."

The Ridgewood (N.J.) Country Club yesterday was selected as the site for the 1935 Ryder Cup matches between picked golf professionals of the United States and Great Britain, according to The Associated Press.

Representatives of needle trades and the fur workers unions conferred yesterday with Nathan Straus Jr., State director of the National Emergency Council, at NRA headquarters, 45 Broadway, in what turned out to be a general discussion of the effectiveness of the NRA in these trades.

A revolution in the Dominican Republic within the next few months that will overthrow the government headed by President Rafael Trujillo was forecast here yesterday by Angel Morales, former Dominican Minister to Washington, who was exiled as a result of his criticism of the Trujillo regime.
Maurice Chevalier, now working with Jeanette MacDonald in "The Merry Widow," has signed a new contract with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.
LONDON, July 12 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- Wholesale commodity prices dropped off fractionally again during the week ended July 7, Commissioner Lubin of the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index number, based on 1926 averages, dropped from 74.8 to 74.7 during the week.

Fears that the drought may cause a sharp drop in men's wear volume in the areas affected were removed yesterday, when stores operating in those districts sent in confirmations to clothing manufacturers here on Fall orders placed previously. Furthermore, a few large, operators placed additional commitments, indicating their convictions that Fall business would at least equal that of last year.

WASHINGTON, D.C., July 12. -- Just had a fine long visit (and incidentally a good lunch) with the kindliest, friendliest and most able of our diplomats in a long time, Secretary of State Cordell Hull. We talked much of South America, where he made many friends at that conference.

LONDON, July 12. -- Trading on the stock markets here was less active today but the undertone remained firm. Price movements were generally higher. British funds were inclined to slow down, following the recent rapid advance. German bonds improved after a dull opening.

CHICAGO, July 12 (AP). -- Bob Johnson hit his twenty-sixth home run of the season with Roger Cramer on base in the eighth inning today, tying the score at 2 -- all, but the White Sox scored a run in the ninth to take the opening game of the series with the Athletics, 3 to 2.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., July 12. -- Accused of mismanagement, Frank N. Hoffstot, for twenty-five years president of the Pressed Steel Car Company, was ousted today from control of the company when Judge Robert M. Gibson, in Federal court, removed him as one of three receivers for the company, which is being reorganized under the amended Bankruptcy Act.

Cardinal Hayes, in a letter to be read this Sunday in all Roman Catholic churches of the archdiocese, gave endorsement yesterday to the nation-wide campaign for improved motion pictures and announced that organization of the Legion of Decency would begin here early in October.

BISMARCK, N.D., July 12. -- Governor William Langer today called a special session of the Legislature for July 19 to investigate his conviction by a Federal court jury of defrauding the United States Government.

Residential and business buildings in Manhattan and an industrial site in the Bronx passed to new control in city deals reported yesterday. Details show that investors are continuing the practice of buying houses for alteration into smaller suites.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP). -- To indicate that the paper is cooperating with the Federal Trade Commission in suppressing false advertising, the commission has adopted a policy of making public the name of the paper when such cases come up.

HAVANA, July 12. -- A soldier was killed this afternoon at Santiago in an attempt to force striking street-car employes to operate a car. They were on an hour's strike in protest against the killing of a street-car conductor in Havana yesterday.

MOSCOW, July 12. -- An amphibian automobile, designed to carry passengers and freight both over land and rivers in the expanses of the Soviet Union that have neither railroads nor bridges, has been constructed here at an experimental laboratory for water gliders and air sleighs.

ALBANY, July 12. -- Complete freedom of action, which will permit him to go deeply into the political relations of public utility corporations in the State and their lobbying and election activities, today was voted to John E. Mack, former Supreme Court justice, who is counsel for the joint legislative committee which, under a legislative mandate, is to undertake a sweeping investigation of the public utilities.

DOUGLAS, Isle of Man, July 12 (AP). -- With the prosecution expressing hope that an explanation warranting acquittal could be found, Kaye Don, British motor and speed boat racer, was placed on trial today on a charge of manslaughter growing out of an automobile accident.

No difficulty should be experienced in understanding why Republican Congressional leaders are disturbed over the broadside attack on Congress made by National Chairman Henry P. Fletcher. He sarcastically suggests that when a medal is struck for the Seventy-third Congress it should be "a rubber stamp, lying down."

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 12. -- With only one more round left to play, Miss Rosalie Knapp appears to be in line for the women's Long Island medal play title which Miss Helen Hicks renounced when she decided to turn "business woman" golfer recently.

Throughout Wednesday night Thomas Leonard worked on his books in the accounting department of the Guaranty Trust Company on the eleventh floor at 140 Broadway. At 6 A.M. yesterday, unnoticed by the other clerks, he climbed out on the window sill.
DUBLIN, July 12. -- Celebrations of the anniversary of the Battle of Boyne, held throughout Northern Ireland today, were large as ever.

BUENOS AIRES, July 12. -- Argentina has suddenly decided to send all officers of the naval training ship Presidente Sarmiento to Bogota as an embassy extraordinary to attend the inauguration of Alfonso Lopez as President of Colombia on Aug. 7.

The possibility that the city, if it does not get what it considers a fair price for its $70,000,000 in unsold bonds from the bankers, may attempt to sell at least part of the issue to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was indicated yesterday.

Under the constitutional amendment proposed by the City Charter Commission five District Attorneys, one for each county, will continue to be elected every two or four years as the Legislature shall direct. The County Clerks, instead of being elected, will be appointed by the Appellate Divisions of the Supreme Court in their respective judicial districts and given added duties.

Identify led from flagfall to finish to score a driving half-length victory in the mile and seventy-yard feature at Empire City yesterday. The favorite, Henry Lingelbach's Balios, was second, a scant head before J.H. Louchheim's Economic.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- President Roosevelt, by naval radio from the cruiser Houston, today approved the recommendations of the Marine Corps Selection Board for the promotion of Colonels Richard P. Williams and Thomas Holcomb to be brigadier generals of the line.
CINCINNATI, July 12. -- Only the formality of acceptance by the owning and operating utility companies is awaited before Cincinnati is assured of an exceptionally low electric rate.

WATERLOO, Iowa, July 12. -General Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, lashed out at Germany today in the first speech of a Western tour on which he plans to convince the farmers that the Blue Eagle has not failed them.

Stocks lost yesterday about all of their advance of the previous day and there was an accompanying contraction in trading. The volume of business on the Stock Exchange was roughly 470,000 shares, compared with 648,000 on Wednesday, and the composite index of averages fell 52 cents, against an advance of 49 cents.

The United States Army team will play the Monmouth County four tomorrow afternoon in the opening game of the national junior championship polo tourney at the Rumson Country Club in Rumson, N.J., according to the draw announced yesterday by the United States Polo Association.

Charles J. Hardy, president of the American Car and Foundry Company, said yesterday at the annual meeting that orders on the company's books on July 1 totaled $9,477,000, compared with $622,000 a year ago. He added that the government aid to the railroads had helped the equipment business and that large buying was expected in the near future.

Although bank clearings in the week ended on Wednesday were 11. 7 per cent less than those of the corresponding week last year, they were larger than in the preceding week. For twenty-two leading cities, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., they aggregated $4,739,546,000, which compared with $4,375,407,000 a week ago and $5,369,319,000 for the week ended on July 12, 1933.
PARIS, July 12 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

CHICAGO, July 12. -- Creditors and security holders of the Middle West Utilities Company, largest of former Insull enterprises, have come to an agreement on a plan for reorganizing the big holding company.

LONDON, July 12. -- Reports from Berlin tonight that the British Ambassador had called at the German Foreign Office today to urge Germany's adherence to the "eastern Locarno pact" add considerable interest to a statement Sir John Simon, the Foreign Secretary, is due to make in the House of Commons tomorrow on the results of the recent visit of Louis Barthou, the French Foreign Minister, to London.
CHICAGO, July 12. -- Smiling Bob Smith stuck his tongue in his cheek before he decided to answer the question.

The committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that the stock of Associated Apparel Industries, Inc., would be suspended from trading on next Tuesday because the company had failed thus far to issue its report for the fiscal year ended on Nov. 30 last.

The Hague administration in Jersey City, it appeared last night, had reversed its policy prohibiting picketing in labor disputes. In the absence of Mayor Frank Hague, who is on a cruise to Africa, Acting Mayor Arthur Potterton will clarify the attitude of city officials in a statement this afternoon.

EASTERN POINT, Conn., July 12. -- Miss Jean Bauer of Providence, the medalist, today advanced to the final round in the sixteenth annual Griswold Trophy golf tournament. Pitted against Miss Helen Bennett of New London, Conn., the Rhode Island girl won by 1 up at the Shenecossett Country Club in an exciting battle that went to the twentieth hole.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- Federal Home Loan banks approved loans of $595,600 in the week ended July 7, increasing the total authorized to $128,053,333.42, of which $116,663,347.63 has been paid out, the Home Loan Bank Board announced today.

The appointment of 989 additional teachers next year to handle the increasing enrolment in the senior high schools of the city was indicated in budget estimates disclosed yesterday at the Board of Education.

Demanding "a living American wage," about 2,000 organized workers of the knitted goods industry voted at a meeting in Webster Hall last night to empower their leaders to call a general strike subject to a referendum of the entire membership.

GREENBURG, N.Y., July 12. -- A large party of policemen, firemen and residents were beating the thick woods in this town tonight in a search for an 18-months-old baby who disappeared from his home at 6 P.M. The searchers had powerful searchlights and a bloodhound to aid them, but up to midnight had found no trace of the child.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 12 (AP). -- A slim, methodical young golfer from Syracuse, who has missed par figures on only five holes of the 49 he played thus far, tonight led the field into the quarter-finals of the State junior championship.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 12. -- Bobby Jacobson, 16 years old, of the Hollywood Country Club, today won the New Jersey junior golf championship at the Plainfield Country Club, defeating Wallace Manion, 19-year-old public links entrant, 3 and 1.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 12 (AP). -- Frank Martin, trusty convict who killed the notorious Helen Spence Eaton as she sought to escape prison, was arrested today on a technical charge of murder as a speedy investigation of the killing was promised by Lawrence C. Auten, Assistant Prosecuting Attorney.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 12. -- Two men were arrested here today accused of extorting $2,753 from an old man who had saved hardly more than that after a lifetime of labor and had recently retired. The prisoners, who were lodged in the county jail here on charges of robbery under threat, said they were Edward Witkowski, 35 years old, and Thomas Witkowski, 25, brothers, both of 12 Hassart Street, this city.
ALBANY, July 12. -- Governor Lehman called upon the special session of the Legislature today to appropriate $1,500,000 additional far the elimination of bovine tuberculosis.

Apparently many persons upholding the so-called decency of the movies are unable to understand English, or else they deliberately misinterpret and misstate the aims of the Legion of Decency as reported in the newspapers.

BERLIN, July 12. -- Chancellor Hitler will receive on Monday Reich Bishop Mueller and his law counselor, Dr. August Jaeger, former State Commissioner for the Protestant Church, according to an official announcement today.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 12. -- Like an avalanche rolling down a mountainside, the threat of a general strike in San Francisco and the bay region hourly became more ominous today.

Thirty-seven new waterfowl breeding areas have been created in Connecticut and placed under management this year as part of the nation-wide movement for the establishment of migratory bird refuges, it was announced yesterday by Arthur L. Clark, superintendent of the Connecticut. State Board of Fisheries and Game.

CAMP DIX, N.J., July 12. -- More than 800 Citizens Military Training Camp students from the metropolitan area of New York City and Northern New Jersey arrived here this afternoon on a special train. They joined more than 200 early arrivals and the work of equipping and organizing the men into a regiment immediately got under way.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 12. -- Something approximating a record was set in the Spring Lake invitation tennis tournament today when the starting field of twenty-five teams in the doubles was cut down to a bare total of seven survivors.

An investigation of shipping practices in the intercoastal trade, which was started last February by the Shipping Board, was renewed yesterday morning at the Federal Building, 641 Washington Street, in the presence of about forty steamship operators and representatives of ports served by the intercoastal lines.

The chairman of the Citizens Budget Committee, Peter Grimm, recently appeared before the Commission of Inquiry on Public Service Personnel and suggested special courses in schools and colleges to train young people for careers in the public service, and that appointments and promotions be accorded the winners in competitive examinations rather than from one of the three highest rating candidates.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 12. -- Her mainsail sharp-edged with an air of speed, the America's Cup yacht Yankee today continued to show the two other defense candidates the way around the sea. She defeated Weetamoe 3 minutes and 12 seconds over another squeezed-in triangle of 22 1/2 miles.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended July 11, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,468,000,000, a decrease of $4,000,000, compared with the preceding week and an increase of $238,000,000, compared with the corresponding week in 1933.

ALBANY, July 12. -- Governor Lehman will hear on Monday a plea for legislation at the special session to restore, under State auspices, the fair trade practice provisions dropped from the National Service Industry Codes.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

Professor Roy V. Peel, of New York University, was elected chairman of the City Fusion Party, at a convention held last night at the Hotel Astor. Professor Peel succeeds Maurice P. Davidson, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.

Heywood Broun, president of the American Newspaper Guild, was distributing copies of a special edition of The Guild Reporter attacking The Long Island Press for refusing to recognize the guild, last night at Jamaica Avenue and 165th Street, Jamaica.

Wise though he is about the ways of politics, Peter J. McGuinness of Greenpoint learned a thing or two yesterday about baseball -- baseball, that is, as it is played when the Board of Aldermen meets the Association of City Hall Reporters on the New York Athletic Club diamond at Travers Island.

Negotiations with the banks which would revise the Bankers Agreement to the end that the city could eliminate or materially reduce the $50,000,000 reserve fund which the agreement provides must be put in the 1935 budget are nearing completion, Mayor LaGuardia revealed yesterday.

YARMOUTH, N.S., July 12. -- Four youthful Massachusetts yachtsmen, representing the Vineyard Haven and Beverly Clubs, will match tacks tomorrow in the final series of races for the Prince of Wales Trophy, emblematic of the junior yachting supremacy of North America.

Announcement was made yesterday at the Army Second Corps Area headquarters at Governors Island that the First Army Provisional Train, United States Army Reserve, would begin two weeks of active duty next Sunday at Fort Hancock, Sandy Hook, N.J. Colonel Kingsley G. Martin of 94 Parkway Road, Bronxville, N.Y., will command the unit.

" Noble" John Moore, convict and self-confessed confidence man, created excitement yesterday in Federal court when he shouted from the witness stand that he had been offered $20,000 to stop testifying against William J. Graham, gambling promoter of Reno, Nev., who is on trial with two others here for mail fraud.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12. -- Joseph McCormick, 26 years old, of Montclair, N.J., was killed here today when an autogiro which he was flying on its first trip after structural changes had been made in its design, crashed this afternoon a few minutes after it had taken off from Wings Field, near Conshohocken.
PARIS, July 12. -- George L. Harrison, governor of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, will leave Paris for Berlin tomorrow or Saturday and will sail on the Europa from Bremerhaven on Tuesday.

ALBANY, July 12. -- Governor Lehman started today a campaign for increased consumption of milk which he said would play a part in saving farms from foreclosure, setting factory wheels humming and improving the general health of the State.

Many worshipers wonder if Dr. Charles Stelzle, who suggested that the churches of the city contribute $2,500,000 a year for relief purposes, has a peculiar sense of humor or if he is just uninformed on current facts.

BERLIN, July 12. -- A party of about fifty representatives of American universities, brought here at considerable expense to see the new Germany and observe its functioning, seems likely to go home harboring some doubt as to the universality of the blessings conferred by Nazism.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 12. -- Executives of 100 of the leading railroads of the country are believed ready to approve a plan to seek a 10 per cent increase in freight rates when they convene here tomorrow at the semi-annual meeting of the Association of Railway Executives.

BUENOS AIRES, July 12. -- The fifth battle of Fort Ballivian continued fiercely on all fronts last night and today, according to Paraguayan dispatches. The defeat of two Bolivian infantry regiments is reported in a Paraguayan charge in the Canada Strongest sector this morning and the repulse of several vigorous Bolivian counterattacks in the Canada El Carmen sector with heavy losses to the enemy.

The concerts by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium are in danger of being curtailed, it was announced yesterday. Increased and sustained attendance and the raising of the $8,000 still necessary to complete the $50,000 fund to cover the deficit are the conditions necessary to the completion of the season's schedule.

LONDON, July 12. -- Dr. Axel Munthe, famous Swedish author of a world-wide best seller, "The Story of San Michele," made one of his rare public appearances today at a luncheon of the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds.
Governor Lehman may be opposed for re-election this Fall by a Fusion ticket headed by Samuel Seabury, it was learned yesterday on excellent authority.

It is not pleasant to record a decision by the New York State Court of Appeals refusing to intervene in support of the merit system. For nearly a generation reformers and politicians have been battling over the numerous lucrative court jobs often passed out to ward heelers, in defiance of the constitutional mandate.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 12. -Option betting, modeled on the pari-mutuel system, continued at the Onondaga Racing Association's meet today in the face of the New York State Racing Commission's order that the association act immediately to stop the "illegal selling of option pools."

LONDON, July 12. -- The scientific periodical Nature will publish tomorrow an account of the discovery in pitchblende from the famous deposits in Joachimsthal, Czechoslovakia, of a new radioactive element with a higher atomic number that uranium.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- Satisfied for the present with the increased benefits allowed by the Seventy-third Congress over the veto of President Roosevelt, the national legislative committee of the American Legion has suggested a nation-wide movement for a universal draft law at the next session.

ALBANY, July 12. -- With Governor Lehman insistent that reapportionment be enacted by the Legislature, although no bill that is likely to receive his approval has appeared, one more measure with that aim was introduced today by Democrats.

Interest in the stock market was only a trifle more active yesterday than on the day before, so Wall Street gave first attention to the commodities, particularly wheat and cotton. Bonds were quiet but generally steady.

The popular uprising against nasty films has brought forth in some quarters a counter-cry of censorship. But it is hard to see how censorship figures in what is essentially a buyers' strike. The leaders of the boycott have not asked for legislation.

The first large block party in the program of the East Harlem Community Council's street play project was held last night in East 118th Street between Park and Lexington Avenues. This block is one of the sixteen play streets in the neighborhood in which parties will be given during the Summer.

ALBANY, July 13. -- Governor Lehman today sent two special messages to the Senate and Assembly, one recommending legislation for the relief of holders of guaranteed mortgage certificates and the other dealing with the demand for additional State funds for the common schools.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation today won its fight to obtain lower interest rates for the railroads. Kuhn, Loeb Co. and Spryer Co. of New York agreed to sell, as agents for the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, a $50,000,000 issue of five-year 4 1/2 per cent secured notes at par and accrued interest, charging only 1 per cent of the face value of the notes as expenses.
BERLIN, July 13. -- Striking passages in the address of Chancellor Hitler before the Reichstag tonight follow:
EAST ORANGE, N.J., July 13. -- Mrs. M.E. Risley of Echo Lake today scored an 83 over the Morris County Country Club course to win the women's New Jersey Golf Association's one-day tournament.
BERLIN, July 13. -- Adolf Hitler chose to battle alone today in his greatest crisis since becoming Chancellor.
ELMIRA, N.Y., July 13 (AP). -- A comprehensive program for the commercial use of gliders and sailplanes has been announced by Elias Lustig of New York City, president of a new corporation.

PORTLAND, Ore., July 13. -- Declaring that the National Longshoremen's Labor Board appointed by President Roosevelt had "the provincial viewpoint of San Francisco," Governor Julius L. Meier of Oregon today telegraphed to Senator McNary in Washington urging that it be succeeded by a board representing the entire West Coast unless it could manage to take decisive action at once on the Coast strikes.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 13. -- Boos and cheers, the volume of which showed sentiment to be about evenly divided, marked the opening meeting here today of a series planned by the Legislature's code investigating committee, headed by Senator Albert F. Woodruff of Camden.

The prospect of the election of James J. Dooling, leader of the Fifth Assembly District, as the leader of Tammany Hall on Monday grew brighter yesterday. Several of his supporters, who spent the day trying to bring about the withdrawal of Stephen A. Ruddy, leader of the Sixteenth Assembly District, as a rival candidate, voiced the prediction that Mr. Dooling's name would be the only one for which ballots would be cast.
NEWARK, N.J., July 13. -- Allegations that L. Bamberger Co. purchased German-made goods were denied today on behalf of the store. It was said German goods had not been purchased in many months.

In a message to members of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms, Frederick F. Lyden, secretary, has forwarded the opinion of the association's counsel on the responsibilities of brokers under the new city tax of one-tenth of 1 per cent of gross income.

BERLIN, July 13. -- The journal of the Catholic Diocese of Berlin, which appeared today with a front page photograph of Dr. Eric Klausener, chairman of the Catholic Action Society, who was shot by black-uniformed Hitler Guards on June 30, carried the Bishop of Berlin's "final greeting" to the Catholic leader.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
CLEVELAND, July 13. -- A man and a woman were shot dead and a policeman and two other persons were seriously wounded today in a riot at the downtown county relief administration offices.

While a grand jury was investigating yesterday the charge that Dr. Alter Weiss, 28 years old, offered a $5,000 bribe to two Health Department officials last month to obtain a poultry slaughter house permit, the physician was arrested in his office at 708 Sixth Street, by order of Acting District Attorney Harold W. Hastings.

VIENNA, July 13. -- In connection with the reorganization of the Dollfuss Cabinet, the press announces that a general offensive against all suspected Nazi sympathizers is about to be launched by the Dollfuss Patriotic Front.

Bids have been asked on a total of $16,195,900 of new State and municipal financing next week. This compares with $85,723,643 this week, including the $72,000,000 New York City issue of which $70,000,000 was not sold. The weekly average of new municipal financing for the year to date is $21,746,470.
Continued activity in housing transactions was indicated by the New Jersey realty reports yesterday.

TRENTON, July 13. -- Of 443 persons who took the April examination for admission to the practice of law in New Jersey only 163 were successful, the State Board of Bar Examiners announced today. Only eighty-two of 218 attorneys who took the test for counselors passed.

BUENOS AIRES, July 13. -- A Paraguayan communique tonight announces the retreat of the Bolivians in the Canada el Carmen sector following the failure of a strong counterattack they launched there after one of the heaviest artillery bombardments of the Chaco war.

MONTREAL, July 13 (AP). -- Denver Grigsby dropped Dale Alexander's easy fly in right field with two out in the seventh inning today and two Bears scored to give Newark a 5-to-4 victory over the Royals that evened the series.

PRAGUE, July 13. -- The Prager Tageblatt reprints from a German newspaper, the Emmericher Tageblatt, a description of General Hermann Goering's appearance "as a silver swan" in honor of the seventh centenary of the town of Emmerich.

IF the world of Chaplin's comedies suddenly became the real world and we were forced under threat of death to run about pulling one another's noses, stealing and kicking and throwing pies, our situation might be worse in degree but it would not be worse in kind than that described in Clifford Johnson's "Pirate Junk" (Scribner's, $2.50).

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- William E. Dodd, United States Ambassador to Germany, was directed by Secretary Hull today to make strong representations to the Hitler government against discriminatory treatment of American holders of Dawes and Young Plan bonds as a result of the debt moratorium declared on July 1.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Favorable reports from England featured the Commerce Department's weekly survey of foreign business, made public today. The many industries in the Sheffield district, according to consular reports, are maintaining their "comparatively good position."

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- An NRA legal ruling threatens to restrict public participation in price slashes resulting from President Roosevelt's order that bidders on government contracts may go 15 per cent below their listed Blue Eagle prices.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- The new National Labor Relations Board acted swiftly today in citing eight industrial concerns to show cause why their cases should not be referred to the Department of Justice and the NRA compliance division for removal of Blue Eagles.

A young woman who was learning to drive an automobile had an almost miraculous escape from death yesterday afternoon when the car, accidentally placed in reverse, backed off the dock at the foot of East Seventieth Street, into about thirty feet of swirling tide water.

BERLIN, July 13. -- The Foreign Press Association of Berlin, many of whose members were recently assailed by Propaganda Minister Paul Joseph Goebbels for spreading erroneous reports in connection with Chancellor Hitler's "second revolution," delivered its answer today.

DETROIT, July 13. -- A record that promises to endure for all time was attained on Navin Field today when Babe Ruth smashed his seven-hundredth home run in a lifetime career. It promises to live, first, because few players of history have enjoyed the longevity on the diamond of the immortal Bambino, and, second, because only two other players in the history of baseball have hit more than 300 home runs.

BERLIN, July 13. -- Before the German Reichstag assembled in the Kroll Opera House tonight Adolf Hitler, Chancellor of the Reich and supreme leader of the National Socialist party, gave an account of the incipient rebellion against his authority and an accounting of the deaths entailed in the suppression of it.

BOSTON, July 13 (AP). -- Wally Berger's twentieth homer of the season started a four-run drive in the seventh that enabled the Braves to defeat the Cubs, 7 -- 6, today in the last game of the series. Bill Lee, who pitched the Cubs to their only other two setbacks this month, was charged with the defeat.

CEDARHURST, L.I., July 13. -- Edward B. Austin's medal-waning 74 and T. Suffern Tailer's failure to place in the first sixteen were the high lights of the qualifying round today in the Rockaway Hunting Club's invitation golf tournament.

The dispute over the right of union labor to picket in Jersey City, which began a month and a half ago and has been marked by nineteen arrests, including those of Corliss Lamont and Alfred M. Bingham, apparently ended yesterday when Acting Mayor Arthur Potterton conceded virtually all the demands of the labor unions and the Civil Liberties Union, which jointly waged the campaign.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 13. -Frank Parker of Spring Lake and Lawrenceville hurdled one of his most dangerous obstacles in the invitation tennis tournament at the Bathing and Tennis Club today when he defeated Berkeley Bell in the quarter-finals, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4.

BERLIN, July 13 (By Wireless). -- A young German war hero stood with his back against the red brick wall of the Lichterfelde Cadet School, facing a line of soldiers with uplifted rifles. Quickly he raised his right arm and tore open his Storm Trooper's jacket.

Ambrose V. McCall, Assistant State Attorney General, in charge of the Bureau of Securities, announced yesterday that Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck had signed an order restraining permanently R.R. Dancy Co., Inc., 509 Fifth Avenue, and Otto Schmidt, president and treasurer of the company, from the sale of any stocks, including commodities dealt in on any Exchange, within the State of New York.
" Her Majesty, the Widow," will end its engagement this evening at the Ritz Theatre and "Gypsy Blonde" will close at the Lyric Theatre.
WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Movements of vessels follow. All dates are July 12 unless specified.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 13. -- Coming through shadowy waters, with sea and sky streaked east and west, the America's Cup yacht Yankee slid past Brenton Lightship today to win her fourth race of the New York Yacht Club's observation contests to select a defender.

WHITEFIELD, N.H., July 13. -Blessed by mountain showers while the lightning made the new stage wires sputter and an overture of rolling thunder echoed among the White Hills, the Yale University theatre's post-graduate students, known as the Forty-Niners, began an eight-week season here tonight with a house sold out and a play, "The Two Orphans," over which three generations had wept and thrilled.

We have repealed the Eighteenth Amendment, devalued the dollar, created large reservoirs of cheap bank credit, extended held to the farmer and home owner, provided relief to industry and the unemployed, stimulated some activity by public works, recognized Russia, are contemplating a housing campaign to stimulate heavy industry -- in fine, induced supreme efforts within the country.

A taxi driver, the father of four children, who "couldn't get the breaks," yesterday leaped to his death from a ferryboat plying between 125th Street and Fort Lee, N.J. An attempt to rescue him failed because a swift tide carried his body rapidly downstream, at a pace faster than the ferryboat could maintain, although the captain sent his boat off its course and pursued the body until it disappeared from sight at 116th Street.

EAST HAMPTON, N.Y., July 13. -- Dr. and Mrs. Louis Faugeres Bishop gave a dinner tonight at Bishops' Gate for Mr. and Mrs. Abram I. Elkus, their week-end house guests. Mr. Elkus is a former United States Ambassador to Turkey.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- A contract for construction of the Grand Coulee Dam and power plant in the Columbia Basin of Washington State to the Silas Mason Company of New York City, the Atkinson Kier Company of San Francisco, and the Walsh Construction Company of Davenport, Iowa, with a joint low bid of $29,339,301, was awarded today by Secretary Ickes.

LONDON, July 13. -- Great Britain, so far as its government and Parliament are concerned, fully approves the new French plan for an "Eastern Locarno" which Foreign Minister Louis Barthou laid before the British Cabinet Monday and Tuesday.

OKLAHOMA CITY, July 13 (AP). -- The Western amateur golf tournament today became a battle of the South -- and of youth -- when Jack Westland of Chicago, a United States Walker Cup player, was shorn of his title by Dave Goldman of Dallas and the veteran Chick Evans of Chicago was eliminated by Verne Stewart of Albuquerque, N.M, in a stirring quarter-final match.

Steel work on the new $850,000 building of the Jewish Memorial Hospital, at the northeast corner of Broadway and 196th Street, has been completed and construction work is being pushed in order to permit occupancy of the structure early next year, Dr. Jacob Carlinger, superintendent, announced yesterday.

ROME, July 13. -- A government communique announced today that the Italian Government had withdrawn its objections to the Eastern European pact of mutual assistance sponsored by Foreign Minister Barthou of France and Foreign Commissar Litvinoff of Russia.

CHICAGO, July 13. -- Hogs were picked up readily today at an advance of 10 to 15 cents a hundred-weight. A top price of $5.05 was paid as against $4.95 yesterday. The average price was $4.60, an advance of 10 cents. Most sales were at $4.15 to $5, compared with $4.05 to $4.80 yesterday.

OTTAWA, July 15. -- A determined drive against further adherence to the world wheat agreement which has begun in the Canadian Prairie Provinces makes the possibility of its continuance next year extremely remote. Canada will live up to it this year because Premier Bennett said so in emphatic terms.

An interdenominational conference of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, representing Protestant groups with a membership of 22,000,000 persons, voted yesterday to present a "united front" with the Roman Catholic Legion of Decency in its campaign for more wholesome motion pictures.

SYRACUSE, July 13. -- The annual encampment of the Veterans of Foreign Wars today unanimously approved a resolution for making mandatory, through State legislation, an oath of allegiance to the United States for all public school teachers.
Police Commissioner John F. O'Ryan held an impromptu hearing in the trial room at police headquarters yesterday, dismissed one patrolman from the force and fined four others.

LONDON, July 13 (Canadian Press). -- The touring Australian cricketers today defeated Derbyshire by nine wickets in a game started Wednesday at Chesterfield. The Australians had a first innings score of 255, then tallied 32 for one after Derbyshire had scored 145 and followed on for 139.

COCOS ISLAND, Pacific Ocean, July 13 (AP). -- President Roosevelt, headed for the Hawaiian Islands aboard the cruiser Houston, paused today at uninhabited Cocos Island, an old pirate rendezvous, and immediately started to fish.

EASTERN POINT, Conn., July 13. -- Averaging close to 200 yards with her drives and displaying a brilliant short game, Miss Jean Bauer of Providence, R.I., gained her first leg on the Griswold golf trophy today at the Shenecossett Country Club.

BERLIN, July 13 (AP). -- Chancellor Hitler's statement in his speech today that his "cleansing" of the Nazi party was undertaken "with power derived not through bayonets but from the heart of the people" was taken by many to be an answer to recent criticisms from Vice Chancellor Franz von Papen.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations, including processing tax, on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

Five officers of the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, including Cortlandt Field Bishop, director and chief owner, must testify before trial in the suit of Barnet J. Beyer, Inc., dealer in rare books, against the art association for $15,386 damages.

CHICAGO, July 13. -- All interested groups united today for the first time in presenting to Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson a plan for reorganization of Middle West Utilities Company, the great Insull holding concern.

Three counterclaims totaling $2,066,082, which had been interposed by William Fox in the suit brought against him by equity receivers for the Fox Theatres Corporation, were dismissed yesterday by the Appellate Division in Brooklyn.
Comment of leading American newspapers on the speech made by Chancellor Hitler yesterday follows:

BADEN, July 13. -- Ivy Lee, whose testimony that he had been retained by the German Dye Trust at $25,000 a year as an adviser on American relations was made public in New York, arrived here late yesterday to take the cure. His health has not been good for some time.

Ninety-five Germans arrived in New York yesterday on the Hamburg-American liner Hamburg to spend two weeks in this country. The group is the second from Europe that will tour the United States as a result of the devaluation of the dollar.

BOSTON, July 13 (AP). -- The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "Interest in wool, both in the East and West, has been at low ebb this week. Manufacturers have evinced very little desire to own wool at the prices asked here, especially since the sharp drop in London and the buyers of goods evidently are convinced that a drop in wool prices is inevitable and so they are waiting.
WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Georgia's action in directing cuts in railroad passenger fares within that State was challenged by the Interstate Commerce Commission today when it ordered an investigation.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 13. -- From the farm to the factory lies the way to the "more abundant life" according to Mordecai Ezekiel, economic adviser to the Secretary of Agriculture.

ST. LOUIS, July 13 (AP). -- Wesley Ferrell's two home runs were more than enough to give the Red Sox a victory over the Browns today, but his team-mates chipped in to run up a 7-to-2 score in the series opener.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- A single valuation write-up of $40,000,000 was found in the books of the Power Corporation of New York by an examiner for the Federal Trade Commission, it was revealed today. According to the commission, the write-up was brought about Dec. 31, 1928, by increasing the book value of "water-power rights and privileges" by that amount, which was credited to "surplus due to appreciation."

Local Republican leaders turned cold shoulders yesterday to the suggestion that Samuel Seabury be named, with their support, to head a State-wide Fusion ticket to oppose Governor Lehman, or any other Democratic nominee, in the Fall Gubernatorial election.

CHICAGO, July 13. -- Dollar wheat was realized today for December delivery on the Chicago Board of Trade, the highest price since June 1. The advance to $1 a bushel occurred in the last hour of active trading, and was met by a reaction of 3/8 to 1/2 cent a bushel, the close being at 99 3/8 to 99 1/2 cents for old and 99 1/2 to 99 5/8 cents for new style.

PARIS, July 13. -- Twenty million francs for the protection of the population of Paris against gas and aerial attacks was voted today by the General Council of the Department of the Seine. The franc is worth about 6.60 cents at current exchange.

PARIS, July 13. -- With the promulgation of the so-called, Tasso law today, the government commences a heavy subsidy for the French merchant marine which is expected to have a telling effect on world shipping and international trade. Its importance to France will be to save the merchant marine, which is in a desperate situation.

With Joe Moore, lead-off man par excellence, stroking the world's champions along at a blistering pace, the Giants sent the Pirates' rapidly fading pennant hopes down to a vanishing point yesterday by coming home in front in the series final at the Polo Grounds, 7 to 6.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in this State, now offered by dealers:

CLEVELAND, July 13 (AP). -- The Senators took the first of a four-game series with the Indians, 3 to 2, today at the cost of Right Fielder Jonathan Stone, who suffered a fracture of the left ankle and was carried from the field.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP). -- The Republican campaign officials said today that while "some of our better known comedians" were on vacation, Democratic spokesmen were providing the people with "entertainment."

LONDON, Saturday, July 14. -- In its almost unanimous approval of the Eastern Locarno plan the British press foresees that from the beginning of the regional agreement a general system of security may gradually be established under which a reduction of national armaments will at most automatically follow.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 13. -- Miss Rosalie Knapp of the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club today won the third annual women's Long Island medal play tournament over the links of the North Hempstead Country Club.

Why does Mr. FARLEY, about to irradiate the West, deny his light to Wisconsin? He won't poke his nose into its politics -- not again for the present, that is. He leaves the job to Mr. ROOSEVELT. It promises to be a rather delicate one. Some time ago Mr. FARLEY seemed to give his blessing to a Democratic candidate for Senator.

RAPID CITY, S.D., July 13. -- Following a study of weather charts at the camp in Spring Creek Canyon whence the national geographic Army Air Corps stratosphere balloon flight will start, Major William E. Kepner, pilot, said today that he saw no chance of a take-off for another forty-eight hours.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Secretary Wallace, on his return from a trip to Western farming districts, said today that so far as he could observe numbers of farmers "want more rather than less Federal regulation."
Leasehold deals dominated realty trading in Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday. Most of the day's activity in the former borough was confined to the West Side.

Offering himself yesterday as a mediator of the differences between The Long Island Daily Press of Jamaica and its discharged employes, members of the Newspaper Guild, Mayor LaGuardia invited both sides to meet him at City Hall this morning.

BERLIN, July 13. -- The names of the judges who are to sit in the first great National Socialist judicial body, the People's Court for the trial of treason cases, were announced today. In all, there are thirty-two appointees, of which twelve are professional lawyers, five army officers, five Storm Troop captains, five aviation commanders and five Nazi party officials.

The third opera bill at the Lewisohn Stadium was given last night, Alexander Smallens conducting, and was devoted to Mascagni's "Cavalleria Rusticana" and Leoncavallo's "Pagliacci." The attendance, between seven and eight thousand, was larger than at any former opera given in this place.

The splendidly written communication of Dr. Walter E. Spahr captioned "Opposing Natural Order" appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES deserves a vote of thanks from the befuddled man in the street for its enlightening clarity and logic -- as far as it goes.

One of the many things the Legislature left undone which it should have done at the regular session last Winter was relief for the holders of guaranteed mortgage certificates. Moreland Commissioner ALGER and his associates pleaded in vain. The problem still remains, and for the 300,000-odd certificate holders it is very pressing.
DETROIT, July 13. -- The incomparable Babe Ruth reached his goal today with his 700th home run, a wallop that helped in sending the Yankees back into the lead in the American League pennant race.

ST. THOMAS, V.I., July 13. -- A new turn in the political life of these islands occurred today when hundreds of black and white natives, including members of the French colony, rushed to the Federal District Court in the expectation of witnessing the trial of two government employes charged with theft and padding of payrolls of the Public Works Department here.

The operations of subsidiaries of intercoastal conference steamship lines were studied yesterday at the resumption of the Shipping Board investigation of intercoastal practices, at the Federal Building, 641 Washington Street. The rivalries of competing ports, and pier practices and trucking operations in the haulage of intercoastal freight were also the subject of testimony, with non-conference executives probing into the affairs of their conference competitors.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 13. -- Governor Lehman personally stopped the option system of betting at the State Fair Grounds race track today.

A ninth-inning Brooklyn drive, its greatest momentum coming from two Cincinnati misplays, fell short of the necessary total and the Reds scored their second straight victory over the Dodgers yesterday, 8 to 6, to even the series.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 13. -- Mr. and Mrs. Goodhue Livingston gave a dinner tonight at Old Trees for Miss Alice Van Rensselaer, Francis Henry Balfour Byrne and Ashbel H. Barney, who are visiting them.

Protests against the NRA order permitting reformatories and other sheltered workshops to use Blue Eagle labels on garments they produce will be made to L.M. Collins, Division Administrator, in Washington Monday by Colonel R.B. Paddock, executive director of the Cotton Garment Code Authority, and representatives of garment producers.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 13. -- The week-end entertaining got under way in earnest in the Summer colony today and there promises to be plenty to keep everybody busy until after Sunday.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 13. -- An appeal to Indiana to select Democrats as their representatives in Congress as a means of helping President Roosevelt to complete the giant task of national recovery was delivered here tonight by Postmaster General James A. Farley, chairman of the National Democratic Committee.
Money market was quiet and quotations unchanged for all classifications. Stock Exchange call loans were 1 per cent, while 3/4 prevailed in the counter trading.

Former Magistrate Francis X. McQuade's efforts to force the city to pay him a pension of about $6,000 a year received a setback yesterday when Supreme Court Justice O'Brien filed a decision rejecting Mr. McQuade's application for a mandamus requiring the Board of Estimate to vote the pension.
ST. PAUL, July 13 (AP). -- Horton Smith of Chicago smashed par with a 68 today to lead the field in the opening eighteen holes of the $5,000 St. Paul open golf championship.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 13. -The first all-Wagner program of the season was presented by the New York Orchestra under the direction of Nikolai Sokoloff this evening before another large audience at Music Hall, the open-air theatre in Weston.

A hearing yesterday before Chairman Milo R. Maltbie of the Public Service Commission on the proposed $6,845,500 bond issue of the Long Island Lighting Company developed into competitive bidding for the issue. Two offers were made from the floor in competition with the contract of sale for which the company sought approval.
