But Beale Street is not only a thoroughfare; it is also a state of mind.

Your editorial "Economics and Ethics'' properly calls attention to the formality complex dominating the "dismal science." In their desire to make economics closely resemble the so-called exact sciences our economists persistently apply mathematical and philosophical methods in a field in which they have to do mainly with human nature and intelligence.

Plans for the erection of new homes in outlying sections of the metropolitan area were announced in connection with sales of lots negotiated over the week-end. The suburban lot market was unusually brisk for this time of the year. Another feature of the week-end activity was the demand for property in New Jersey.

ZURICH, Switzerland, July 15. -- H. Johner of Switzerland took the lead in the International Chess Masters' tournament today, winning his adjourned game from Salo Flohr of Czechoslovakia, then defeating his countryman, H. Grob, in the second round.

Dr. TILDSLEY'S report on the high schools of this city for the year ending June 30, 1934, is not a mere statistical review. But there is one significant outstanding statistical fact: there was an increased enrolment of 9,364, with a decrease of 524 in teaching positions. The result was overcrowding, an overloading of teachers, an over-use of substitute teachers.

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- After more than twenty-eight months of secret investigation, public hearings and legislative activities on the floor of the Senate, the Senate Banking and Currency Committee gave out today a bulky report covering in detail its activities from March 2, 1932, to the enactment of the Securities and Exchange Act on June 6.

To speak of a "general strike" in San Francisco is misleading. It is a local strike. Moreover, it is of the general nature of a sympathetic strike. Several trade unions, though they have no grievances of their own, are going on strike in support of the dockmen who have been on strike up and down the Coast for more than two months.

KOHLER, Wis., July 15 (AP). -- Kohler Village, the "near Utopian dream community," established and developed during the last two decades by Walter J. Kohler, wealthy industrialist and former Wisconsin Governor, prepared tonight for its first strike demonstration.

Offering will be made today of a new issue of $2,962,000 State of South Carolina 4 1/2 per cent highway certificates of indebtedness. The certificates, due serially from Aug. 1, 1944 to 1953, will be priced to yield 4.30 to 4.35 per cent.

On the first page of this newspaper last Saturday, side by side, were accounts of two interchanges between representatives of the American and the German Governments. Both come under the classification of diplomacy, but they are wholly different in their importance. The protest of the German Charge d'Affaires at Washington and the Secretary of State's reply were entirely diplomatic, a thing solely for the record.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 15. -- The Aiken Cyclones polo team, with Dunbar Bostwick, Jimmy Mills, Elbridge Gerry and Devereux Milburn riding in that order, downed Raymond Guest's Templeton four, 7 to 3, in a special high goal match a Bostwick Field in Old Westbury today.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 15. -- The threat of a renewal of the truck drivers' strike, which tied up commercial transportation for ten days in May, hung over Minneapolis tonight as Governor Olson, E.H. Dunnigan, conciliation commissioner of the Labor Department, and members of the Regional Labor Board met with leaders of the truck drivers' and helpers' union in a last-minute effort to avert the walkout.

With the arrival here last week of the first large contingent of buyers seeking Fall merchandise, business activity increased sharply throughout the wholesale markets. Liberal buying was noticed in all Fall lines, but the demand was heaviest in the staple goods. Many buyers of apparel and accessories are due here this week.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 15. -Mgr. Lavelle of St. Patrick's Cathedral, New York, visited the C.M.T.C. camp in the pines here tonight, and was greeted by Colonel W.D. Wallace, commanding officer of the Twenty-sixth Infantry; Lieut. Col. Wallace H. Watts, the regimental chaplain; Major Benjamin A. Tinter and Lieutenant Felix Burant, the reserve chaplains.

CHICAGO, July 15. -- A marble column from the ancient Roman Forum was formally presented to the city of Chicago by Italo Balbo, speaking from Rome over the radio today. The column, standing in front of the Italian Building at the fair, was unveiled at exercises commemorating the good-will flight of Balbo and his air squadron to Chicago a year ago.

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- The $3,700,000,000 which has been made available to the emergency Public Work Administration since its establishment was virtually depleted by the allotments in excess of $100,000,000 which were announced in the last few days, the PWA stated today.

As a citizen who is deeply interested in the greater Consumption of milk I read with interest your account of the luncheon at Albany yesterday arranged by Governor Lehman to discuss plans for using the $500,000 appropriated by the Legislature in a campaign to increase the consumption of milk.
PRAGUE, July 15 (AP). -- Australia defeated Czechoslovakia, three matches to two, in the European Zone Davis Cup tennis final today and qualified to meet the United States in the interzone final.

In Maryland such a struggle of politicians for power as would have interested the late FREDERICK SCOTT OLIVER of "The Endless Adventure" has been going on for some months. Shall Governor RITCHIE have a fifth term? That would make his tenure only one year short of Sir ROBERT WALPOLE'S as chief Minister.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., July 15. -- The dance last evening in the Sagamore grill was well attended. Many dinners preceded it. Mr. and Mrs. Karl P. Abbott entertained for Mr. and Mrs. Carl Ellerman and Mr. and Mrs. C. Eugene Hames of New York City; Mr. and Mrs. Newton C. Boykin of Camden, S.C., who have a cottage on Green Island, entertained for Mr. and Mrs. Gaylor Tucker and Mrs. Woods Robinson of Saratoga Springs.

A new mode of commuting will begin this morning when the first plane of the New York and Suburban Airways, Inc., flies from Oyster Bay, L.I., to the East River float at the foot of Wall Street with ten passengers. The ship, under control of Stanley W. Jacques, has been booked to capacity and will run morning and evening from Mondays to Fridays each week until the end of the Summer.

Reports to New York from the outlying Summer theatres say that, despite the heat and other adversities, the rural drama is generally holding its own and that this week probably will be the most active this season.
Yes, definitions are important and must be accurate.

ALBANY, July 15. -- Conflicting trends in political opinion on reforms in county government, both in New York City and up-State, will be disclosed tomorrow at a public hearing on all pending measures before the extraordinary session of the Legislature.
ST. LOUIS, July 15 (AP). -- Runs and hits were plentiful today as the Red Sox and Browns split a doubleheader.

Modern teaching aids, including motion pictures, colored slides, photographs and drawings, are among the items on view at the annual education exhibit opening today at the Columbia University Summer School session. More than 5,000 textbooks, including the latest for elementary, high school and college use, are shown.

OKLAHOMA CITY, July 15. -- Zell Eaton of Oklahoma City, the medalist, celebrated his twenty-first birthday today by winning the Western amateur golf championship on the wind-swept Twin Hills course with a 4 and 3 conquest of Dave Goldman of Dallas in the 76-hole final of the thirty-sixth annual tournament.

BERLIN, July 14. -- The crop condition report as of July 1 shows serious deterioration. On the index basis whereby 2 equals good, 3 middling and 4 bad, Winter wheat moved in June from 3 to 3.2, Spring wheat from 3 to 3.4, Winter rye from 2.9 to 3.1 and oats from 2.9 to 3.4.

POSSIBLY Bill Terry will have another chapter to add to this short story. They tell the tale differently. Some say that Bill was once a left-handed pitcher but repented and became a more-than-respectable first baseman of his own accord. It may have been a matter of conscience, or he read the history of Rube Waddell, Duster Mails and others of that ilk and decided to lead a better life.

Russell Doubleday, who has just come from Kennebunkport, Me., says Booth Tarkington has a new sport called "whale-watching." Almost every day now he runs his motor boat about five miles out to sea and looks for whales. He says he saw one that was at least sixty feet long.

MOSCOW, July 15. -- A new method of treatment discovered and developed by Dr. I.N. Kasakof is being applied in the State Scientific Institute for Metabolic and Endocrine Disorders in Moscow. The method is called lizatotherapy -- hydrolyzation cure is the closest English translation -- because it consists of injections prepared by subjecting certain human and animal organs to the action of water under high pressure in an autoclave.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 15. -- Scoring a total of seven goals, Tommy Hitchcock Jr. led a White team to an 11-to-5 triumph over a Red combination at the Sands Point Club today. Stephen Sanford at back was the high scorer for the losers with three markers.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP). -- The Federal Government was disclosed today to be planning to take a direct hand in the meat canning business as a relief measure.

A special report to stockholders by the American Superpower Corporation, as of June 30, shows that "in order to more nearly reflect, on its books, the approximate market value of the corporation's holdings in common stocks and option warrants, a reserve of $65,000,000 on account of decrease in market value from the book cost of such securities has been created by transferring approximately $37,000,000 from capital surplus and the balance from earned surplus."

RYE, N.Y., July 15. -- Swallow the brand-new six-meter yacht owned by the Philip J. Roosevell syndicate, was victorious today a sixty-seven boats, the largest Sunday fleet of the season, competed in the American Yacht Club's special regatta.
LIDO BEACH, L.I., July 15. -- Six hundred members and guests attended a supper dance on the terrace of the Lido Country Club this evening.

NEW ORLEANS, July 15. -- A decided increase in activity featured the cotton market last week, the unexpectedly bullish character of the government's acreage estimate coupled with the continued drought in the West and a decidedly unfavorable weekly weather and crop report on Wednesday stimulating active buying not only by the trade but by outsiders as well.
DETROIT, July 15. -- Hank Greenberg, a lad from the Bronx who plays first base for Mickey Cochrane's Tigers, today dealt the Yankees a crushing blow at Navin Field before 26,000 highly excited fans.

PARIS, July 15. -- With that skill in diplomatic oratory which leaves the listener or reader free to interpret the words according to his inclination Foreign Minister Louis Barthou spoke at Bayonne today of his conversations in London and of the proposed "Eastern Locarno" pact in a manner which conveyed a great deal but left a great deal more of what was meant to be guessed at.

BERLIN, July 14. -- Business activity in Germany is slackening, partly because of the approach of the holidays. The decline in the number of unemployed by only 47,000 in June is considered unsatisfactory here, and indicates that the Spring and Summer seasonal activity is ebbing earlier than usual. In June, 1933, the number of unemployed declined 150,000.

Recognition is becoming general that substantial recovery in addition to what we have already achieved depends upon improvement in the "durable goods" industries. The latest report of the Federal Reserve Board, while revealing a promising trend in these industries, shows them to be still much further below normal than the consumption goods trades.

Displaying an unusual lack of consideration for the feeling of 22,000 fans assembled at Ebbets Field yesterday to view their favorites, the Dodgers succumbed to the Cardinals in both ends of a double-header.

STOCKHOLM, July 15 (London Times Dispatch). -- Chancellor Hitler seems to have made Scandinavia safer than ever for democracy. At no time has the general attitude of the Swedes, the Norwegians and the Danes toward Germany been more critical than today.

Nine war memorial playgrounds were dedicated and opened to the public by Mayor LaGuardia yesterday afternoon. They were built by the Park Department from a $350,000 police war memorial fund released by a court decree from the custody of the City Chamberlain.

PHILADELPHIA, July 15. -- Modification of the general boycott of moving-pictures theatres in this area was demanded today by the Musicians Protective Association, Local 77. The musicians' demand was concurred in by the Central Labor Union of Philadelphia.

BUENOS AIRES, July 15. -- The Paraguayan right wing has established contact with Fort D'Orbigny, seventy miles northwest of Fort Ballivian and fifty miles northwest of Fort Guachalla, on the Pilcomayo River, according to unofficial dispatches from Asuncion.
One man was injured fatally and seven other persons were hurt severely yesterday in a head-on collision of two automobiles on the Pulaski Skyway in Jersey City.

BELGRADE, July 15. -- The Yugoslav newspaper Politika reports from Sofia that the new Bulgarian Government has issued an order to all military and civilian authorities that Ivan Mihailoff, leader of the Macedonian revolutionary forces who has lived on both sides of the Bulgarian-Yugoslav frontier at various times since 1918 as the uncrowned King of Macedonia, is to be arrested or killed within fourteen days.

The 1934 pennant drive of the Giants swung sharply back into its proper gearing at the Polo Grounds yesterday as the world's champions, with Mel Ott's two doubles blasting three of their runs across the plate, brought down the Cubs in the second game of the current series, 5 to 3.
PORTLAND, Ore., July 15. -- Following is the text of General Hugh S. Johnson's speech here today before the Pacific Coast Association of Advertising Clubs as he prepared it for delivery:

Guatemala is ready to settle several thousand German-Jewish refugees on government land, according to a plan now up for ratification by the HICEM, the joint board of the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society and the Jewish Colonization Association.

Having finished two sets in the ambitious mural series undertaken a year or more ago in the New York State Training School for Boys at Warwick, N.Y., the artist, Jo Cain, reports that he will begin this week on a fresh division of the work, sketches for which have already been prepared.
RUMSON, N.J., July 15. -- Burnt Mills, by the slim margin of 11 goals to 10, rode into the semifinals of the national junior polo championship with a victory over Rumson today.

JONES BEACH, L.I., July 15. -- Recouping the amazing distance of fifteen yards in the last 100 meters as he thrashed over the dull gray waters of Zach's Bay in a magnificent sprint that brought him from last to first, Paul Friesel of the Dragon Club won the national A.A.U. junior 220-yard breast stroke championship today.

LONDON, July 14. -- There is some conflict of opinion concerning the prospects of British trade. Business men here are rather inclined to view the peak of activity as having been reached, if not actually passed, although all available statistics appear to show that trade is being well maintained.
CLEVELAND, July 15 (AP). -- The Indians won both games of a double-header from Washington today by duplicate scores of 10 to 8 and pushed the Senators more firmly into the second division.

Except in the grain trade -- where prices, for obvious reasons, rose last week with much violence -- markets continue to present the picture of apathy often associated heretofore with midsummer. If, however, a strong initiative existed in financial sentiment, whether pointing to better conditions or to worse, experience proves that the picture would be different.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 15 (AP). -- A new Constitution for Brazil, which provides among other things for a "brain trust" whose unanimous opinion cannot be rejected by Cabinet Ministers, was published today.

Apropos THE NEW YORK TIMES editorial "Definitions," quoting John W. Davis's defense of the real principles of laissez-faire in his University of Virginia address, is the fine definition of the term "laissez-faire" by Overton H. Taylor, one of the seven Harvard economists who criticized the New Deal in a book entitled "The Economics of the Recovery Program," which was published this Spring. Professor Taylor writes:

Prices swung upward in successive waves on the Cotton Exchange last week, following the publication of the government's acreage report, and net gains for the week exceeded $3 a bale. Professional and outside interest was great throughout the period, and efforts were made to determine what relationship existed between the prospective yields and the reduced acreage sown.

Cecil B. DeMille's next production for Paramount following "Cleopatra," which is now before the cameras, will be "The Crusades," a story of the religious wars based on Harold Lamb's book. Mr. Lamb has been engaged to prepare the screen script, and production will begin late this Summer.

CHICAGO, July 15. -- A desire to revenge himself for the loss of his job on the town of Guthrie, Ky., fanned into a criminal plot through the reading of Mark Twain's short story "The Man That Corrupted Hadleyburg," landed Gordon Morgan, 43 years old, in a cell here today.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 15. -- San Francisco and the bay region today began to feel in earnest the blighting paralysis of the general strike, officially scheduled to go into effect at 8 A.M. tomorrow.

In general, married women make better school teachers than their unmarried sisters, according to a survey made by Dr. David Peters of Teachers College, Columbia University. Pupils taught by married women teachers have a higher measure of achievement than those taught by single women teachers.

BERLIN, July 14. -- Pending Chancellor Hitler's statement to the Reichstag, from which it was hoped to judge whether the government intended to continue on the path of terrorism or to attempt reconciliation, business circles showed much reserve, and there was a marked decline in new orders to manufacturers.

It was announced recently that Commissioner O'Ryan had ordered patrolmen to take note of smoking chimneys. All along the East River, day and night, tall chimneys belch forth dirty brown smoke which from time to time becomes black and thick. Evenings in this weather people climb to the roofs for rest even for sleep.

Though the financial, social and other foundations upon which so many of us relied have been destroyed, the foundations of faith still exist unshaken, the Rev. Dr. Lewis Seymour Mudge, Stated Clerk of the Presbyterian General Assembly and former Moderator, declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue at 105th Street.

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- The general strike in San Francisco will be left to Mayor Rossi and the Governor of California to handle for the present, with authorities here keeping a careful eye on developments and constantly flashing news by radio to President Roosevelt on the cruiser Houston in the Pacific.
ST. PAUL, Minn., July 15 (AP). -- Johnny Revolta of Milwaukee shot a brilliant 65 today to tie Harry Cooper of Chicago and Ky Laffoon of Denver for first honors in the St. Paul Open Championship.
BERLIN, July 15 (AP). -- Germany turned from considering the after-effects of Chancellor Hitler's party cleansing today to another nationwide Nazi "Tag Day."

The lumber industry is virtually at a standstill, J. Herbert Bate, president of the lumber concern of J. Herbert Bate Company, Inc., charged yesterday. He declared this was due to unnecessary delay on the part of the National Recovery Administration and the Code Authority for the lumber industry in making public a set of new code prices.

Winning two matches on his first day of play, Percy L. Kynaston, twice winner of the title, reached the quarter-finals of the Richmond County clay court tennis championship at the Clifton Tennis Club in Arrochar yesterday.
The nation-wide campaign for moral motion pictures was recommended yesterday from pulpits throughout the city.

HOUSTON, Texas, July 15. -- Three Negro independent longshoremen were shot to death, a fourth was wounded probably fatally, and two others and a white member of the International Longshoremen's Association were shot in a gun fight near the ship channel here today.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP). -The nation's business men were told today by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States that, despite expressed Presidential hopes, any balancing of the budget before 1937 appeared "doubtful."

Creditors and stockholders of the Associated Telephone Utilities Company have been notified by William J. Wardall, as trustee of the estate of the company, that by order of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York it was ordered that all their claims and interests must be filed or evidenced by Aug. 25.

Adam Heiselman, Eddie Woelke and Billy Densmore forgot their beer last night in Toby's Bar at 143 East Forty-fifth Street as they went deeper and deeper into the legends of the robust era of drinking in New York.

The charter-makers devoted considerable attention last week to the administrative side of local government. They decided, for one thing, to make no fundamental changes in the present organization of the Police and Fire Departments. That is wise. These two departments are properly constituted today, with a commissioner at the head of each, responsible directly to the Mayor.

PORTLAND, Ore., July 15. -- Casting aside all hope for waterfront peace, organized labor of Portland moved definitely today toward a general strike. Efforts to unite labor of the Pacific Northwest behind a last-minute program for negotiation and settlement apparently had failed.

LONDON, July 15. -- Chancellor Hitler's Reichstag speech of Friday "carries no conviction at all," declares The London Times in an editorial that derides his account of the alleged conspiracy of June 30.

Weaknesses developed last week in many of the commodity futures markets here despite the rise in wheat and certain other major staples, and the resumption of talk of an inflated currency in trade and financial circles. The volume of trading was small.

A reduced scale of prices for orchestra seats will go into effect at tonight's performance of "As Thousands Cheer," at the Music Box Theatre. The new prices will be $3.85 instead of $4.40 for evenings and $2.75 instead of $3.30 for matinees.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 15. -- Science even to the extent of picked brain trusts has been resorted to in the rivalry between the America's Cup yachts Yankee and Rainbow in their struggle for selection to defend the cup.

YORK, Pa., July 15. -- Fred C. Perkins, an alleged violator of the NRA code covering the battery industry, was out on bail today after spending seventeen days in jail because he was unable to furnish a $5,000 bond to insure his appearance at the October term of court.

CEDARHURST, L.I., July 15. -- Never trailing at any time, Eddie Driggs Jr. of Cherry Valley, New York State amateur champion, defeated Rudy Knepper of the Garden City Golf Club by 2 and 1 in the final today to win the Rockaway Hunting Club's invitation tourney.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 15 (AP). -- Rochester's led Wings cut the Newark Bears' lead to one and one-half games today by taking both ends of a twin bill from the league leaders. Norbert Kleinke pitched the first game, an 8-3 decision, and Ira Smith handed the Bruins their initial shutout of the season in the nightcap, 4 -- 0.

PORTSMOUTH, England, July 15. -- Fifteen out of the twenty-three men of Endeavour's crew went on strike and left the ship today, refusing to accept the wages which the owner, T.O.M. Sopwith, offered them.

CHICAGO, July 15 (AP). -- In Miles City, Mont., only 1.43 inches of rain have fallen since Jan. 1, the United States Weather Bureau said today, and thus Miles City has led all stations covered by the Middle Western bureau in aridity.

LONDON, July 15 (By Cable). -The pleasures of traveling have been enhanced for Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the United States President, by her living with American friends in American homes on her present visit abroad.

Adoption of a State code to regulate the laundry industry was urged by Mayor LaGuardia in a telegram yesterday to Governor Lehman, who has called a hearing at Albany for today to consider problems of the industry.
John Haynes Holmes, pastor of the Community Church, characterized the Oxford Group Movement yesterday as "revivalism for the rich and respectable."

The Rev. Dr. Sidney E. Goldstein, as the representative of the Central Conference of American Rabbis, pledged the cooperation yesterday of Jewish groups with the Catholic and Protestant campaign for improved motion pictures.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 15. -- A strike of textile workers in Alabama was called today at a meeting of representatives from forty out of forty-two local unions in the area. The strike order will effect 18,000 of Alabama's 35,000 operatives.

RAPID CITY, S.D., July 15. -- A change for the worse in the weather destroyed any possibility of a take-off tomorrow for the stratosphere balloon, Major William E. Kepner, who, with Captain Albert W. Stevens, will make the flight, said today.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman paid a "neighborly visit" yesterday to the grief-stricken home of Charles H. Conner in Hartsdale Manor, Vestchester County, to offer all the resources of the State in the search for 21-month-old Bobby Connor, who disappeared mysteriously on Thursday evening.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 15. -- Major Gen. and Mrs. Dennis Nolan of Governors Island and Police Commissioner John F. O'Ryan of New York were among the weekend guests of Brig. Gen. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt at Bealieu, and left with them for New York on the Winchester late today.

BOSTON, July 15 (AP) -- One-hit pitching by Waite Hoyt of the Pirates followed by Ed Brandt's three-hit hurling gave Pittsburgh and Boston an even break in today's double-header. The Pirates took the first game, 5 to 0, and the Braves the second, 4 to 0.

PARIS, July 14. -- The monthly index of commodity prices in France, compiled by the Statistique Generale, shows for the end of June an average of 363, compared with 372 in May and 396 in June, 1933. The index is based on the average for July, 1914, as 100.

CAMP DIX, N.J., July 15. -- After Rabbi Julius Silberfeldt of Newark delivered an address today at the Jewish religious service of the Citizens Military Training Corps, during which he attacked Chancellor Hitler of Germany as "an unscrupulous adventurer," officers at the camp refused to permit the story to be sent out to newspapers.

CHICAGO, July 15. -- Speculative interests are giving more attention to commodity markets in the belief that inflation is gradually developing confidence and a stronger undertone and that the reduced crops of grain in this country and Europe will bring a better class of buyers into the market, and they see better prospects for big profits through advanced prices.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 15. -- Mayors of the bay region cities faced with labor's threat of social paralysis met in hurried conference at the San Francisco City Hall today to devise plans for maintaining complete control of the area in the hands of the duly constituted authorities.

LOS ANGELES, July 15 (AP). -- June Delong, whose attempted suicide yesterday failed when she mistook sleep-inducing pills for poison, will resume the witness stand in the "Hollywood morals trial" case tomorrow if her physical condition permits, Prosecutor Arthur Veitch said today.

ON BOARD THE U.S.S. NEW ORLEANS, Accompanying President Roosevelt, July 15. -- Completely relaxed and anticipating another fishing expedition, President Roosevelt sailed almost due west today on the cruiser Houston, which is taking him to his vacation in Hawaii.

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- The rapid growth of independent commissions and executive agencies which exercise, in some instances, judicial and legislative powers, and many of which have been created during the Roosevelt administration, is seriously undermining the judicial branch of the Federal Government, according to a report by the special committee on administrative law of the American Bar Association which will be presented to the association's annual meeting at Milwaukee on Aug. 29.

BERLIN, July 15. -- Harder to handle than a mere storm trooper's revolt is the problem of how the Third Reich's population will pay for food and clothing in the coming Winter. Official warning after warning has of late been launched against price raising, ordinance after ordinance has regulated the methods of distribution, but the question remains unsolved and cannot be solved by the most summary blood bath.

The other day a letter from J.W. Hamilton headed "England's Napoleonic War Debt," published in THE NEW YORK TIMES, gave me a shock. It either said too much or too little, and while in part correct, was sadly misleading.

CHICAGO, July 15. -- There were scattered rains over virtually all corn-producing sections last week, but temperatures in parts of Iowa, Kansas and Nebraska were unusually high. Nebraska reporting 100 to 108 degrees, which is detrimental to good corn growth.
LONDON, July 15 (AP). -- Another woman's body was found today in a trunk at Brighton, the second since June 18, when the body of a woman crammed in a trunk was discovered in a railway station.

PARIS, July 15. -- The French Socialists' National Council, in accepting tonight a proposal submitted by the Communists for united action "in the struggle against fascism and in defense of laboring and democratic liberties," took a step that is likely to have an important effect upon future internal politics in France.

PARIS, July 14. -- The announcement of the new French Treasury loan occasioned no surprise here. It was a familiar fact that the power of the government to issue treasury bonds must automatically decrease by 2,000,000,000 francs in September, and it is therefore natural that, in order to preserve and slightly to increase the treasury's elasticity, the Minister of Finance should have thought it well to procure 3,000,000,000 francs of fresh money.
Seventy Tammany district leaders and co-leaders will meet at Tammany Hall at 2 P.M. today to elect a leader to succeed John F. Curry, deposed three months ago.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., July 15. -- A crowd of more than 3,000 persons lined the shore at dusk today to watch a parachute jumper who had been carried half a mile to sea by an off-shore wind brought ashore in a small boat. The parachute jumper was Arthur Sousa, 24 years old, of Hackensack.
ISTANBUL, July 15. -- The Turkish Government announced today that it would punish all concerned in the persecution of Turkish Jews and their expulsion from the Dardanelles area and Eastern Thrace.

POINT PLEASANT, N.J., July 15. -- H. Craig Severance, architect who designed many of New York's skyscrapers, and three companions were rescued from the Atlantic today after the motor of his thirty-three-foot cabin cruiser, the Alfreda III, had exploded two miles off shore, setting fire to the boat.

Completion of the State's program for the care of transient needy and unemployed through setting up a network of bureaus of various types was announced yesterday by Homer W. Borst, head of the transient division of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration.

A saving of $2,000,000 a year by establishing special rehabilitation schools to re-educate maladjusted high school students is proposed by Dr. John L. Tildsley, acting head of the high school division, in his annual report released for publication today.

Steps to seek dismissal of the equity receivership of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, now pending in the Federal courts, are being considered by the Manhattan Railway Company, it was intimated yesterday. They will be based, it was said, upon the testimony recently given by James L. Quackenbush, general counsel for the Interborough, before the United States Senate subcommittee that has been investigating Federal receivership methods throughout the country.

ON BOARD THE U.S.S. NEW ORLEANS, accompanying President Roosevelt, July 16 (AP). -- The U.S.S. Houston drove straight course today toward Clipperton Island in an effort to give to President Roosevelt a glimpse of the interesting coral atoll.
Editorial comment published by newspapers of the Pacific Coast region on the general strike in San Francisco and similar threats elsewhere was as follows:

BOSTON, July 16. -- Judge John J. Burns of the Superior Court was appointed to the Superior Court bench by Governor Ely on April 29, 1931. Judge Burns, then a professor at Harvard, was the youngest man ever to attain the Superior bench here.

Perched precariously on the branches of trees, squatting cross-legged on the grass and standing on chairs borrowed for the night from their kitchens, more than 3,500 men, women and children witnessed last night the inauguration of the portable theatre in the Bronx.

LONDON, July 16. -- T.O.M. Sopwith, owner and helmsman of the America's Cup challenger Endeavour, announced tonight that his crew once more was complete. Vacancies were created yesterday when fourteen professional members struck for higher pay and quit.
ST. LOUIS, July 16 (AP). -- Buck Newsom won the decision in a pitcher's battle today with Merritt (Sugar) Cain, the Browns defeating the Athletics, 3 to 2.

The police rifle regiment, organized about six years ago and used principally at parades and exhibitions, is being reorganized as an authentic military unit, it was learned yesterday. The reorganization was ordered by Police Commissioner O'Ryan.

At this time, when, in spite of the administration's promise that Section 7-A of the Recovery Act would stabilize industry, we have the menace of a terrible industrial conflict on the Pacific Coast, it may be well to pause, and, as the French put it, furiously to think on the happenings that will come as consequences of its bizarre experiments with money.
i U.B. Depariment of Agriculture. I leat trade conditions and Wholesale prices at llew'l[ork.

ALBANY, July 16. -- Cutting through red tape and non-essentials with characteristic directness, former Governor Alfred E. Smith, at the public hearing here this afternoon on county reform measures affecting New York City and up-State counties, blazed a trail for harmonious action.

Longford barely outlasted Scotch Gold in a long stretch drive to win the featured Old Hickory Purse at Empire City yesterday. Mrs. Clyde Phillips's racer scored by a nose, while the Howe Stable gelding had a four-length advantage over the show horse, George Schimmel's Aileen C.

NEWPORT, R.I. July 16. -- Rails down in a white-capped, olive-colored sea, the four America's Cup yachts engaging in the international defense trials made fast time today on a wind-thrash to Block Island and back of thirty miles. Rainbow and Yankee were the winners.

GREAT NECK, L.I., July 16. -- Dr. Charles Robinson and Willie Klein, representing the Wheatley Hills Club, walked away with the honors in the annual Long Island amateur-pro championship played at the Lakeville Club today as a prelude to the open event starting tomorrow.

Crime control, whether by prevention or arrest, is by no means the only function of the twentieth-century metropolitan police commissioner. Traffic control has been added to his duties, and has become one of his chief responsibilities. What with skyscrapers, tourist buses, cruising taxicabs, heedless motorists and careless pedestrians it is by no means an easy task to keep the streets safe and the traffic moving.

LONDON, July 16. -- Major Walter E. Elliot, Minister of Agriculture, issued tonight what was virtually a threat to impose drastic quotas on beef imports unless the Dominions land Argentina agree to the scheme for voluntary restriction which the British Government has already suggested to them.

BERLIN, July 16. -- While the three pacts submitted to Germany as the foundation of a new policy of mutual assistance in Europe are still officially in a state of study, the voices for rejection are multiplying and more and more are assuming an official tone.

NEWARK, N.J., July 16. -- The hearing on an application to vacate a Chancery Court order restraining members of the Furniture Workers Industrial Union from picketing the plant of the Miller Parlor Furniture Company, Inc., of 261. Orient Avenue, Jersey City, was continued today by Federal Judge John Boyd Avis to next Monday.
HOUSTON, Texas, July 16. -- The county grand jury today began an investigation of the shooting yesterday in which three Negro independent longshoremen were killed.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Final preparations for a strike of 18,000 knit goods workers were made last night by a strike committee of sixty-five at the office of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union, 3 West Sixteenth Street, the parent body of the Knit Goods Workers Union.

DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., July 16. -- Before a first-night audience which included many persons prominent in the theatre, Ethel Barrymore appeared at the Little Washington Theatre here this evening, with the Mayfair Players, playing the title role in the tryout of the new comedy drama "Laura Garnett" by Leslie and Sewell Stokes.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 16. -- San Francisco labor is prepared to make sacrifices to preserve high standards of working men, Edward D. Vandeleur, chairman of the general strike executive committee, declared today.

Fritz, Heinrich, August, Emil and Wilhelm, who comprise a five-piece German band of more or less excellence, felt yesterday forenoon that they never had run across such luck in their lives as when a tall, dark-mustached stranger, with a demoniacal leer, came up to them at Park Row and New Chambers Street and gave them $1.50.

A plan of reorganization has been arranged for the United Public Service Company and the United Public Utilities Company in connection with petitions filed in the Federal Court in Chicago recently to reorganize under the National Bankruptcy Act.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 16. -- Nineteen restaurants!
The Prudence Company, Inc., is liable for its guaranteed bonds despite the national and State moratoria, the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn ruled yesterday.

Apparel Orders Continue Heavy. Those buyers who had been shopping the various apparel markets last week sent in good-sized orders yesterday on Fall merchandise, mostly in dresses. Coats and suits were bought for next month's promotional sales, while the accessory lines came in for more attention.
The money market was dull and featureless at the opening of new business in the new week. Turnover was light and quotations for all classifications were carried forward without change.

Speculative selling of the dollar abroad, on the news of the general strike in San Francisco, caused yesterday a sharp advance in the principal foreign exchanges here. Francs rose 1 point to 6.60 7/3 cents, a movement which was equivalent to a fall of .2 cent in the dollar to 100.3 per cent of parity.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 16. -- This Midwest city, which tonight retired to the rumbling of trucks making last-minute deliveries, will awake tomorrow morning with all streets and highways picketed by striking truck drivers.

OGUNQUIT, Me., July 16. -- Maude Adams, who is still and always one of the theatre's younger actresses, made two debuts here this evening. She appeared for the first time in a part she had always wished to play, that of Maria in Shakespeare's "Twelfth Night."

Reports from Washington that Federal authorities were determined that San Francisco's general strike should not interfere with interstate commerce recalled the drastic action taken by President Grover Cleveland in the great Pullman strike of 1894.

A committee of the American Bar Association has prepared a report, for submission at its convention next month, on the effect of the great mass of new statutes and administrative orders since March 4, 1933. Extracts from it have been published. No question is made of the sincerity or high public motives of the legislators and administrators who have flung this great network of legal regulation over the entire country.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 16. -- Following is the text of Acting Governor Frank Merriam's radio address on the San Francisco strike situation, delivered from his office in the State Capitol tonight:

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- The establishment of the National Power Policy Commission, which will organize Wednesday, has as one of its purposes the creation of sentiment for the ratification of the St. Lawrence Waterway treaty by the next Senate, according to advisers of the President.

Jose Iturbi said au revoir to the Lewisohn Stadium concerts last night. It was a farewell that took on the proportions of an event. The largest audience of the season was present, virtually filling the concrete seats and a generous section of the field chairs.

CHICAGO, July 16 (AP). -- Home runs by Al Simmons and Zeke Bonura failed to make up a four-run first-inning deficit, and the White Sox were defeated by Boston in the first game of today's double-header, 5 to 4. Simmons, however, came back with another circuit drive to help the Chicagoans to a 4-to-2 victory in the second game.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 16. -- The new Brazilian Constitution was promulgated today after its final adoption by the Constituent Assembly and the dictatorship of Provisional President Getulio Vargas came to an end.

Novelty merchandise was highlighted at the Fall shorting of lamps which opened at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday. Prices for the new season were unchanged from Spring, but the proportion of higher price merchandise in each line was much greater than at the last show.
OAKLAND, July 16 (AP). -- Ten men and two women were arrested by Oakland police today following a battle in which two Communists were knocked unconscious and two policemen injured.

BERLIN, July 16. -- Despite the continuing dearth of public orders the stock market on the whole was steady to moderately upward today. The most notable exception was steels. The best advances were scored by potashes, public utilities and machineries.

A long period of internal quarrels and personal vindictiveness in Tammany Hall has ended with the choice of a new leader. Of Mr. DOOLING, it is to be said that he is a man of education, and has visible means of support outside of politics. He may sincerely believe that Tammany can be reformed from within.

The memorial over the Athenian dead at the battle of Chalcis bears the inscription: "For we lost lovely youth facing the rough cloud of war." It is the better fortune of some of those who lost their lives facing the rough cloud of the World War that their memorials are places of happiness and health.

Emergence of a conservative, optimistic type of college student as opposed to the iconoclastic brooder and gin-drinker believed by many to personify the post-war era in American higher education, was pointed to yesterday by Henry Goddard Leach, editor of The Forum, in announcing winners of the magazine's national intercollegiate poetry contest.

FRANKFURT-AM-MAIN, July 16. -- The banking Rouse of Lazard Speyer-Ellissen of this city, parent house to Speyer Co. of New York, will be liquidated Oct. 1. Notice to this effect issued by the firm says that impaired health prevents its head.

LONDON, July 16. -- Sir John Simon, British Foreign Secretary, gave a farewell dinner tonight to the retiring Polish Ambassador, Konstanty Skirmunt, but the guest of honor probably did not tell his host what he thought of the proposed "Eastern Locarno" pact which Sir John approved so war mly Friday in the House of Commons.

Bond prices were generally lower yesterday on the Stock Exchange in quiet trading. It was the first time in more than a week that all classifications of domestic corporation bonds weakened simultaneously. Losses for the domestic issues ranged from small fractions to 4 points.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 16. -- Mayor Rossi today issued the following proclamation to the citizens of San Francisco:

The members of the executive committee of Tammany, many of them veterans in politics, assembled yesterday afternoon at Tammany Hall and unanimously elected James J. Dooling, 41-year-old leader of the Fifth Assembly District, as leader of the organization.

Prices were mixed or weak in the commodity futures markets yesterday, accompanying the easier tendencies in the grain and securities markets. In the cash markets wheat, rye, oats, lard and rubber declined, while corn, flour, cocoa and cotton advanced.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 16. -- Public opinion now has become a vital factor in strike conditions in this city, but the main task of fighting strike conditions has been borne by the Industrial Association.

LONDON, July 16. -- Captain R. Norris (Dick) Williams today passed over Wilmer Allison, called to England in a frantic last-minute SOS, and named his four original team members, Frank Shields, Sidney B. Wood Jr., Lester Stoefen and George M. Lott Jr., to start the interzone Davis Cup series against Australia at Wimbledon Saturday.

The President's recent holidays have been clouded by labor troubles. During his first year in office the slight relaxation he was able to take was not thus complicated because, in that time, labor with capital was anxiously concentrated on whether there would ever again be wages and working conditions to strike about.

President John A. Heydler of the National League yesterday upheld a protest of the Cardinals on the disputed "infield fly" ruling of Umpire Bill Klem during the Cardinals' game with the Cubs at Chicago July 2 and ordered the game replayed from the point where the ruling was made.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reported yesterday for the first half of 1934 a net income of $61,999,195, equal to $3.32 a share earned on 18,662,275 shares of stock, comparing with $66,224,134, or $3.55 a share, earned in the same period in 1933.

Five of America's feminine tennis stars returned from abroad yesterday. Disembarking from the United States liner Leviathan in the morning were a trio of the successful Wightman Cup team, the Misses Sarah Palfrey, Carolin Babcock and Josephine Cruickshank, and Mrs. Dorothy B. Andrus of Stamford, Conn., who had played in the French and English tournaments.

Charles Mattman, ranked eighth, was the only seeded player eliminated as competition in the junior division of the Eastern championship tennis tournament got under way at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills yesterday. In the boys section all eight of the favored stars survived.
Major developments in the San Francisco and other strike situations yesterday included:

RAPID CITY, S.D., July 16. -- A mass of unfavorable weather piling up in the Northwest destroyed any hope that the balloon flight into the stratosphere could take place for the next three days at least, it was announced at the flight headquarters in Spring Creek Canyon today.
This is the story of Albert Bamber and a tuna.

Members of the Board of Aldermen received an unpleasant surprise yesterday when they found their July 16 pay checks reduced by 5 per cent in conformity with the payless furlough provisions of the Economy Bill.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- In a strongly worded new communication the United States Government has demanded that the German Government give American holders of German bonds the same treatment accorded to bondholders in Great Britain or other countries, and has refused to permit this treatment to be made contingent upon "trade concessions, clearing arrangements or similar measures."

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- Appointment of Judge John J. Burns of the Massachusetts Superior Court as general counsel for the new Securities and Exchange Commission was announced today by the chairman, Joseph P. Kennedy.

The lighting effect on Central Avenue north of 233d Street in the Bronx, which motorists and others have observed since last Thursday night, represents an experiment in street illumination by the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, it was made known yesterday at the office of Commissioner Maurice P. Davidson.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., July 16. -- Hurled from their light sedan when it was in collision with a seven-ton truck this morning one person was killed and five were seriously hurt. Their automobile overturned several times and burst into flames.

A unicameral City Council, election by proportional representation, and a Mayor exercising only executive duties were recommended by speakers at the final public hearing yesterday of the subcommittee on city legislature of the New York City Charter Revision Commission.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 16. -- Harry R. Bridges, leader of the joint marine strike committee and the man to whom principal responsibility for the general strike is credited, has been a figure of mystery among even his own followers here.

The Seventeenth Assembly District Republican Club endorsed the candidacy of Joseph Clark Baldwin 3d for State Senator in the Seventeenth Senatorial District, at a meeting last night at 71 Lenox Avenue. Mr. Baldwin recently resigned as minority leader in the Board of Aldermen and now has the Republican endorsement of two of the three assembly districts in his district.

Newspaper columnists should be interested in the report that a French archaeologist in Asia Minor has discovered not far from Antioch the pillar on which SIMEON or SIMON STYLITES lived for more than a generation.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 16. -- The first day of San Francisco's general strike, which went into effect at 8 o'clock this morning, saw a modification by strike leaders of the transit tie-up, and, to some extent, of the food blockade. There were no mass disorders or looting, and although numerous cases of violence were reported they were sporadic and of a minor nature.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 16. -- George Lauder's Windward turned the tables today on her rival Class M yacht, William J. Strawbridge's Istalena, as the second regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club's race week broke all records for weekday competition.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 16. -- William H. Vanderbilt is giving the Good Hands Cup for the best saddle horse or pony to be ridden by a child under 17 years old at the ninth annual Lenox Horse Show at the Hanna farm on July 27 and 28. The George Gilder Memorial Trophy is to be awarded in the handy hunter class.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- The government rushed additional mediators to the West Coast today to work for settlement of the general strike in San Francisco and to avert another strike threatening the Portland area.

The political cartoon in the July 15 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES pictured the Republican party as being torn apart by sectional interests. As a member of the Republican party I would like to say that whatever diversity of opinion exists is a sign not of weakness but of strength and that it will prove less perplexing to the Republican party than to the Democratic high command.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- Greater flexibility of codes was made possible today by the NRA when it put into effect a new "general policy" under which changes will be made in codes whenever such changes appear necessary or desirable.

Three men of a group of 23, charged with obtaining unemployment relief on fraudulent pretenses, were before Magistrate Aurelio in Jefferson Market Court yesterday. The hearings marked the first step in the city's campaign to clean the relief rolls of fraudulent clients.

BERLIN, July 16 (London Times Dispatch). -- The shooting of Adalbert Probst, Reich leader of the Deutsche Jugendkraft, one of the principal Roman Catholic youth organizations, has aroused such indignation among Catholics that it is less likely than ever that the concordat agreement will be ratified.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 16. -- The State-wide textile strike was put in motion tonight when 350 employes of the Avondale Mills here walked out four hours before the end of their shift.

A demonstration run of a new five-section high-speed car of stainless steel, built on the principle of the Burlington Railroad's "Zephyr," was held yesterday afternoon by the Brooklyn Manhattan Transit Company. Passengers on the run included B.M.T. officials, steel manufacturers and representatives of the press and trade journals.

A decision by Supreme Court Justice Samuel Rosenman, holding five officers and directors of the defunct Equitable Casualty and Surety Company liable for damages for wasting the company's assets and for other alleged improper acts, was announced yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, July 16 (AP). -- A grand jury investigation of the fatal shooting in her bed of Mrs. Dessie Masterson was ordered today soon after a Coroner's verdict found Lear B. Reed, Department of Justice agent, criminally careless in the death.

SEATTLE, July 16. -- Two more incidents of violence in the longshoremen's strike were reported today as Seattle kept a watchful eye on the developments at San Francisco and Portland. Labor leaders corroborated the view expressed yesterday by civic officials that no general strike was in immediate prospect here.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 16. -- Forces of law aided by citizens' committees were mobilizing through the agricultural area of Central California today in opening corridors to the strike-ridden bay district through which they will move convoys of food trucks tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- Reductions of 8 to 10 per cent in mill prices of all number products commonly used in house construction were announced today by the Lumber and Timber Products Code Authority, after General Johnson had given approval.

CHICAGO, July 16. -- Profit-taking in sales in wheat, as a result of the advance of 10 cents a bushel last week, although offers were well taken for a time in the morning, gradually made itself effective today and resulted in a lower close in all markets.
The realty market was dull yesterday, with unusually few deals in the city and suburbs reported.

The Commonwealth of Massachusetts awarded yesterday a new issue of $3,552,000 of notes dated July 20 and due on Nov. 22, 1934, to a syndicate composed of the Bankers Trust Company of New York, Merchants National Bank of Boston and the Second National Bank of Boston.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., July 16. -- Only two bids, covering two of the so-called PWA bond issues, were received today by San Francisco and both were rejected by the Board of Supervisors, acting on the recommendation of the Finance Committee.

Desk lieutenants in the Police Department last night were busy scurrying around for regulation trousers. Under an order issued earlier in the day by Commissioner O'Ryan and effective last midnight, desk lieutenants are ordered to do one full eight-hour tour on patrol out of the four tours they work.

John F. Curry, the man under whom Tammany gained its most sweeping victory -- the re-election of James J. Walker by a 500,000 plurality in 1929, and under whom it also became a shattered machine, stripped of power, quit politics yesterday.

Mayor LaGuardia gave an autographed American League baseball yesterday to a team of 12-year-old ball players whose ball had been confiscated by a policeman last week in Crotona Park, the Bronx. Saul Norflus of 1,456 Wilkins Avenue, the Bronx, wrote to the Mayor and asked how he would feel if some policeman took a brand new baseball away from him.
Helen Broderick, who was expected to rejoin the cast of "As Thousands Cheer" last night at the Music Box, was unable to do so, owing to continued illness.

SOUTHAMPTON L.I., July 16.-- Chairmen of the committees for the flower show to be held on July 26 and 27 in the auditorium of the parochial school in Hill Street, under the auspices of the Garden Club of Southampton and the Southampton Horticultural Society, met today at Vyne Croft, home of Mrs. Robert Waller.
The hospital at the Bronx Zoo was being prepared yesterday for two new patients. They are sister spectacled bears, and they will arrive this morning on the Grace liner Santa Maria.
James J. Dooling, elected yesterday as leader of Tammany Hall, is the youngest man ever to hold that post. Forty-one years old this month, he appear even younger.

SALEM, N.H., July 16 (AP). -- Blackbirder, a fast stepping son of Bostonian, owned and. trained by A.E Silver, left seven other 2-year-olds behind today as he won his second straight race in accounting for the six-furlong feature at Rockingham Park.

It is not likely that Professor EMMANUEL CARVALLO will be taken very seriously by physicists when he maintains that the theory of relativity must fall because he has found definite proof of an ether. Our own very active Professor DAYTON C. MILLER is perhaps the leader of this school of skeptics, and this because of the assiduity with which he has conducted his observations and the frequency of his publications on the subject.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 16 (AP). -- A great city walked to work today. As the zero hour of the general strike struck, with all forms of transportation except private automobiles abandoned, a pall of fog hung low, moistening the brows of the tens of thousands who hoofed it to office or shop.

Because Wall Street was intensely interested yesterday in the strike situation on the Pacific Coast, it was assumed here that the decline in stocks had its inspiration in the accumulating labor difficulties. The net losses on the Stock Exchange ran from 1 to 3 points or more in the case of stocks which were offered most freely.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 16. -- A stern warning against interference with the distribution of the necessaries of life in San Francisco was given by Acting Governor Frank F. Merriam tonight in a radio address in which he declared that alien radical agitators blocked settlement of the maritime strike.

TOKYO, July 16. -- Japanese naval leaders, meeting this morning under Fleet Admiral Fushimi, formally placed, their stamp of approval on a policy of seeking recognition for the principle of "autonomy in national defense" and freedom "from disadvantageous treaties" in 1935.

The eccentric, white-haired peddler of cosmetics who frightened Hartsdale Manor housewives last week by his grandiose and rambling talk was detained yesterday for questioning in the mysterious disappearance of 21-month-old Robert Connor.

HOMESTEAD, Fla., July 16 (AP) -- Mrs. J.B. Owens, about 60, wife of a retired New York tile manufacturer, was in a serious condition today from burns received when gasoline, spilled from a bottle, ignited when she attempted to start a truck.

DANIELSON, Conn.; July 16 (2P). -- Their demands for a 25 per cent wage increase refused, 500 workers at the Dayville plant of the Assawaga Woolen Company went on strike today. They also asked for the discharge of the boss weaver. At noon the company ordered its plant closed and 'strikers immediately began orderly picketing. No specific charges were lodged by the workers against the boss weaver, the: committee merely 'expressing general dissatisfaction with him.

MIAMI, Fla., July 16. -- A story of how former President Gerardo Machado of Cuba fled from this country to the Dominican Republic under the alias of Cohen to escape arrest and extradition to Havana was related to The Associated Press tonight by Captain A.M. Scott of the eighty-foot auxiliary schooner Boreas.

In its early stages the depression was accompanied and partly caused by a collapse of world commodity prices. Economists then thought that employment and business activity could be restored only by reductions in production costs. But counsels regarding price policy soon fell into confusion.

TRENTON, July 16. -- Dr. Guy Wendell Burns, 60 years old, of 157 West Fifty-seventh Street, New York, was held today without bail by Police Judge Duch here on a technical manslaughter charge after two persons had died of injuries suffered when struck by a hit-and-run automobilist.

MOSCOW, July 16. -- Without a flourish of trumpets there occurred last week, from .July 10 to 12 an event of great potential significance -- the celebration of the tenth anniversary of the independence of the Mongolian Republic at Outer Mongolia's capital, now called Ulanbator, formerly Urga.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July l6. -- Mr. and Mrs. John D. Rockefeller Jr., who spent the week-end at the Mountain View in Whitefield. drove today to Peckett's on Sugar Hill to visit Mrs. Winthrop W. Aldrich of New York. Mrs. Aldrich brought her young son, Alexander, with his governess, to spend the entire season at Peckett's.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 16. -- A parade of floats, championship tennis tournament and coronation of Queen Thalia I marked the first day of the midsummer festival here. At the last event, a colorful fete held in the evening in the convention hall, Miss Ruth Stephens, 24 years old, a teacher in the Asbury Park High School, was crowned queen of the first annual midsummer festival.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 16. -- Passengers arriving by airplane at Mills Field at 5:15 o'clock this morning received a striking impression of the effectiveness of the transportation tie-up. Although it was still nearly three hours before the time for the general strike to begin, there was no means of public transportation to the heart of the city, ten miles away.

Federal, State and city officials concerned with the administration of work relief will confer today with Mayor LaGuardia, Borough Presidents, Park Commissioner Moses and other department heads. An effort will be made to fix the allocation of $5,000,000 recently voted by the Board of Estimate for purchase of materials for August, September and October.

State banks and trust companies in this Federal Reserve district have been advised of rulings by the Federal Reserve Board that publication by such institutions of the reports of their affiliates, as required under the Banking Act of 1933, need be made only if the respective State supervisory authorities of the banks call for publication of the bank's own statements.

Max Baer will not defend his recently acquired world's heavyweight championship this year, This was learned yesterday when James J. Johnston, boxing director of the Madison Square Garden Corporation, revealed the contents of a telegram sent by Baer's manager, Ancil Hoffman, from Boston, where the Californian is fulfilling stage contracts.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- Extension from Aug. 1 to Sept. 1 of the maturity date on about $115,000,000 of outstanding corn loans made by the Commodity Credit Corporation was announced today by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 16. -- The first tennis tournament of the season, a women's doubles, will be played on the courts of the Newport Casino tomorrow. The following pairs have entered:

Federal Judge Julian W. Mack, at a hearing yesterday on the question of bringing the city and the Transit Commission into the proceedings as formal parties, rejected an attempt, based on charges of collusion, to end the equity receivership of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- Plans for evacuation of the American marines from Haiti contemplate use of the naval supply ship Bridge, the flagship Argonne of the Fleet Base Forces and the army transport Chateau-Thierry, Secretary Swanson said today.

PARIS, July 16. -- Raymond Prince, son of Magistrate Albert Prince, the unsolved murder of whom has contributed one of the major factors in France's present political unrest, visited Premier Doumergue this afternoon to express on behalf of his mother and himself their bitter disappointment at the way in which the judicial inquiry into his father's death is being handled.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- The advantages that. American agriculture might gain through the commercial treaty with Cuba now under negotiation were discussed at a conference today between Secretary Wallace and Sumner Welles, Assistant Secretary of State.

PORTLAND, Ore., July 16. -- An effort to use the influence of the national administration toward preventing at the eleventh hour a general strike here is seen in the announcement that United States Senator Wagner is flying here tonight from New York.

Karl M. Chworowsky's letter in THE TIMES on Sunday concerning movie censorship was extremely interesting, but there are certain factors involved in the drive for decent films which he does not seem to take into account.
Mayor LaGuardia gave assurance yesterday that there was no danger of any shortage of canned staple foods as a result of the San Francisco strike.

CHICAGO, July 16. -- Police today announced the recovery of jewels valued at $65,200 stolen June 14 from the Blackstone Hotel suite of Mrs. Adolph Zukor, wife of the president of the Paramount-Publix Film Corporation, and the arrest of four women and two men in connection with the case.

Committees appointed by the Association of Railway Executives to act on their proposal for a general rate increase and their opposition to the railway pension law are to meet this week. It is estimated the law would double the present total of about $30,000,000 which the railroads spend on pensions.

LOS ANGELES, July 16. -- The strike situation at Los Angeles Harbor, the only open port on the Pacific Coast today, had settled down largely to a watchful waiting game, with sporadic assaults by small gangs purporting to be striking longshoremen.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 16. -- Practically the entire National Guard of California was under arms tonight as unit after unit was rushed from all over the State to San Francisco's strike area to augment the 2,000 guardsmen who have held the State-owned waterfront in a warlike grip since July 5.

" Merchants of Death," the story of the armament racket by H.C. Engelbrecht and F.C. Hanighen, has been brought out in England, France, Holland and Sweden, and arrangements are under way for a Spanish edition, Dodd, Mead reports.

Six New York business men made their first air commutation trips yesterday between Oyster Bay, L.I., and the foot of Wall Street in the East River. They flew from their Summer homes to the financial district in nineteen minutes.

Emil Schlesinger, attorney for a group of depositors of the closed Harriman National Bank, announced yesterday that he would oppose the offer of nine clearing house banks to settle with the depositors on the basis of 90 cents on the dollar when the motion in connection with the offer is argued in Federal Court Thursday afternoon.

The Home Owners Loan Corporation approved 1,752 mortgage loans totaling $8,760,000 in the week ended July 13, it was announced yesterday by Vincent Dailey, State manager of the HOLC. To date the total of approved loans is 47,458 for a total of $258,251,875.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University and chairman of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, returned yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen from the annual meeting in Paris of the European committee of the endowment.

WHEN Curzio Malaparte was in Warsaw in 1920, Trotsky's Red Army was advancing through Poland. Things looked so ominous for the Polish Government that Sir Horace Rumbold, the British Minister, told Mgr. Ratti, now Pope Pius XI and then Papal Nuncio in Warsaw, that a revolution must inevitably break out at any moment and that, in consequence, the diplomatic corps should quit the capital immediately.

LONDON, July 16. -- Whatever the Japanese may do to wreck or to save next year's naval conference, they have already, by their studied indifference and inaction, reduced to futility the preliminary bilateral discussions that had been scheduled to be held in London this Summer.
Mrs. Sally Schofield gained the final round of the women's metropolitan public links golf championship by turning back Mrs. Ellen Hogg, 3 and 2, at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

Supreme Court Justice Kenneth O'Brien denied yesterday the application for the appointment of new receivers in the dissolution of the City Company of New York, formerly the National City Company, an affiliate of the National City Bank, and for the removal of George D. Buckley, S.R. Shepherd, George S. Moore, Harry S. Law and Frank F. Maguire, liquidating directors.

Highest temperatures of the season throughout Oklahoma, with no moisture either in that State or in Texas over Sunday, increased the gravity of a situation already without precedent in forty years and prices on the Cotton Exchange rose yesterday more than $1 a bale.

Mayor LaGuardia asked Governor Lehman yesterday to support State legislation giving the city power to raise new revenues next year to be applied exclusively to meeting the cost of unemployment relief, which now averages $17,750,000 a month.

MOSCOW, July 16. -- The hope that Germany, after, all, will sign the "Eastern Locarno" agreement is growing daily here. Today Pravda expressed the belief that not only Germany hut Poland, Czechoslovakia and the Baltic States would join with Soviet Russia in this pact.
Acting Mayor Arthur Potterton of Jersey City announced yesterday afternoon that complete harmony exists between city officials and labor unions.
BERLIN, July 16. -- The critical condition of Germany's national economy and the German mark was revealed anew today by the publication of the foreign-trade balance for June.

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 16 (AP). -- Johnny Revolta of Milwaukee today became, the fifth St. Paul open golf champion, defeating Ky Laffoon of Denver and Harry Cooper of Chicago in a thirty-six-hole play-off. They had finished the regulation seventy-two holes yesterday with cards of 283.

ALBANY, July 16. -- Denying a motion for a reargument of the case of Mrs. Anna Antonio, 28-year-old mother of three small children, and Sam Faracci and Vincent Saetta, now in the death house at Sing Sing, with their execution slated for the week of Aug. 6 for the killing of the woman's husband, Salvatore Antonio, the Court of Appeals today laid down a new rule for future guidance in such cases.

During the lull in the local firing there is chance to look over the reports from foreign parts. The ex-president of the defunct Bombay, Baseball League, Mr. Walter B. Schleiter, has moved over to Calcutta and sends word that there isn't much going on in that area now except soccer, of which he remarks:

BERLIN, July 16. -- While the German attitude toward the United States is that interest payments to American holders of Dawes and Young bonds are impossible unless new means of payment are provided, it was announced here today that the German-French negotiations for a new trade treaty were progressing favorably and that an agreement in principle had already been reached on all essential questions, including service of the Dawes and the Young loans.
A sharp conflict in interpretation of the city's new excise or business tax exists between the Controller and Wall Street, it became known yesterday.
LONDON, July 16. -- Another effort will be made next month to keep alive the world wheat agreement; which has been jeopardized in recent weeks by Argentina's refusal to limit her exports.

The very large "blimp" felt beret, measuring 17 or 18 inches across, is considered the outstanding success of the early season, according to the consensus at the official Fall millinery opening of the Millinery Quality Guild yesterday. Many buyers were reported in the market here to view the collection of higher priced makes.

Praise for the present regime in the Dominican Republic was voiced yesterday by Louis M. Vidal of 227 Fulton Street, who has been traveling in Latin America for twenty years as a representative of the Krajewski-Pesant steel manufacturing firm.

The Interfaith Committee of Catholics, Jews and Protestants which undertook last week to unify the church campaigns against morally offensive motion pictures, will meet again at 1:30 P.M. today in the rectory of the Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church.

As the temporary agreements to purchase copper from the members of the Code Authority will expire on Aug. 1, H.O. King, managing director of the Authority, said yesterday that efforts were being made to get consumers to sign permanent agreements.

Colonel Fitzhugh Green, author and explorer, and Mrs. Green; Daniel F. Cohalan, former Supreme Court Justice; Willis H. Booth and Mrs. Booth are among those sailing tonight for the Channel ports on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen. Others on board are:

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 16. -- The reserve officers of the 369th Reserve Regiment, who have been serving at the Citizens Military Training Camp under the supervision of Colonel W.B. Wallace, started to pack tonight to leave for their homes in Albany and Troy as veterans of the 292d Infantry, from Erie County, came in to take their places.

DOUGLAS, Isle of Man, July 16. -- Kaye Don heard himself sentenced to four months in prison today in the picturesque old Deemster's Court here. He had been found guilty Saturday of manslaughter in the death of Francis Taylor, his mechanic, who succumbed to injuries following a night trial of a racing automobile last May.
MANCHESTER, Mass., July 16 (AP). -- Lacking its usual high class field, the tenth Essex County Club's women's invitation tennis tournament got under way today.

Two decisions in suits brought against twelve individuals and firms accused of violating the code of fair competition for the cast pipe trade were handed down yesterday in the Federal court in Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, July 16. -- Prices for hogs here today were steady to 25 cents a hundred pounds lower than on Saturday, with a top of $5 and an average of $4.60. Most sales were at $4.20 to $4.95, indicating an increase of about 5 cents. Hogs averaging 195 to 255 pounds brought $3.80 to $5, those averaging 255 to 400 pounds $3.75 to $5, those averaging 185 to 195 pounds $3 to $4.95.

With stocks displaying what the brokers speak of as "softness," there was little in yesterday's market to indicate any change in the general speculative attitude. If anything, the market was bearish, or at least pessimistic in its inferences.

DETROIT, July 16 (AP). -- Turning what had started out to he a pitching duel into a free-hitting contest, the Senators snapped their losing streak at three games today as they defeated the Tigers, 10 to 8.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 16. -- In a letter to Governor Merriam today, asking for additional troops, Mayor Rossi said:

ALBANY, N.J., July 16. -- The election of James J. Dooling as the new leader of Tammany Hall was received quietly at the Capitol by the New York City political leaders and legislators here for the special session.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-one leading cities on July 11 shows increases for the week of $90,000,000 in net demand deposits, $17,000,000 in time deposits, $132,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and $22,000,000 in investments, and a decrease of $32,000,000 in loans.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-one leading cities on July 11 shows increases for the week of $90,000,000 in net demand deposits, $17,000,000 in time deposits, $132,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and $22,000,000 in investments, and a decrease of $32,000,000 in loans.

The four-day fiesta in the Italian district of East Harlem in celebration of Our Lady of Mount Carmel closed last night. Nearly 200,000 Italians, residents of the quarter and out-of-town visitors, thronged the neighborhood of First Avenue from Jefferson Park to 125th Street.

The general strike on the Pacific Coast served yesterday to accentuate the demands of certain labor organizations at the port of New York which have submitted proposals for improved working conditions at intervals in the last year.
THE TIMES printed this morning the conversation of three "old-time" barkeeps. It may have interested a lot of people, but it irritated me.

BERLIN, July 16. -- An open fight by Gottingen University students against Nazi rule was a fresh contribution today to the general discontent in Germany. In the revolt, the first instance of the kind under the Hitler regime, 1,000 fraternity men battled with brown-shirted Nazi students in defense of their ancient colors.

ALBANY, July 16. -- A dozen representatives of service industries which are no longer covered by national codes urged Governor Lehman today to call upon the special session to set up a State NRA to cover those industries.

CHICAGO, July 16 (AP). -- Breaking on top, Gallant Mac, racing in the colors of B.B. Jones's Audley Farm of Virginia, carried top weight of 115 pounds to victory today in the mile feature at Arlington Park.

RAPID CITY, S.D., July 17. -- The uncertain weather which for more than a week now has prevented the start of the stratosphere exploration is expected to continue for at least another forty-eight hours, Major William E. Kepner said this afternoon.
The translation into English of Professor Albert Einstein's forthcoming book, "The World as I See It," has just been received by Covici, Friede, who will publish the book in September.

About the time of the Spanish-American War a young reporter on THE NEW YORK TIMES used to bring snakes in a satchel to the office. He did not use them for lunch or excite them to bite the editors, but carried them about with him after office hours on his lecture tours around town.
COLOGNE, Germany, July 17 (AP). -- Touring American athletes won four events but lost five others today in a track and field meet with stars from Germany, Hungary and Poland.

BERLIN, July 17. -- Alfons Sack, who was counsel for Ernst Torgler, Communist Parliamentary leader, in the Reichstag fire trial and was mainly instrumental in obtaining his acquittal, was arrested during the Hitler purge. No total of such arrests has been made known officially, but the number has been put down by persons who are in a position to make an estimate as something like 4,000.

LONDON, July 17. -- Thirteen amateurs, all young ocean-going members of the Royal Corinthian Yacht Club and the majority of whom own yachts, were signed today by T.O.M. Sopwith as members of the crew of the Endeavour, British America's Cup challenger, to replace the dismissed striking professionals.

Scratched by brambles, caked with mud, and in a serious condition from hunger, thirst and exposure, 21-month-old Robert Connor was found yesterday afternoon in a thicket three-quarters of a mile from his home in Hartsdale Manor, from which he disappeared last Thursday.

ALBANY, July 17. -- Republican legislators challenged Governor Lehman today to recommend new taxes to the extraordinary session, asserting that otherwise the State would be confronted by a deficit of $105,000,000 at the end of the current fiscal year.
