The dispute between the banks and the city administration over the rejection by the city at its bond sale a week ago of bids submitted by a banking syndicate has been compromised and a new sale will be announced within a day or two, it was indicated yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 17. -- President Roosevelt's order, authorizing Postmaster General Farley to investigate ocean mail and foreign air mail contracts, follows:

LONDON, July 17 (AP). -- Beyond the assertion that he had picked what he considered his strongest team, Captain R. Norris (Dick) Williams of the United States Davis Cup team today had little comment to make on Wilmer Allison's abrupt decision to return home on the Europa tomorrow.
Pierrepont E. Grannis of Grannis, MacMurdy Co. and William Currie of J.K. Rice Jr. Co. were elected yesterday to membership in the New York Security Dealers Association.

SEAGIRT, N.J., July 17. -- Governor Moore, after a conference here today with Charles Edison, chairman of the State Recovery Administration, and Harry Tepper, acting director, said he could find no wide conflict of policy between the State body and the National Recovery Administration and was trying to bring the State organization into line with the demands of General Johnson.

Except for coffee and raw hides, the tone on the commodity futures markets was weak or mixed yesterday. The volume of trading was at its previous low levels and interest was virtually at a standstill. In the cash markets gains appeared in wheat, corn, oats, flour, eggs, quicksilver, printcloths and cotton, while cocoa, zinc and rubber eased.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 17. -- With the sea running white along her rail the sloop Yankee came through today to another victory over the Rainbow in the observation races to select a defender of the America's Cup.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

The dollar volume of business in grains on the Chicago Board of Trade in the last two months has been far larger than the dollar volume of transactions in securities on the New York Stock Exchange, according to a survey by Fenner Beane, members of the Exchange.

The truth, born of long experience, that a great strike cannot be won if it outrages public opinion, has apparently been grasped by the "strategy committee" of the San Francisco strikers. Its early announcements of policy were drastic and pitiless. The city was to be threatened with starvation.

A suit brought by the Trust Company of North America to liquidate the Russian beer barrel enterprise organized by Dr. Armand Hammer resulted yesterday in charges by Dr. Hammer that the trust company had exacted a $50,000 bonus for supplying $100,000 working capital to the barrel company.

Broadway Miscellany: Philip Loeb will direct sketches and dialogue for the Winter Garden revue, "Life Begins at 8:40," to open next month. . . . A.H. Woods denies reports that Vivienne Siegal, the songstress, has been engaged for his Fall production, "The Red Cat."

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 17. -- A festival concert and the operetta "The Rose Maiden," given under the sponsorship of the allied Catholic societies of Asbury Park, were presented in the Convention Hall this evening and featured the second day of the Midsummer Festival.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 17. -- This city was in the grip of its second truck drivers' strike in two months tonight and commercial transportation was virtually at a standstill.

Shortly after Parliament voted that Waterloo Bridge shouldn't be destroyed, the London County Council, which has authority over London bridges under old acts of Parliament, began to destroy it. Lamentations continue to be made over this "vandalism."

Tammany Hall, under the leadership of James J. Dooling, embarked yesterday on a course that it has not sailed in the last eight or ten years, namely, the winning of public support by offering its support to progressive legislation, and the building up of the personnel that it offers to the electorate.

To the rumblings of traffic at First Avenue and the Queensboro Bridge there was added yesterday morning the blare of band music, marking the opening of the four-week observance of the Midtown Municipal Market's eighteenth anniversary.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., July 17. -Owen Madden, who was head of New York's midtown racketeers, left this resort last Saturday, it became known today, to testify before a New York County grand jury investigating a city coal fraud.

Stocks followed an uneven course yesterday, backing and filling uncertainly in trading that was slightly more active than that of the day before. The net result was a fractional loss in the price averages. Bonds were irregular and the major commodities pointed upward.

LONDON, July 17. -- Montagu Norman, governor of the Bank of England, and his wife are sailing aboard the liner Europa from Southampton tomorrow for a short holiday on the coast of Maine, which Mr. Norman visits almost annually.
LONDON, July 17. -- The Court of Appeal today emphatically upheld the recent award of 25,000 damages to Princess Irene Youssoupoff for libel in the film "Rasputin, the Mad Monk."

Mayor LaGuardia welcomed yesterday the annual convention of the American Association of Nurserymen, which opened at the Hotel New Yorker, with the remark that "New York City has planted more trees since Jan. 1 than any other city in the history of the world."

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- Details of the invasion by an insane Japanese of the United States Consulate General in Mukden yesterday were given in a report received by the State Department today from Consul General Myers.

While the Legislature has still to act on ex-Governor SMITH'S canny stratagem in the matter of county reorganization, it looks as if he has shown the leaders a way out of their jealousies and difficulties. Instead of calling for a "plague" o' both their houses, after the manner of Mercutio, he has in effect invoked a benison on them.

A couple of aces were roundly trumped at the Polo Grounds yesterday as the Giants and Cubs resumed their crucial struggle for the National League leadership, while a crowd of 44,000, the largest of the championship campaign here, sat spellbound at the spectacle and left the arena even more mystified.

The New York City Charter Revision Commission, after a long wrangling debate over committee reports favoring retention of borough government and recommending three different forms of city Legislature, was jolted by word from Albany of amendments to its County Reform Bill completely emasculating that measure.

Leader DOOLING paints for an as yet unbelieving city an affecting picture of another New Tammany. Sometimes in the past "bad men" have made their way into the ancient altruistic and philanthropic institution. Its standard of integrity should not be misjudged on account of the failings of a few members false to those lofty conceptions which are rigidly to be adhered to henceforth.

Secretary off Agriculture Wallace has received the recommendations announced several days ago by the Advisory Board Migratory Bird Treaty Act, and concurred in by the Bureau of Biological Survey. Secretary Wallace, after studying the report, will make his recommendations to President Roosevelt.

The Interfaith Committee of Catholics, Jews and Protestants, which undertook on July 9 to unify the church campaigns in this city against morally offensive motion pictures, decided yesterday to extend its activities beyond churchgoers to include non-churchgoers as well.

There has been an unfortunate misinterpretation of the appeal of the 1934 Mobilization for Human Needs, of which Newton D. Baker is chairman. The appeal is not for funds to keep the unemployed from starving. This would be absurd in view of the fact that government sources now supply more than 97 per cent of such relief.

The children's division of Bellevue Hospital will receive most of the estate of Mrs. Anna Phipps Tinker, widow of Dr. Horace H. Tinker, who was in her eighty-seventh year when she died on June 30, it was revealed yesterday when her will was filed for probate in Surrogates' Court.

MANCHESTER, Mass., July 17 (AP). -- The East and mid-West dominated the third-round play in the Essex Country Club's women's invitation tennis tournament today, each section placing three representatives in the quarter finals. The remaining two brackets went to the survivors of the large California delegation.

A few days ago Commoners tried to smoke out the Government's monetary policy. The Chancellor of the Exchequer professed to be satisfied with things as they are. There were 800,000 more employed than in 1932. Exports were up for the first five months of the year by 11 per cent, and retail sales were 7.7 per cent higher.

CHICAGO, July 17. -- Reduced arrivals of hogs here and at all other markets today made prices steady to 5 cents a hundredweight higher in this market, with a top of $5 and an average of $4.65, against $4.60 yesterday. Most sales were at the same as yesterday's prices, $4.20 to $4.95.

The self-styled Prince Childe de Rohan d'Harcourt, former convict, whose lectures in Greenwich Village on the subject of love and the "cosmic ego" were interrupted last month by detectives of the criminal alien squad, waged a fight yesterday for his freedom.

An order requiring Barron G. Collier and twenty-four other directors of the State Title and Mortgage Company to defend a civil action brought in the Supreme Court by George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, to recover more than $5,000,000, based upon alleged acts of waste, nonfeasance and malfeasance in office, was entered yesterday by Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard.

Judge Alfred C. Knox in Federal Court yesterday signed an order outlining procedure preliminary to the reorganization of the United Cigar Stores Company of America under Section 77B of the new Bankruptcy Act. The order makes permanent the appointment of the Irving Trust Company as trustee and names Irwin Kurtz, referee in bankruptcy, as special master to whom reorganization proceedings are to be referred.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP). -- To guard against the gouging of consumers, Secretary Ickes today ordered an inquiry into fuel and heating oil prices and charges that distributing firms were sponsoring monopolistic practices.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 17. -- Of interest to residents and Summer visitors is the third annual horse show to be held in Williamstown tomorrow morning and afternoon. There are twenty-two classes. W. Blanchard Rand and Gordon Cox will be the judges.

PARIS, July 17. -- Nobody in France dreams of seeking a quarrel with any nation or committing an aggression under any pretext whatever, Premier Gaston Doumergue said tonight in a radio address to the entire population. This talk continued the Premier's personal appeals to the people, which have been so successful in establishing confidence in the government's policies.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., July 17. -- Marie Dresaler, ill on the Aontecito, estate of C. I{. G. Billings, i passed a comfortable twenty-four! hours, F. -1. Nuzum, her physician, i reported tonight, Her temperature l remains around .-100 degrees, and! there is no material change in her condition.

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 17. -- Harry R. Bridges, one of the outstanding leaders of the longshoremen's strike in San Francisco, had no career here as an industrial official. He was born in 1901 in a comfortable home in a Melbourne suburb,

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., July 17. -- Melvin Crook, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur Crook of Montclair, N.J., is seen daily trying out his new boat, Betty V, in Lake George in front of the Sagamore. He hopes to capture the Governor Lehman Trophy Race, scheduled in connection with the Gold Cup regatta on Aug. 3, 4 and 5. He has a penguin as a mascot.

The San Francisco strike had little effect on maritime labor in this port yesterday, although leaders contended a start had been made that eventually would link workers on both coasts in a general demand for new contracts and improved working conditions.

ALBANY, July 17 (AP). -- Charles H. Baldwin, agriculture commissioner, charged the New York City administration of Mayor LaGuardia tonight with evading State Milk Control Division orders through the sale of loose milk at city welfare stations to any one instead of relief recipients as specified.

ALBANY, July 17. -- A bill requiring teachers in public and practically all private schools to take an oath to support the State and Federal Constitutions was introduced today by Assemblyman Irving M. Ives, Chenango County Republican.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 17 (AP). -- Rochester made a clean sweep of the three-game series which closed today by beating Newark and its ace pitcher, Walter Brown, by a 4-to-3 count. Tony Kaufmann gave only one earned run to the visitors.
Portden, the Geneseo Stable's good son of The Porter, scored a driving neck victory in the short six furlongs of the featured Kitchawan Purse at Empire City yesterday.

The New York Urban League has equipped its twenty-one-acre plot at Verplanck, N.Y., as a Summer camp for Negro children. This land was originally acquired by the league as a convalescent home for Negro mothers and young children, but due to the expense involved has not until now actually been put to use.

The council of the Actors Equity Association discussed yesterday the plan suggested on Monday at a meeting of the League of New York Theatres whereby the "road" would be revived this coming season with a series of fresh productions. The council reached no decision, however, as to whether permission would be granted for Equity members to play twelve performances a week to make the plan possible.
Small housing properties in various communities were included in the New Jersey turnover reported yesterday.

Senator Weeks of Massachusetts once said, "Government business means government of, for and by politicians. It is a refuge, a charity. It comes high, and yet there are those who love it." He spoke too of the "flat and fatal incompetence of government business." "Those fallacious economies, savings, reductions of expenditures; those profits calculated by never taking cost of plant and upkeep into consideration; those expensive extensions made by politicians for the sake of votes."
HONOLULU, July 17. -- It was indicated here today that President Roosevelt would not cancel his trip to Hawaii to turn back and intervene in the Pacific Coast strike.

With more care than is necessary in bringing in an ocean liner, a bright red, hollow cube of steel was floated up the North River yesterday and warped gently into place at the foot of West Thirty-ninth Street. It was the steel caisson which will serve as the Manhattan base for construction of the Hudson Midtown Tunnel.
ISTANBUL, July 17. -- Seven Turkish soldiers were arrested tonight for having assaulted and robbed Professor Richard C. Borden of New York University and his wife near Istanbul Sunday night.

BERLIN, July 17. -- The stock market, again virtually left to professional trading, was uneven today, but with an upward current somewhat predominating. Fluctuations generally kept within a narrow range. Exceptions were some browncoals, public utilities and specialties.

AMITYVILLE, L.I., July 17. -- The Suffolk County Cancer Committee is sponsoring a joint benefit featurin an appearance of Jules Bledsoe in a Dixie Festival to De given at the South Shore I-Ioliday House, Amityville, on Aug. 8. The Holiday I-touse maintains hundreds of children of needy city families during the Summer months.

SEATTLE, Wash., July 17. -- While cargo continued to be worked by non-union dock labor, in the midst of the longshoreman's strike here, an investigation was under way today into the mysterious sinking of the tugboat Tempest this morning.

HAVANA, July 17. -- The Cuban Government has made no move to demand the extradition of former President Gerardo Machado from the Dominican Republic, where he is said to have taken refuge, according to Dr. Pablof Lavin, prosecuting attorney of the Court of Sanctions.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., July 17. -- Well, for a little fresh air away from Hollywood. Made a little two-hour flight up to Frisco last night. Lovely historic old place, but it seems nothing ever happens there.

Completely recovered from the throat ailment contracted in England, Miss Helen Jacobs walked down the gangplank of the White Star liner Olympic yesterday with one thought uppermost in her mind -- to return to Wimbledon next Summer for another try at the British title.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I. July 17. -- Mrs. John A. Warner gave a dinner and bridge tonight at her home in Toylsome Lane. Among her guests were Mrs. Goodhue Livingston, Mrs. Charles Tracy Barney, Mrs. Phillips B. Thompson, Miss F. Ethel Wickham, Mrs. Albert Gallatin, Mrs. William Robinson Simonds, Mrs. Thomas Bealle Davis, Mrs. Edward Van Ingen, Mrs. George F. Vietor, Mrs. Rufus L. Patterson and Miss Candace C. Stimson.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 17. -- The general strike gripped Oakland and the East Bay cities today. National Guard and police were in full control. In general, San Francisco's situation and control were duplicated.

The police of the Missing Persons Bureau were asked yesterday to find Isadore Tankel, 14-year-old junior high school student, of 405 East Ninety-fourth Street, Brooklyn, who disappeared on Monday. Samuel Tankel, the boy's brother, made the request.

SANTIAGO, Chile, July 17. -- Nitrate interests here attach great importance to the agreement reached in Paris among Chilean nitrate producers and European producers of synthetic nitrogenous fertilizers to form a world cartel to avoid price wars.

The roof playground at Public School 31, Monroe and Gouverneur Streets, will be reopened this afternoon with formal ceremonies. Mayor LaGuardia and other city officials are expected to attend as guests of the Lower East Side Community Council.

PARIS, July 17. -- A grave view is taken in the French press today of the San Francisco strike, which the semi-official Temps in its leading editorial calls "one of the gravest social crises which has ever occurred in the United States." On the Bourse the dollar touched 15.135, the lowest since May 25, and this weakness was ascribed solely to California's labor troubles.

CHICAGO, July 17. -- Strong bullish sentiment on the Board of Trade combined with a wave of buying today carried prices of grains to higher levels and resulted in a greater volume of business, with a more substantial basis, than the trade has had in some time.

LONDON, July 18. -- "The Six of Calais," Bernard Shaw's new one-act play, was performed for the first time tonight at the open-air theatre in Regents Park. Shaw this time humorously names Froissart, who has been dead 500 years, as his collaborator in giving a new version of the heroic burghers of Calais.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 17. -- Three happy children, the two sisters and brother of the missing Robert Connor, clapped their hands and danced with joy tonight when they were told by their grandmother, Mrs. Richard H. Murphy, that their baby brother had been found.

MANILA, July 17. -- A striking parallel between Governor General Murphy's message to the Legislature and Senator Quezon's opening address indicates the possibility of agreement upon the future course of action by the Philippines respecting trade with the United States.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- Ten big army bombing planes will start from Bolling Field Thursday on a four-day, 3.667-mile formation flight to Fairbanks, Alaska, with strong indications that, on their return trip, they will attempt a "continuous" journey, broken probably by only three stops en route for gasoline and oil replenishment.

The bond market on the New York Stock Exchange was somewhat more active yesterday, sales amounting to $11,897,200, against $9,030,000 on Monday. Domestic bonds drifted slightly lower, losing 15 points in THE NEW YORK TIMES combined average of fifty issues.

Sales billed by the General Electric Company for the first half of 1934 amounted in value to $80,983,094, comparing with $61,773,414 in the corresponding period last year, an increase of 31 per cent, Gerard Swope, president, announced yesterday.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 17 (AP). -- A bill of complaint flied by Tessie Berwick of New York against the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation of New York and two other companies was dismissed by the Chancery Court today in so far as it applied to the New York corporation.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- Secretary Ickes will confer tomorrow with Chairman Jones of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation on the possible purchase by the RFC of securities held by the PWA, a move which would make available more money for PWA projects.
KOHLER, Wis., July 17 (AP) -- The ill blast of strike winds swept today through this "ideal village, dedicated to an idyllic industrialism."

Approval of the proposed strike of 18,000 knit goods workers in New York and vicinity, to be conducted by the Knit Goods Workers Union, was given yesterday by the executive board of the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union, the parent organization, at a meeting in the Hotel New Yorker.
RYE, N.Y., July 17. -- The annual Westchester Country Club horse show will be staged on Friday, Saturday and Sunday on the polo field of the clubhouse.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 17. -- Groups of "vigilantes" raided Communist and radical headquarters here today, beating opponents, breaking windows and smashing office equipment. The police, "mopping up" after them, arrested more than 300 persons as Communists.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 17. -- Most of the closed restaurants, lunch rooms, saloons, liquor stores and other small stores affected by the strike bore signs in their windows reading simply "closed," or "closed during strike," or "closed due to strike conditions."
LIVERPOOL, July 17. -- The largest under-water tunnel in the world, beneath the River Mersey, will be opened tomorrow by King George, who will then drive through it with Queen Mary.

Cancer statistics just compiled for 1933 by Dr. Frederick L. Hoffman, consulting statistician, show a sharp increase in mortality over 1932. Dr. Hoffman's report is published in The Spectator, insurance publication. The figures, the report says, also mark a continuation of the steady advance in the cancer mortality rate recorded annually since 1906.

CHICAGO, July 17. -- The Chicago Motor Coach Company, operators of the city bus lines, has openly defied the authority of the National Labor Board, and has flatly refused to accede to the board's demand for reinstatement of fifteen employes discharged several months ago, it was made known today.

Langdon W. Post, Tenement House Commissioner and chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, has submitted to Dwight L. Hoopingarner, newly appointed advisory associate director of the Public Works Administration, surveys of the slum-clearance projects contemplated by the City Housing Authority with the $25,000,000 appropriation authorized by the Public Works Administration.

PORTLAND, Ore., July 17. -- Senator Wagner of New York, arrived here by plane this evening to use his influence at the request of the National Longshoremen's Board, toward averting a general strike. He was greeted by city and State officials and labor leaders.

PHILADELPHIA, July 17 (AP). -- Curt Davis, the Phillies' right-hander, registered his fourth consecutive triumph and his twelfth of the season as he shut out the Reds, 7 to 0, today. Davis also hit a homer.

DETROIT, July 17 (AP). -- Coming through with timely hits and a double play to help Carl Fischer over some tough places, the Tigers defeated Washington, 4 to 3, today and strengthened their hold on first place.

Net income of the International Business Machines Corporation, including foreign subsidiaries, for the six months ended on June 30 amounted to $3,401,176, after interest, reserves, depreciation, estimated Federal taxes and other charges.

Carl Weagant, 26 years old, associate editor of the magazine Yachting, who gained prominence five years ago when he commanded his 46-foot ketch Carlsark on its voyage from Ithaca, N.Y., to Ithaca, Greece, hanged himself last night, according to the police, in his home at 39-27 Main load, Douglaston, Queens.

The elimination of Jack Totten of Paterson, N.J., fifth seeded player, by Stanley Singer, an unranked entrant, of Hollywood, Calif., was the feature of the second day of competition in the Eastern junior singles tennis championship at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills yesterday.

TRENTON, July 17. -- The National Recovery Administration does not recognize the need foe a State administration distinct from a Regional Code Authority, Governor Moore was advised today by General Hugh S. Johnson, Federal NRA administrator.
Chief developments in strike situations in San Francisco and other places yesterday were:

SAN FRANCISCO, July 17. -- Calling upon "responsible labor organization" to "run these subversive influences out from its ranks like rats," General Hugh S. Johnson, administrator of the NRA, declared the San Francisco strike situation was "civil war and a menace to government" and one in which the Federal Government must take action.

BERLIN, July 17. -- The old adage that it is an ill wind that blows nobody good seems to apply to the Jews in Germany in the matter of the recent clean-up. So busy are the Nazis with their own troubles that nobody is taking much notice of the "non-Aryans" and they are being allowed to slip into the background.

By inference Professor Moley in his remarks quoted in your editorial, "AAA vs. NRA," intimates that THE TIMES is among those who "use statistics carelessly," at least in connection with the "parity" index.
BISMARCK, N.D., July 17. -- This city was placed under martial law tonight by order of William Langer a few hours after the State Supreme Court had ordered him ousted as Governor.

SALEM, N.H., July 17. -- Integrity, 5-year-old gelding, which raced successfully over the New York tracks for the B.B. Stable, carried the silks of J.W. Walter Jr. to victory in the one and one-sixteenth miles claiming event featuring the card at Rockingham Park today.
Except for the activity in the commercial paper market there was no other feature in the money market. Business in the Stock Exchange call loans, maturity money and acceptances was small.

Despite the handicap of blindness in both eyes, Alice Adkins Johnson, wife of Professor Douglas Johnson of Columbia University, has recorded her impressions of extensive travels with her husband in both hemispheres.
WASHINGTON, July 17. -- Organization of the new Federal Communications Commission into three divisions, as directed by the new law, was effected today.

The Spanish Peasant Chorus of Galicia gave performances of old sacred music, folk songs and dances, passages from Spanish operettas, sword dances, harvest songs and other species of Galician folklore last night in Town Hall. In addition to music and dance there were the recitations of an admirable comedian, D. Julio Borrajo, better known to the stage by his popular nickname, Xulino, who kept his audience in a state of continuous hilarity during entr'actes.

BERLIN, July 17. -- Reich Bishop Ludwig Mueller waited in vain again today for a summons to make the visit to Chancellor Hitler scheduled for yesterday morning and officially announced last Saturday. The Chancellor was still too occupied with other affairs to see him, it was declared.
DENVER, July l7. -- Two huge grizzly bears, maddened by the heat, attacked and killed their keeper, Charles E. Wyman, as he was cleaning their pen at the city park zoo today.

Norman C. Norman is an individualist who is prepared to fight to maintain what he considers his right to do business in his own way. He does not like President Roosevelt's recovery policies and least of all does he like the NRA. Yesterday he defied the government to force him to help support the Blue Eagle.

CHICAGO, July 17 (AP). -- Making a spectacular stretch finish, Ed Trotter's Isaiah, ridden by Jack Westrope, captured the Midlothian Handicap at Arlington Park today by a head over the Calumet's Some Pomp. C.V. Whitney's Clotho finished third in the six-furlong dash.
WASHINGTON, July 17. -- Complete revision of the government's ocean mail-merchant marine policies within six months is planned by the administration.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 17. -- With resumption of street car service by the Municipal Railway, every normal function of the city government was being carried on "as usual."

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- Government officials were much encouraged tonight at word that the strike committee in San Francisco had voted to advise dockers and marine workers to submit to arbitration and were hopeful that this turn of events would lead to a swift settlement of the West Coast labor troubles.
Steamship officials of companies who are a part of the American merchant marine said yesterday that they would welcome a defined Federal policy on mail contracts.
WASHINGTON, July 17. -- The National Emergency Council is trying to increase Uncle Sam's business as a publisher and salesman of books.
OAKLAND, July 17. -- National Guard trucks carrying machine guns left the Berkeley Armory this afternoon to patrol the commercial and waterfront areas of the East Bay district.

LOS ANGELES, July 17. -- Mrs. Eleanor Wilson McAdoo, daughter of the late President Wilson, obtained a divorce from William Gibbs McAdoo, Democratic junior Senator from California, in Superior Court here today.

Another day of intense heat and no rains in the great producing region west of the Mississippi River increased anxiety over the crop outlook and sent prices on the Cotton Exchange into new high territory again yesterday. After a slightly lower opening, quotations advanced on steady outside buying orders, which carried the list up about $1.50 a bale and left quotations 3 to 7 points higher than on Monday.

PARIS, July 17. -- The plan for Montagu Norman, governor of the Bank of England, and George L. Harrison, governor of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, to sail to New York together aboard the Europa, was settled while the financiers were at Basle.

A revolver went off in the hands of Oakley J. Burns, 17 years old, while he was taking it apart in his home at 337 East 138th Street, the Bronx, yesterday afternoon. The bullet pierced his left hand and struck his 15-year-old brother, Edgar, in the chest, killing him.

CHICAGO, July 17 (AP). -- Pitching steadily, Wes Ferrell turned in his seventh victory for the Red Sox today as the Bostonians defeated the White Sox, 6 to 2, to go 1 up in the series. Ferrell has been charged with only one defeat this season.

Between 12,000 and 15,000 earnest students of the drama fought so fiercely last night for front positions at an open-air performance of "Uncle Tom's Cabin" in Crotona Park, at Arthur Avenue and 175th Street, the Bronx, that the police reserves had to be called to maintain order.

NEWARK, N.J., July 17. -- Two former employes of A. Fink Sons, Inc., meat packers at 810 Frelinghuysen Avenue, were sentenced to thirty days in the Essex County jail by Vice Chancellor M. L. Berry today for contempt of court in the alleged violation of an injunction restraining striking butchers from interfering with the company's business.
Leasehold transactions for business and residential purposes made up the bulk of the Manhattan realty activity reported yesterday.
CHICAGO, July 17. -- A comprehensive plan for reorganization of Middle West Utilities Company bogged down temporarily on details tonight.

Honorary membership in nine police associations has been abolished, and similar action will probably soon be taken by some twenty remaining associations, Police Commissioner O'Ryan announced yesterday.

An issue of $474,500 refunding bonds of the city of Augusta (Me.) water district was awarded yesterday to Estabrook Co. and the Eastern Trust and Banking Company of Bangor at 100.188 for 3 1/4 per cent securities. The bonds, dated Aug. 1, 1934, will mature on Aug. 1, 1935 to 1954.
ST. LOUIS, July 17 (AP). -- Philadelphia batsmen equaled a record today when three players drove home runs in succession, but the Browns beat the Athletics, 7 to 4.

Len Koenecke lifted the depression for the Dodgers and Casey Stengel at Ebbets Field yesterday when he propelled a home run high into the right-field screen that gave the local athletes a 7-to-6 victory over the Cardinals.

GREAT NECK, L.I., July 17. -Walter Scheiber, the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association champion, and Joe Turnesa, who finished second in the national open championship in 1926, tied for the lead in the first eighteen holes of the Long Island open championship at the Lakeville Club today.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 17. -- Play in the Wheatley Cups tournament, the annual 9-goal polo event, got under way at the Meadow Brook Club today with Gerald Dempsey's Wanderers and Princemere registering second-round victories. Aknusti also triumphed in a first-round match.

BERLIN, July 17. -- Details of the system of coercive grain deliveries of fixed quantities which is to be applied to German farmers on the Soviet model are revealed in a decree that became effective yesterday.

The Code Authority for the silk textile industry yesterday voted to operate the industry on a single shift of forty hours a week and to establish a $17 weekly minimum wage for weavers, it was announced by Peter Van Horn, chairman.

Herman Snltkin, store in 72 Cortlandt St., for Ianford Henderson; Gennaro Lettierl store in 455 Broadway; Liggett Drug Company, inc., corner store in_2,12129 BroadwaY: garry Buas and Jaeoo lppert in 122JS0 W 27tn St.; w. H. Tlbbals, in 409-15 Pearl St.; Charles F. Noyes Co., broker. Marstan Studios. portraits, in 1,487-S9 I Broadway; Taukoos. Smith Co., brok%rs.
ON BOARD THE U.S.S. HOUSTON, July 17 (AP). -- Strike developments on the Pacific Coast were relayed to President Roosevelt today as he reached Clipperton Island. He withheld comment.

BALTIMORE, July 17. -- Mrs. Henry Barton Jacobs of Baltimore and Newport today informed the Board of Estimate that she was contributing her art collection, regarded as one of the most important private possessions of its kind in the East, to the city of Baltimore through the Baltimore Museum of Art.

Fourteen properties, including eight in Manhattan and six in the Bronx, were bid in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday. Nine of the plaintiffs were banks. Apartment houses and dwellings made up the bulk of the holdings.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

CALCUTTA, July 17. -- According to dispatches from Northern India, disaster has overtaken the German expedition led by Willy Merkl, which started from Srinagar on May 2 in an attempt to climb Mount Nanga Parbat, 26,629-foot Himalyan peak in Kashmir.

BERLIN, July 17. -- A conflict of fundamental importance to all those investing money in foreign bonds supposedly secured by the revenues of foreign governments has broken out between the three trustees for the Dawes loan and the German Government.

Wall Street's hopes rose yesterday for a time because of what appeared to be a promising rally in the share market, but the customary lamentations were heard in the afternoon when prices had settled back to a point a little below the closing level of the previous day.
Republicans of the Fourteenth Assembly District put up two Democrats as their party candidates at a meeting last night of the Ivy Republican Club, First Avenue and Seventieth Street.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 17. -- The Constituent Assembly this evening elected Provisional President Getulio Vargas as the first constitutional President under the new basic law.

In accordance with a court order, the trustees for $163,000,000 Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway first and refunding mortgage 4 per cent bonds, which matured on April 1, will disburse on Aug. 1, from interest received on the $38,400,000 of general mortgage bonds pledged with them, after certain deductions, $4.74 in respect to interest due on Oct. 1, 1933, for each $1,000 first and refunding bonds.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 17. -- The opening of the second week's bill at the Casino Theatre was paramount in the minds of a majority of the members of the Summer colony this evening. Very few of the colonists were absent.

RUMSON, N.J., July 17. -- Trailing by two goals at half time and with their teamwork broken up by the deep, hard hitting of Rube Williams at back, the United States Army rallied in the second half today and defeated Austin, 7 to 6, reach the final round of the national junior polo championship at the Rumson Country Club.

Alderman John J. Mahoney of the Fifth Assembly District was selected last night to succeed John F. Curry as leader of the northern third of the district. The selection was made at a meeting of the seventeen district captains at the clubhouse, 413 West Fifty-seventh Street.

A letter commending the work of the Boy Scout organization here and expressing the hope that the local drive for a Boy Scout fund would be "most successful" sent by Cardinal Hayes to Chief Justice Frederic Kernochan of the Court of Special Sessions, was made public yesterday by the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New Fork.

ALBANY, July 17. -- Bills designed to prevent Tammany raids on Fusion nominations in New York City were introduced today by Senator Fearon, Republican leader in the Senate, and Assemblyman Ross, Republican of New York City.

ALBANY, July 17. -- The way was cleared at conferences of the legislative leaders today for favorable action on the three pending measures to amend the State Constitution so as to make possible drastic governmental reforms in the five counties comprising New York City and in counties outside of the city as well.
Now and again your editorial page alludes to "Rorabackia" and to Mr. Roraback as a "paleozoic boss." I fancy Mr. Roraback is amused.

CLEVELAND, July 17. -- The Yanks went down in a turbulent game with the Indians at League Park today and at the same time went back to a game and a half behind the league-leading Tigers, who defeated the Senators.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 17. -- The little hamlet of Continentalville, eight miles north of here, was again today the scene of battle after a lapse of about 160 years, when the Continental forces were engaged in repulsing the invading British forces in this historic valley.
For the first time during the present, buying season, the number of buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday reached the thousand mark. The

Two employes of the Sanitation Department were promoted to the top ranks of the department yesterday in recognition of the high ratings they obtained in a promotion examination opened for the first time to all department employes.

James Crawford Biggs, United States Solicitor General; Ewing Y. Mitchell, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, and Charles Edward Russell, American author and journalist, are among the passengers due to sail today on the Manhattan of the United States Lines for the Channel ports.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,600,750 barrels, compared with 2,564,300 the previous week, an increase of 36,450, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Gains of 50,600 barrels in Oklahoma and 16,700 in California were partly offset by a decrease of 38,500 barrels in Texas.

An official announcement this week from the Federal Emergency Administration of Public Works reveals that it has now spent or allotted the entire $3,700,000,000 voted by Congress, and Secretary Ickes is going to ask the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for more.

Chronic unemployment and "implacable" growth of the population of Puerto Rico are two principal economic problems facing the island, Santiago Iglesias, Resident Commissioner in Washintgon, declared here yesterday en route to San Juan.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 17. -- The general strike committee tonight adopted a resolution asking the Governors of all States and the Mayors of all cities affected by the general strike here and by the Pacific Coast dock strike, to urge intervention by President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- Withdrawals from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation on June 30 totaled 188 banks with estimated gross deposits of $5,525,000,000, Leo T. Crowley, chairman, announced today.

WARSAW, July 17. -- While Germany and other large parts of Central Europe are suffering from a drought, a deluge has flooded the entire Polish province of Cracow with a population of 2,000,000. More than 100 persons are reported to have been drowned, while several hundred villages and twenty towns are under water.

" The Three Musketeers," first shown in New York in 1921, will be remade in the new Technicolor process by RKO Radio Pictures, in association with Pioneer Pictures, it was announced yesterday. Tentative plans call for production to begin in October, with Francis Lederer heading an all-star cast.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 17. -- In a dying breeze that collapsed entirely before some of the larger classes could finish, 249 craft started in the third regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club's thirty-sixth annual race week today.

The B.M.T. system announced yesterday that agreements had been reached with committees representing 90 per cent of its employes for the restoration of 2 per cent of the employes' salaries, beginning this month. A 10 per cent cut in salaries was put into effect in 1932.

LOS ANGELES, July 17. -- Violence broke out late today in the Los Angeles harbor strike district. Six paid-off officers and members of the crew of the freighter Point Salinas were forcibly taken from in front of the office of the United States Shipping Commissioner, directly across the street from the police station, and herded into a near-by alley, where all were badly beaten and two were robbed.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., July 17. -- Eleven giant navy patrol planes soared away from San Diego today on an 8,000-mile flight to Alaska and return. Twelve ships will comprise the entire squadron, but one plane, piloted by Lieutenant Bruce Studley, developed minor engine trouble after the take-off and returned to the North Island base for repairs.

BERLIN, July 17. -- National Socialist party officials in Saxony have issued an appeal to all young workers to abandon their jobs and go into labor camps, and to all employers to replace young employes with workers with families.

The State Department of Social Welfare at meeting held yesterday at 80 Centre Street approved an application for the establishment of a non-profit corporation to administer group hospitalization to wage-earners and small-salaried workers through voluntary insurance.
Numerous apartment rentals, particularly on the upper East Side, in the Greenwich Village section and the Bronx, were reported by brokers yesterday, as follows:

HELENA, Mont., July 17. -- Increasing disorders today marked the strike of 3,600 copper miners at Butte, where work ceased on May 8 when the men walked out demanding an increase from 60 cents to $1.25 an hour in basic wages, several changes in working conditions and a thirty-hour work week.
BERLIN, July 17 (AP). -- The Reichsbank statement as of July 14 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

In the delightful days of the old Round Robins they were getting ready to play a holiday morning game at the Polo Grounds when Uncle Wilbert, who was about to hoist a half-pound of chewing tobacco to his mouth, paused to bellow:

Eugene Ormandy began a two-weeks stay at the head of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium last night. His program, like those he has fashioned for succeeding evenings, was adroitly made; it included Weber's "Euryanthe" Overture, Prokofieff's "Classical Symphony," Ravel's Alborado del Gracioso and Schubert's Symphony No. 7 in C.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 17. -- The Tennessee Valley Authority announced today that it had arranged to buy the properties of the Tennessee Public Service Company for $6,088,000.

Interest centred on the ship's brig when the Grace liner Santa Maria docked at Pier 7, North River, at 8 A.M. yesterday. The inmates of the plain but airy detention cell in the interior of the dummy, forward funnel on the sun deck, were two young spectacled bears from Ecuador, consigned to Dr. W. Reid Blair, director of the Bronx Zoo.

ATHENS, July 17. -- The most valuable collection of Byzantine manuscrips in the world has been destroyed, along with scores of ikons, in a fire at the famous monastery of Megaspelaeon, or "great grotto."

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., July 17. -- Mrs. Leo G. Federman of Lakeville today annexed the low-gross prize in a one-day tournament conducted by the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club. Her winning total was 86.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP). -- The Ocean Steamship Company today received Interstate Commerce Commission approval of its local freight and passenger service between New York and Boston, which had been suspended because of protests of other steamship lines and New England interests.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 17. -- A series of raids on known Communist "hot spots" were under way here late today. The police are determined to smash the radical element in San Francisco. Youthful civic Vigilantes aided them.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 18. -- A 30-yard free hit by Harry East after more than seven minutes of overtime enabled the Burnt Mills polo team of New Jersey to down William Ziegler's Great Island quartet, 10 to 9, in the final match of the Hempstead Cups tournament on Cochran Field of the Meadow Brook Club today.

TOKYO, July 18. -- The police report they have unearthed another reactionary plot directed against government leaders, similar to that of May 15, 1932. Wearing bulletproof vests and carrying revolvers, which is unusual in Japan, a squad of policemen raided the headquarters of the East Asia Supremacy Society late last night and arrested four of the group's eighteen known members.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Ten army bombing planes, ready for a mass flight of 3,667 miles to Fairbanks, Alaska, swooped down upon Bolling Field this morning, where Acting Secretary Woodring of the War Department and Air Corps officials waited to welcome the pilots.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Sections of the Securities and Exchange Act which prohibit pools, syndicates and price-pegging wilt be administered by David Saperstein, who was chief assistant of Ferdinand Pecora during the Senate Stock Exchange inquiry.

A further advance in passenger revenue is shown in the Interstate Commerce Commission's compilation of reports by 149 Class I railways for May and the first five months of this year. Passenger revenue in the five months was $133,636,375, against $11,021,364 in the same period last year.

Robert J. Sullivan, 55 years old, of 637 Park Road, West Hartford, Conn., vice president of the Travelers Insurance Company died in Bellevue Hospital at 2 o'clock this morning, an hour and twenty minutes after he was hit by an automobile at Forty-third Street and Sixth Avenue.

PARIS, July 18 (AP). -- A dramatic midnight interrogation of two former Premiers of France, Camille Chautemps and Andre Tardieu, caused national interest in the notorious Stavisky scandal to flare anew tonight.

Auctioneers' stands were the scene of sales of thirteen properties in Manhattan and eight in the Bronx yesterday. All the parsels offered were struck down to the plaintiffs, woh acted to protect their liens on the properties in default.

Touching off a six-run explosion in the third inning, which saw the last of Guy Bush and also Melvin Ott's twenty-second circuit blow of the campaign, the Giants yesterday hurtled the Cubs out of the Polo Grounds feeling more than slightly dubious of playing host to a Chicago world's series next October.

Sophie Braslau, contralto, was soloist last night at the concert by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium. It was Eugene Ormandy's second evening in his fortnight as guest conductor of this eight-week series. There was a good-sized audience which gave Miss Braslau an enthusiastic reception and responded warmly to the interpretations of Mr. Ormandy and the orchestra.
May I comment on your editorial "Steam Airplanes"?

BERLIN, July 18 (London Times Dispatch). -- As the facts of the clean-up of June 30 gradually become known it is revealed that some Jews met their death in the "purge." They were presumably unofficial victims -- that is, they could scarcely have been reckoned among the few civilians included in Chancellor Adolf Hitler's list of seventy-seven persons shot for complicity in the alleged plot.

Results of the first nation-wide examination ever held to pick New York City prison wardens were made public yesterday by the Municipal Civil Service Commission. They show that the best a New York City man could do was to win seventh place.

The Shawinigan Water and Power Company reported yesterday gross revenue of $5,942,569 for the first half of 1934, compared with $5,687,744 in the same period a year ago, after deducting $300,000 representing charge on capital cost of work under construction for that period.

Price ranges for knitted sweaters and dresses for Fall will be the same as those established in the Spring, it was announced here yesterday by the sportswear group of the National Knitted Outerwear Association. The brackets for sweaters are $15.75, $22.50, $30, $33, $42, $45, and $54 a dozen.

Hoboken business men and merchants borrowed a practice from labor yesterday and picketed two chain stores which had refused to enter into their agreement to close Wednesday afternoons. The pickets, however, were hired "sandwich" men.

The semi-final bracket in the annual Eastern junior singles tennis championship was filled yesterday when the first four seeded players triumphed in their matches at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

LONDON, July 18 (AP). -- Fred Perry, Wimbledon and United States tennis champion, and F.H. D. Wilde, sixth ranking English player, today were officially nominated by the English Association to compete in the United States championships at Forest Hills in September.

ALBANY, July 18. -- Awaiting today from Governor Lehman the formal transmission of a protest sent to the Governor by former Governor Alfred E. Smith against the emasculating amendments to the county reform program of the New York City Charter Commission, members of the Legislature today learned that Mr. Lehman is prepared to back Mr. Smith and the Charter Commission to the limit in their fight.

Steel operations have increased his week to 28 per cent of capacity, compared with 27 per cent a week ago, according to the estimate of the Iron Age. The publication says, however, that "seasonal inactivity in the steel industry has been accentuated by increased uncertainty regarding the labor situation and renewed unsettlement in the finished steel price structure."

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., July 19 (AP). -- New York State's amateur golfers are pointing today for the twelfth annual State tournament, July 25-28, on the tricky layout of the Sagamore Golf Club, overlooking Lake George in the lower Adirondacks.

BUENOS AIRES, July 18. -- Argentina's failure to abide by the wheat quota agreement was the result of a larger crop than was expected, according to a long statement by Minister of Agriculture Luis Duhau published today, explaining the government's position.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Conceding the futility of attempting permanently to restore agricultural prosperity through the benefit payment method, Secretary Wallace declared today that re-establishment of the purchasing power of farmers upon its pre-war level depended upon revival of foreign trade.

James C. McKay, gambling promoter of Reno, Nev., on trial here for mail fraud, took the stand yesterday in Federal court and denied to Judge Carroll C. Hincks and a jury that he had ever played a part in confidence games.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 18. -- Judgment for the defendant rendered today by Judge John Rufus Booth of Superior Court in the case of Peter Strong of Hartford against the International Union of Elevator Constructors. Labor leaders hailed the decision as highly important and significant.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP). -- Increase of the drought over a major part of the country was reported today by the Weather Bureau in its weekly bulletin.

Ellis Jungman, who was chairman of the Municipal Examining Board of Plumbers until he was removed by Mayor LaGuardia, was revealed yesterday to have been one of two former members of the board who had been indicted on Tuesday for bribery.

BISMARCK, N.D., July 18. -- The political chaos growing out of the conflict between William Langer and Ole H. Olson over the Governorship of North Dakota threatened tonight to develop into a state of anarchy.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18 (AP). -- The Reds today won their first game in Philadelphia this season, defeating the Phillies, 9 to 8, in a ninth-inning rally. The defeat ended a Phil winning streak at five games.

BERLIN, July 18. -- It was announced from Munich tonight that at a session of the Bavarian Cabinet it had been decided, "in line with a pertinent decision of the Reich Ministry of the Interior and a decree of the chief of staff of the Storm Troops," to abolish immediately in Bavaria also the institution of Storm Troop members invested with special powers or special commissions in administrative offices.

DETROIT, July 18 (AP). -- The Tigers made it two out of three over the Senators today, taking the final game of the series, 4 to 2. The victory increased Detroit's margin over the second-place Yankees to two and a half games.

WESTERLY, R.I., July 18. -- Police today questioned three recently employed servants in the theft of $24,000 worth of jewels from Mrs. J. Russell Forgan of Chicago at Meadow Crest cottage, in the exclusive Watch Hill colony. They refused to state tonight whether they had found any clues in the mysterious robbery of Sunday night or Monday.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

BISMARCK, N.D., July 18. -- Acting Governor Ole H. Olson today apparently gathered in control of the State's military forces after the Supreme Court again sustained him in his contest with the ousted Governor, William A. Langer.

" Some of your readers might like to hear of my experiences with a type of fishing which is becoming increasingly popular," writes Peter W. Barrett of lepton School, Tarrytown, N.Y. "I refer to bass fishing with the so-called bugs.

CHICAGO, July 18. -- Prices of hogs today were weak to 5 cents a hundredweight lower than yesterday, common lights selling at the under figures. Most hogs were of plain quality. The top was $4.95, a drop of 5 cents; the average was $4.65, the same as yesterday. Most sales were at from $4.20 to $4.90, compared with $4.20 to $4.95 yesterday.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 18. -- Tonight's opening performance of the new comedy "Hitch Your Wagon" by the South Shore Players at Guild Hall was witnessed by a brilliant and enthusiastic audience. Miss Ona Munson and Alan Marshall took leading parts.

CHICAGO, July 18 (AP). -- Scoring nine runs in the first inning, seven of them on homers by Roy Johnson and Bill Cissell, the former's with two on and the latter's with the bases loaded, the Red Sox routed the White Sox, 16 to 3, today to take the series, three games to one.

Estimating that its eight-month inquiry into the Brooklyn laundry racket has saved the public more than $2,000,000, the extraordinary grand jury in Brooklyn completed its labors yesterday. It exonerated public officials of any wrongdoing, and outlined many reforms for the prevention of future evils in the laundry industry.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 18. -- The Rev. Francis J. Haas, Federal Labor Relations Board mediator, went into conference with officers of the drivers' union late today in an effort to settle the strike which has tied up truck transportation here for two days. E.H. Dunnigan, Federal labor conciliator, whose efforts to avert the walkout were fruitless, also attended the parley.

ABOARD CRUISER NEW ORLEANS, ACCOMPANYING PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT, July 18 (AP). -- President Roosevelt watched the cruisers Houston and New Orleans play hide and seek in tactical maneuvres on the Pacific today. Aboard the Houston he continued his cruise toward Hawaii, the boats cutting through whitecapped swells in squally weather.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 18. -- A mile-a-minute, achieved by Mike Murphy on a bicycle four decades ago, was attained within a fraction by the new America's Cup yacht Rainbow over the rejuvenated Yankee today, but it meant little as far as comparison toward a cup defender.

GENEVA, N.Y., July 18 (AP). -A warning to grape growers to be on the lookout for signs of the grape leafhopper has been issued by Professor F.Z. Hartzell, entomologist, at the New York State agricultural experiment station. The pest has been found in many grade areas in the State this year.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., July 18. -- Back from the strike. There is no doubt the "Reds" run away with the fair, conservative leaders in the union. The thing was not, as some try to make you believe, 100 per cent one-sided. They had some just kicks, and plenty of fair-minded people of San Francisco were in sympathy with 'em.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 18. -- How the Communist high command in New York planned nearly a year ago to shake the maritime cities of America by strikes such as those now in effect on the Pacific Coast was revealed today by documents seized in raids on Communist centres here Tuesday.

KANSAS CITY, July 18 (AP). -- Drought in the great Southwest is paralyzing industry, creating want, destroying properly and bringing untold suffering. Vegetation does not grow. Streams have run dry. Springs have failed. Trees, with leaves blighted, provide little or no shade.
It seems to me that all of our critics of the New Deal were most effectively answered by Will Rogers in THE TIMES this morning when he said: "You feed a dog and he bites you."

Stocks displayed quiet strength yesterday, but there was a shrinkage in the volume of business on the Stock Exchange. Prices rose an average of about l 1/4 points, the broadest advance in two weeks. Transactions made up a total of 490,000 shares, compared with 616,000 shares on the day before.

CHICAGO, July 18. -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, said today that the San Francisco general strike was not authorized and had "no national significance." He stated that his organization was not entering into the controversy.

Maritime labor unions here will request the Federal Government to set up arbitration machinery for the adjustment of differences between the workers and steamship owners to avoid any possibility of a strike in the Port of New York.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 18. -- The Stockbridge art exhibition committee, at a meeting yesterday in the Weybourne Hill villa of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Johansen, voted to hold the annual exhibition at the Berkshire playhouse early in September. Mr. Johansen was reelected chairman and Miss Curtis Beaver secretary and manager.

HELENA, Mont., July 18. -- Senator John E. Erickson, who resigned as Governor of Montana to accept appointment to the Senate by the Lieutenant Governor, who succeeded him, apparently was defeated for the Democratic nomination to succeed himself.

Twenty-four hours more of scorching heat in Texas, Arkansas and Oklahoma, which normally contribute nearly half the yearly production of American cotton, sent prices into new high ground again yesterday. With unfavorable reports of the crop coming from wide areas in Texas and Oklahoma, the buying movement absorbed a large quantity of cotton sold by Southern holders in liquidating loans.

PORTLAND, Ore., July 18. -- United States Senator Robert F. Wagner, representing the National Labor Relations Board in the labor upheavals here, and a party of labor union officials were fired on by guards at Municipal Terminal 4 tonight as they were inspecting the premises, which have been the scene of strike-breaking activities and numerous clashes between police and striking longshoremen.

BERLIN, July 18. -- The constant struggle for power going on behind the facade of the Third Reich is approaching a crisis in the economic field. At stake are the degree of liberty to be enjoyed by the German business man and the role competition is to play in German economic life.

In a statement pledging Socialist support to the general strike on the West Coast, the national publicity committee of the Socialist party yesterday accused the industrialist and conservative elements of California of conspiracy to destroy the labor unions and of provoking the conflict now in progress.

CAMP DIX, N.J., July 18. -- The first regimental parade of the citizens' military training camp, Second Corps Area, with more than 900 students in line, took place here this evening. Officers of the 307th Infantry, Seventy-seventh Division, were in command.

Italy's plan to construct two 35,000-ton battleships, which is her privilege under the Washington Agreement of 1922, is followed by reports from Washington that our Navy Department contemplates 35,000-ton vessels as replacements for its aging battleships of today.

BALBOA, C.Z., July 18. -- Sixteen earthquakes, the first at 8:45 P.M. yesterday, have been recorded in this area in the last twenty-four hours. They have resulted in one known death and in injuries to at least five persons.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Housing conditions in the United States amply demonstrate the need of the administration's new housing program, Acting Secretary Dickinson of the Commerce Department, announced today in making public results of a national "real property inventory," now being conducted by the department.

BERLIN, July 18. -- Moderate revival of public interest lifted a number of active stocks to higher levels on the Boerse today. Most of the advances were only fractional to one point or so, but Berlin-Karlsruhe gained 2 1/2 points on the day and Bavarian Motors closed 4 3/8 points above yesterday's final quotation.

Reflecting the continued tendency of borrowers to seek credit through the cheaper media of over-the-counter bank loans and commercial paper, rather than bankers' acceptances, the volume of bankers' bills outstanding fell $34,597,266 further in June to $534,193,248 at the end of that month.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

Primo Carnera issued an ultimatum to the Madison Square Garden Corporation yesterday through his manager, Louis Soresi, notifying James J. Johnston, director of boxing, that unless a suitable opponent for him was named within forty-eight hours he would accept an offer from Jeff Dickson, European promoter.

SALEM, N.H., July 18 (AP). -- Teralice, a 4-year-old son of Terry, carried A. Bartelstein's silks to his third straight victory in accounting for the $2,500 White Mountain Handicap at six furlongs over the Rockingham Park course today.
BOSTON, July I8 (AP). -- The Braves took both games of a double-header today, defeating the Pirates, 3 -- 1 and 7 -- 5, and winning the series, three games to two.

BERLIN, July 18. -- Revelations as to the spending of millions of marks in voluntary contributions to various Nazi funds have had a considerable effect on the National Socialist party's income. In these circumstances new methods of keeping the population alive to the necessity for contributing freely and without questions have had to be devised. An ingenious one was developed today.
LIVERPOOL, July 18. -- King George pressed a golden switch today to open the new $40,000,000 Mersey tunnel, between Liverpool and Birkenhead, the largest underwater tunnel in the world.

One hundred and twenty New York University students attained the honor roll for the second semester of the 1933-34 academic year in the day division of the university's School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance, Dean John T. Madden announced yesterday.

A sharp upturn in the demand for multi-family buildings in Manhattan and the Bronx was indicated in sales announced yesterday. The increased activity is exceptional for this time of the year and is accounted for in part by the demand of investors for buildings that can be renovated in time for the Fall renting season.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 18. -- Fire in one of the two motors of a huge seaplane which started from Chicago late today on a round-the-world tour threatened to destroy the plane as it neared Cleveland tonight and forced Flight Commander W.H. Alexander, the pilot, to make a swift landing in Lake Erie, 1,000 feet from the Edgewater Park breakwater.

For three hours yesterday afternoon General Sessions Judge Otto A. Rosalsky, acting as mediator at the request of Mayor LaGuardia, listened to arguments in differences over wages, working hours and other grievances between the 300 union shochetim, or kosher chicken killers, of the city and wholesale and retail dealers in the kosher chicken market.

LONDON, July 18 (AP). -- International circles here said a new political pact involving Japan, Great Britain and the United States, suggested at Geneva today, was "impossible" because of American and British opposition. It was recalled that the same suggestion was made by Japan some time ago.
Robert Connor, 21-month-old "explorer" whose wanderings in the woods near his Hartsdale Manor home almost cost him his life, was reported yesterday to be gaining strength and convalescing slowly.

Central Park's sheep meadow buzzed with the sound of "winders" yesterday as more than 300 boys coiled tie rubber bands which are the motors of most types of model airplanes. Members of the Junior Birdmen of America, they were competing in several categories of model flight.

Children's Day will be observed at Jones Beach State Park on Saturday, July 28, it was announced yesterday by the Long Island State Park Commission. The program, under the joint auspices of the commission and R.H. Macy Co., Inc., will include games, races and story-telling.

A modern industrial system must provide a substitute for the pork barrel and the sauerkraut jar that carried families through Winters in periods of economic stress under an earlier and less specialized economic system, Owen D. Young says in an interview printed in the current issue of the weekly Today.

LONDON, July 18. -- A team of eight women golfers headed by Miss Doris Chambers as captain today was named to represent Great Britain in a team series against Canadian women Sept. 15 and in the Curtis Cup matches against the United States Sept. 27-28.

The operators of American flag merchant ships welcome the proposed Federal investigation of ocean mail contracts and favor a revision of the present system to provide more stable government aid based on long-term planning, according to R.J. Baker, president of the American Steamship Owners Association.
MANCHESTER, Mass., July 18 (AP). -- Three-fourths of the seeded list was eliminated today in the quarter-final round of the Essex County women's invitation tennis tournament.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 18. -- The hills and valleys along the six-mile route between Continentalville and Camp Smith reverberated today with the fire of machine guns and rifles as the 107th Infantry, the old Seventh Regiment of Manhattan, returning from its two-night bivouac at Continentalville, continued its war manoeuvres.

DUSSELDORF, Germany, July 18 (AP). -- The team of American track and field stars, led by John Lyman, the husky weight tosser from Stanford University, won four of seven first places today in its third meet this week.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- This government is convinced that the Dawes and Young Plan loan contracts have been torn up by the actions of Germany and Great Britain, although sufficient information has not been received as to the latest measures taken in Berlin for officials to form even tentative opinions as to what should be done to meet the new situation.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Secretary Ickes today made an allotment of $478,300 from PWA funds for construction of a full-speed wind tunnel at the laboratories of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics at Langley Field, Va. The project had not only the unanimous endorsement of the NACA but also the support of Secretaries Dern, Swanson and Roper.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- The National Emergency Council is building up a system for disseminating information on government recovery agencies and the procedure for using them. The data are being put into a loose-leaf manual on which the council's staff is working.

PARIS, Thursday, July 19. -- In an exhausting and bitter exchange of political and personal recriminations that lasted for fifteen hours all yesterday and most of last night, Andre Tardieu, former Premier and Minister of State at present, had his say on the Stavisky scandal before the parliamentary commission of inquiry.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP). -- Pressure is being brought on the National Recovery Administration to declare ninety-day price fixing emergencies in several industries beset by midsummer business slack and sharp competition.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 18. -Joseph Gagliardi of Winged Foot, playing on his home course, returned a 77, five above par, to annex low gross honors in the Metropolitan Golf Association's one-day tournament today. The leader equaled par on the outgoing nine with a 36 but faltered coming in, taking a 41.

The fact that, as Mayor LAGUARDIA said to the nurserymen, this city has "planted more trees since the first of "January than any other city in the "world" indicates a progress toward the ideal. The place of ultimate happiness, as described in the Apocalypse, is a city in the midst of which are trees of life "on this side and on that" of the river of water flowing through it.
BERLIN, July 18. -- Aviation Minister Hermann Wilhelm Goering's newspaper, the Essner Nazionaler Zeitung, says today:

CHICAGO, July 18. -- A basis for the distribution of "rights" for the purchase of stock in a reorganized company has been tentatively agreed upon by security holders of Middle West Utilities Company. This was indicated today following further conferences between representatives of the noteholders and the preferred stockholders.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 18. -- The Federal authorities joined forces today with San Francisco police, citizen Vigilantes and conservative union leaders in their efforts to exterminate Communist terrorism.

SEATTLE, Wash., July 18. -- Twelve hundred striking maritime workers and sympathizers wearing Communist buttons stormed police lines guarding two piers today. Part of the crowd broke through the lines in an attempt to reach non-union workers unloading steamers, but were repulsed with tear-gas bombs.

After running pretty much all over the United States a shocking practice has invaded New York. It is the use in newspapers of "U" for university. This usage, which I assume will be defended from the standpoint of the width of the column in which the abbreviation appears, is unattractive.

RED BANK, N.J., July 18. -- A warning of the presence of sharks was echoing today along the waterfront of this and neighboring communities on the North Shrewsbury River. Bathing was restricted to the sunny beaches, and, here at least, if the mental picture of a triangular fin cleaving the water was not sufficient to keep bathers ashore a squad of police was at hand to do it.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board issued today figures indicating that member banks on June 30 had nearly one-third more assets in securities than at the peak of the boom in 1929. With the shrinkage of loans and investments from $35,711,000,000 to around $26,000,000,000, the proportion of security holdings to the total nearly doubled.

CLEVELAND, July 18. -- This was a melancholy day in the life of the Yankees. They lost their farewell game of the series to the Indians, 15 to 14, they dropped further back in the torrid race for the American League flag, and they lost the services of Babe Ruth, all in one fell swoop.

Demand for borough autonomy has more than mere politics behind it. Politicians are only capitalizing what is a widespread and deep-rooted sentiment in the so-called "outlying boroughs." Historically, socially and commercially Manhattan has been the centre, and is still.

A new issue of $750,000 Hamilton County, Ohio, poor relief bonds, dated Aug. 1, 1934, and due from Sept. 1, 1934, to March 1, 1938, was awarded yesterday to a syndicate comprising the Guaranty Trust Company, E.B. Smith Co. and the Central Trust Company of Cincinnati.

Net income of the Owens-Illinois Glass Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on June 30 amounted to $5,854,212 after depreciation, interest, Federal taxes and other charges. This was equivalent to $4.88 a share on 1,200,000 shares of $25 par common stock.

" There will be plenty of politics this year." So warns, or chuckles, a Tammany sta- ether he speaks for the new leader, Er. DOOLTNa, does not appear. But there is every sign $2t a reunited T. rnrnany is already preparing to display its strength at the polls in November.

BERLIN, July 18. -- The new United States note contributed to the long-standing diplomatic debate between Washington and Berlin on the rights and wrongs of alleged German financial and commercial discrimination against Americans has created a very painful impression on German officials, it was learned today.

An application for the appointment of a receiver of the property of Charles L. Craig, lawyer and former Controller, in supplementary proceedings on a judgment for $406 obtained in Putnam County by the McNulty Brothers Garages, INC., was filed in Supreme Court yesterday.

Eighteen families living on the upper floor of a large building at Beach Thirty-fourth Street and Edgemere Avenue, Edgemere, Queens, were routed from their apartments last night when fire started in a drugstore on the ground floor of the building.

When Secretary Ickes approaches Chairman Jones of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for the purpose of recruiting the loaning funds of the PWA, a New Deal commission will be seeking aid from the progenitor of all the alphabetical establishments that have grown up under President Roosevelt.
NEWARK, N.J., July 18. -- Frank Makosky, pitching his first full game of the season, hurled the Bears back into winning form today with a creditable 7-to-3 victory, over Baltimore.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 18 (AP). -Canned roses are not quoted on market exchanges, but the industry founded on development of a new process of sealing plants in airtight containers, has grown to a surprising extent.

Mrs. Kathryn Budd of 411 Caton Avenue, Brooklyn, received a permit yesterday from the State Labor Department to do industrial home work in artificial flowers. But the issuance of the permit, far from settling the controversy over the right of a mother with two children to carry on industrial work in her home despite NRA code provisions, merely precipitated the dispute into a new stage.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 18. -- The general strike was rapidly disintegrating tonight at the end of its third day. Its effectiveness was greatly decreased, and it was widely believed that it could not last even as a formality for more than other day or two.

KOHLER, Wis., July 18 (AP). -- Former Governor Walter J. Kohler of Wisconsin, in the first statement for the management of the Kohler Company, whose employes are on strike, today challenged the right of Union No. 18545, American Federation of Labor, to represent workers of the plumbing concern.
What this country needs is a good definition of "unfair competition."

BALTIMORE, July 18. -- United States District Judge W. Calvin Chestnut today signed an order temporarily restraining NRA and code officials from attempting to force L. Greif Brothers, Inc., second largest clothing manufacturer in the country, to pay wages above the Clothing Code minimum.

Twelve new playgrounds will be opened by the Park Department on Aug. 11, it became known yesterday. Under orders from Park Commissioner Moses the department is concentrating most of its relief labor on playground work, so that these recreation areas may be made available to the city's children this Summer.

A better tone prevailed in the majority of commodity futures markets yesterday. Advances were scored by rubber, coffee and hides. Metals were somewhat firmer in dull trading, while sugar and silk futures were weak. In the cash markets all the grains, sugar, cotton and rubber advanced.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 18. -- Oakland and its seven companion cities on the East Bay began today to draw themselves out of the difficulties of a general strike.

In opposition to the current campaign of the Catholic, Protestant and Jewish faiths to reform the screen and stage, a mass meeting will be held Monday night at the New Yorker Hotel by the newly incorporated Association for the Preservation of the Freedom of Screen and Stage.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 18. -- While their elders took a day off from the rigors of Larchmont Race Week to give a thought to business or join the rocking chair fleet ashore, a record number of youngsters sailed in the ninth annual regatta of the Junior Yacht Racing Association today.

A poll of opinions among the Code Authorities of consumer goods industries on the major questions surrounding the NRA at present will be taken by a subcommittee of the Consumer Industries Committee, it was decided yesterday at a meeting of the group at the Hotel Waldorf.

ALBANY, July 18. -- Additional legislation will be sought by the joint legislative committee created to make a broad investigation of the public utility and power interests in the State and their political relations.
Conveyance of a business building in the Journal Square area of Jersey City featured the New Jersey realty trading reported yesterday.

WILMER ALLISON from Texas, down by the Rio Grande had a free trip to Europe, but Wilmer's expressed opinion is that he was just being taken for a ride. It's a puzzling case, hard for outsiders to understand.

CHICAGO, July 18. -- Country holders of corn are taking advantage of the reports of damage done to the corn crop by hot weather in Kansas and Nebraska and are selling their holdings on all sharp price advances. Commission-house buying has increased greatly within a week and large professional operators buy on weak spots, thereby absorbing liberal lines.

BRIDGETON, N.J., July 18. -- General labor unrest among farmhands and employes in affiliated industries was evident in Southern New Jersey today as one organization closed its plants and warning was sounded that a general strike might be called on Aug. 6 at the Seabrook Farms.

LONDON, July 18. -- Charles E. Nicholson, designer of the British America's Cup challenger, Endeavour, told THE NEW YORK TIMES tonight that he was making every effort to get the Yacht ready to leave for New York on Sunday. He added that the owner of Endeavour, T.O.M. Sopwith, was eager to have her in American waters at the earliest possible moment.
HONGKONG, July 18. -- Nanking representatives today discussed with Canton officials plans for electing a Governor of Kwangtung Province to supersede the existing political council.
