James J. Dooling, new leader of Tammany Hall, said yesterday that he planned to confer with the Democratic leaders of the other counties on Monday to begin the task of picking a candidate for the Controllership nomination. It was indicated that arrangements for the conference had been made.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 18. -Arriving here from Spring Lake, where he successfully defended the Clifford Hemphill Challenge Trophy, Frank Parker started his grass court campaign today in the invitation tournament of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club.

The Dutch Treat Club, the Artists' and Writers' Golf Association and the Society of Illustrators have sent checks totaling $1,050 to the Authors League Fund to help meet unusually urgent emergencies, it is reported by Arthur McKeogh, chairman of the fund's committee on aid for unemployed writers.

CHICAGO, July 18 (AP). -- The Republican party opened Western campaign headquarters here today, planning to have its activities running full tilt by Sept. 17. Representative Chester C. Bolton of Cleveland, chairman of the Congressional campaign committee, announced he would also serve as "Western joint campaign manager."

Louis A. Stone writes to THE NEW YORK TIMES concerning automobile insurance and suggests that financial responsibility through public liability and property damage coverage should be compulsory in this State.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Retail food prices advanced slightly during the two weeks ended July 3, Commissioner Lubin of the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. This is the third consecutive advance, and the bureau's index, based on 1913 averages, stood at 109.6 on July 3 as compared with 109.1 June 19, 108.4 June 5 and May 22, and 108.2 on May 8.
ALBANY, July 18. -- Fred W. Hammond, Clerk of the Assembly and storm centre of Republican politics in recent months, announced today that he would retire at the end of the current term.

Police Commissioner O'Ryan announced yesterday the transfer of 108 more uniformed sergeants, in keeping with the plan announced last Saturday for the eventual transfer of every sergeant who has been at his present post for more than two years.

Such was the cry of the friends of civic virtue who renominated WILLIAM LANGER for Governor of North Dakota in the Republican primary the day before a Federal district judge sentenced him to eighteen months in the penitentiary and a fine of $10,000 for defrauding the United States Government by soliciting political funds from Federal employes.
Disproving reports that she had lost her speed, the Dorwood Stable's Miss Merriment scored a two-length victory in the featured Chevalier Purse at Empire City yesterday.

The protection afforded civil service employes in the matters of permanent status, prevailing rates of pay and vacations with pay was asked yesterday by employes of the Independent Subway System of the city at a hearing before members of the Municipal Civil Service Commission at the City Hall.

New York City saves a total of $3,450,000 in interest under the terms of a revised agreement reached last night between the city and a banking syndicate for the purchase by the banks of $58,000,000 of city securities.
RYE, N.Y., July 18. -- Mrs. George Buchtenkirk received the sweepstakes prize at the flower show of the Rye Garden Club, held today at the Rye Library. She was the winner of three first prizes.

The Regional Labor Board intervened yesterday in an effort to stop the threatened strike of 18,000 knit goods workers, plans for which were completed this week by the Knit Goods Workers Union with the approval of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union, the parent organization, and with the cooperation of the United Textile Workers of America.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18. -- City Controller S. Davis Wilson was made defendant today in a $50,000 slander suit, filed in Common Pleas Court 3 by Frederick P. Gruenberg, a member of the Pennsylvania Public Service Commission.

The bond market on the Stock Exchange was active and generally higher yesterday, all classifications participating in the advance. Most of the United States Government long-term issues closed higher, final prices being up 7-32 to down 5-32 point.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 18. -- Mrs. Nicholas Brown opened her estate, Harbour Court, this afternoon for the annual lawn party for the benefit of Emmanuel Church, of which her son, John Nicholas Brown, is senior warden. Residents of the Summer colony were liberal patrons of the various booths, where others of their number assisted the church members who were in charge.
As Liner Comes Up the Bay They Sing and Dance -- Bring Stamp Collection for the President.

LONDON, July 18. -- I.M. Maisky, Soviet Ambassador, called at the Foreign Office this afternoon and assured Sir Robert Vansittart, Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, that Russia would give the guarantee required of her in the event that the proposed Eastern Locarno plan were adopted by all the countries concerned.

CHICAGO, July 18 (AP). -- Jumping to the front in the Lake Bluff Purse at five and a half furlongs at Arlington Park today, E.D. Shaffer's St. Bernard raced to a brilliant victory, conquering five other fast 2-year-olds.

ALBANY, July 18. -- Governor Lehman will present to the extraordinary session of the Legislature the request of the LaGuardia administration for power to levy special taxes for unemployment relief, it was indicated here today.

LONDON, July 18. -- The stock markets became more cheerful today after several days of extreme dullness. British Government funds were steady. A firm undertone pushed British industrials upward, although public interest was small. Textiles, tobaccos, shippings and aviations improved generally.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., July 18. -- The Westchester Lighting Company has abandoned a $4,500,000 construction program scheduled for this year because of "troublesome conditions," according to a statement by Eugene Rosenquest, president of the company, which was contained in the pay envelopes of each of the corporation's 3,000 employes.

ALBANY, July 18 (AP). -- New York City grocers appeared before State Milk Control officials today to add their protest to the claim of Charles H. Baldwin, Agriculture Commissioner, that the administration of Mayor LaGuardia is evading the division's orders in its sales of loose milk at city welfare stations.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 18. -- The Hudson Counties Title and Mortgage Company of Newburgh, Orange County, was placed under rehabilitation today by order of Supreme Court Justice Frederick P. Close. George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, who moved to take over the company, said it would be "hazardous" for policy holders, creditors and the public for the company to continue business.

Four men robbed the Charles P. Goldsmith wholesale jewelry concern, at 20-26 West Thirty-sixth Street, of $250,000 worth of jewelry yesterday afternoon. But while they were stuffing the loot into two satchels and a brief case a man who had watched the proceedings from a window across the street telephoned the police.

Stirred by Manager Frankie Frisch's fiery pre-game appeal to start winning "their share" of games, and aided no little by three Dodger errors, the Cardinals yesterday captured the final game of the series at Ebbets Field, 5 to 3.

The industrial advisory committee of the New York Federal Reserve district held its third meeting yesterday and completed its organization. The committee, which consists of five industrialists, has been organized to pass upon loans to industry to be made by or guaranteed by the Federal Reserve Bank under the Industrial Loan Act of June 19.

Machado's Strange Refuge. The story about MACHADO taking asylum in Santo Domingo will not for a moment deceive the well-informed person who knows his Alexandre Dumas plus his Sherlock Holmes. With scores of thousands of Cubans thirsting for his blood, why should MACHADO seek refuge only a few hundred miles from Santiago de Cuba?

LOS ANGELES, July 18. -- Investigation was begun today into the speed with which the famous White House romance of Senator William Gibbs McAdoo and Eleanor Wilson McAdoo, daughter of the late President Wilson, was shattered here late yesterday by a divorce.

AUSTIN, Texas, July 18 (AP). -- "Fergusonism," an issue that has blazed a vivid trail for twenty years across the firmament of Texas politics, has been revived in the current scramble for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP). -- Whether and how to unify the nation's supply of electricity and standardize the rate structure will be investigated by President Roosevelt's new National Power Policy Committee in its effort to find a means of providing power cheaply to all users.
WASHINGTON, July 18. -- President Roosevelt expressed full confidence today that the National Longshoremen's Board, which he appointed, would be able to settle the San Francisco strike.

Lloyd P. Stryker, counsel for Dr. Fred H. Albee, internationally known bone surgeon, who was suspended by the New York County Medical Society for a year on charges of improper advertising, told Supreme Court Justice Valente yesterday that he had "never seen a more stark case of injustice" in all his "experience before the bar of New York."

GREAT NECK, L.I., July 18. -In spite of a depressing finish Joe Turnesa, the Old Belleclaire professional, protected his lead in the Long Island open golf championship today while Walter Scheiber of Hillcrest, with whom he shared the lead in the first round, dropped back.

Desha Breckinridge of Lexington, Ky., who is at the Savoy-Plaza before going to Nantucket, Mass., gave a luncheon there yesterday. His guests included Colonel and Mrs. Henry S. Breckinridge, Captain William Breckinridge, U.S.A., and Mrs. Breckinridge, Mrs. E.L.D. Breckinridge, the Misses Elizabeth and Dudley Breckinridge and Oren Root Jr.
New Yorkers will soon have no need to repair to the country to study nature or to indulge in fishing.
VIENNA, July 18. -- The Vienna Catholic organ Reichspost published today the details of several murders of German Catholics. It obtained the facts from trustworthy Catholic correspondent in Germany.

LONDON, Thursday, July 19. -- What Daily Mail headlines describe as a "divergence of ideas" on the aims and methods of the Black Shirts has appeared between Sir Oswald Mosley, leader of the British Fascist movement, and Lord Rothermere, who until recently has given to Sir Oswald the full support of the Rothermere chain of newspapers.
ATLANTA, July 18 (AP). -- A revolt against legislative bossism" has been organized by Georgia's Mayors, who figure that they ought to be allowed to run their city business without State dictation.

LONDON, July 18. -- A wealthy American's search for King John's treasure, believed to have been lost in The Wash, a twenty-mile sheet of tidal water between Norfolkshire and Lincolnshire, more than 700 years ago, was the subject of a legal action here today.

ST. LOUIS, July 18 (AP). -- Jimmy Foxx pounded out his twenty-eighth home run of the season today, scoring Bob Johnson ahead of him, in a ninth-inning rally that fell short as the Athletics dropped the third in a row to the Browns, 3 to 2.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 18 (AP). -- A chance to use the spectroscope to read in simple terms the ordinary complicated puzzle of biological, or living, substances was demonstrated to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology spectroscopy conference today.
" Roberta," at the New Amsterdam Theatre, will have its concluding performance on Saturday night. It will begin a road tour in Boston the latter part of August.

RAPID CITY, S.D., July 18. -- With local storm areas throughout the Northwest, there was little prospect of a take-off before the end of the week, it was announced today at the stratosphere camp in Spring Creek canyon.

VIENNA, July 18. -- Former King Alfonso was involved in a fatal automobile accident in the small hours of this morning. He was returning to the city from a fashionable cafe on Cobenzi Hill above the city when another car approached his in Grinzing, a suburb, at the same moment a street car rounded the corner.

Brokers were disappointed yesterday in the amount of business available, but their customers were heartened by the moderate advance in prices. The fact that prices rose on such a small turnover was encouraging, but Wall Street concluded that the market needs much more of a stimulant than it has received at any time this Summer.

Determination to enforce the assessment right of code authorities as a means of financing operation of codes was expressed yesterday by Nathan Straus Jr., State director of the National Emergency Council and chief NRA enforcement officer in this State.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Governor Merriam of California informed Secretary Perkins today that he had radioed President Roosevelt at sea asking that immigration officials on the West Coast be instructed to deport aliens "who shall be found guilty of participating in or in any way aiding any violent and unlawful action or riot."

HUNTSVILLE, Ala., July 18 (AP). -- Alabama's textile strike, confined exclusively to the northern half of the State, today was marked principally by peaceful picketing of the twenty-one closed cotton mills and by angling by union officials for other units to join the walkout.

CLEVELAND, July 19 (AP). -- Alva Bradley, president of the Cleveland Baseball Club of the American League, announced tonight that he had signed Walter Johnson as the Indians' manager for the 1935 season.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 19. -- The general strike was called off this afternoon and most of the 50,000 union men and women who have been out for the last four days returned to work or prepared to get back on the job tomorrow morning.
For the first time in many a week Casey Stengel's Dodgers staged one of those perfect ninth-inning finishes at Ebbets Field yesterday to sink the Pirates, 4 to 2, in the opening game of the series.
HARRIMAN, Tenn., July 19. -- The Blue Eagle has been officially restored to the Harriman Hosiery Mills, it was revealed here today.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- Decreases in employment of 119,000 workers and about $5,000,000 in weekly wages during June were reported today by Secretary Perkins. The figures were based on returns from 103,788 establishments in manufacturing and non-manufacturing industries surveyed by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date. No other important item in the system reached a new high or low point for the year.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

SALEM, N.H., July 19 (AP). -- The longest odds on a winner in the history of Rockingham Park were returned today when W.F. Axton's Monks Star accounted for the second race and paid $209.50 for a $2 ticket in the mutuels.
The movie magnates are represented as puzzled by what is meant by "good movies." In these circumstances would it be expecting too much to ask them for a little art?

Johnfritz Achelis, president of Commercial Factors Corporation, announced yesterday that James Gould, James F. Hallinan and Walter L. Weil have been elected directors and members of the executive committee effective as of July 1, 1934.

The Continental Can Company, Inc., reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on June 30 a net profit of $9,059,662, after depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges. This is equivalent to $5.16 a share on 1,755,689 shares of $20 par common stock outstanding at the end of the period.
Prices moved irregularly higher in a fair volume of trading yesterday in local commodity markets. The midday drop in cotton was almost ignored. Cash prices changed little.

The grievances of representatives of various branches of the ice industry in this area were presented yesterday at a hearing called by the NRA administration to regulate prices and overproduction, which, according to local code authorities, have created "an emergency" in this industry.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 19. -- Mrs. Robert Appleton entertained members of her postoffice committee for the village fair to be held on July 27 at a tea today. The committee includes:

Called by the New York provisional committee in support of the West Coast strike, 5,000 Communists gathered in Union Square last night under the watchful eye of an elaborate police detail and heard Left-Wing leaders give their opinions about the situation in San Francisco.
LONDON, July 19 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP). -- Several small stock exchanges are seeking exemption from regulation by the Securities and Exchange Commission. This became known today as Commissioner George C. Mathews was designated to supervise the corporate reporting division and Commissioner Ferdinand Pecora the stock trading division.
VIENNA, July 19. -- Bombers got busy today after the expiration of the time limit set in Chancellor Dollfuss's ultimatum for the surrender of explosives under threat of the death penalty.

Next year's automobile show in this city will be held under the auspices of the Automobile Merchants Association of New York, an organization of distributers and dealers, and not under those of the National Automobile Chamber of Commerce, it was announced yesterday.
CHICAGO, July 19. -- Almost three and a half billion dollars were paid to policy holders and beneficiaries in 1933 by life insurance companies in the United States and Canada.

Further consideration of the pro-] /posal for an approach to the Triol I Borough Bridge from the westerly I section of the Bronx, comprising Sedgvick Avenue, Exterior Streett and East 135th Street, is requested I in a letter addressed by Fred Berry, ] President of the ]3ronx Board of | Trade, to Commissioner Robert Moses of the Bridge uthority.

Hal Schumacher, the distinguished St. Lawrence alumnus, who, upon entering the National League, took to beating the Reds as the youngsters up in his home town in Dolgeville, N.Y., take to ice skates, used exactly one hour and twenty-five minutes at the Polo Grounds yesterday to demonstrate that there is nothing more simple than downing the Reds.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., July 19. -- Navy Patrol Squadron No. 7, comprising six big navy seaplanes, took off from Paradise Cove in San Francisco Bay this morning. Squadron VP-9 still is at rest on the bay and will follow Squadron 7 Saturday morning.
CLEVELAND, July 19. -- Babe Ruth's leg injury was on the mend today -- which means that the Yankees' 40-year-old home run puncher will continue his punching "within a few days."
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

Regarding the American Legion, Katherine Mayo, in her book "Soldiers -- What Next!" has expressed the feeling of many people who have been browbeaten and tormented by that organization for several years. It isn't only through the bonus. The American Legion has a nasty attitude when demanding donations.lll
The New York City Charter Revision Commission at a four-hour session marked by arguments decided last night to retain separate governments for the five boroughs of the city.

LITTLE AMERICA, Antarctica, July 15 (delayed). -- Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, from his isolated outpost 123 miles to the south, re-established radio contact today with Little America after nine days' silence. He reported all was well, but he offered no explanation for the loss of communication.

LONDON, July 19. -- Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, indicated today in the House of Commons that the British Government was slightly and gradually relaxing its embargo on foreign loans.

Both the city and the bankers were partly to blame for the loan fiasco of July 10. The Controller apparently did not expose his wares for sale in the most attractive form. The Mayor was overconfident and thundered too much in the index. The bankers, on the other hand, made a bid for the short-term securities among those offered at that time which was palpably unacceptable.

LONDON, July 19. -- Norman H. Davis, United States Ambassador at large; Rear Admiral Richard H. Leigh, and Commander Wilkinson sailed tonight on the steamship Washington for home after a month's conversations with Acting Prime Minister Baldwin, Sir John Simon, Foreign Minister; Sir Bolton Eyres-Monsell, First Lord of the Admiralty, and other members of the British Cabinet concerning the five-power naval conference scheduled for next year.

Stocks moved with their customary uncertainty yesterday, but they did not wander far from the price levels of the previous afternoon. The combined averages recorded a fractional decline and transactions were about 125,000 shares smaller than on Wednesday.

The National Geographic Society announces that three lakes in the English Lake District are up for public auction. They lie near the western border of the famous district beyond the Derwent Water. Two of them, Crummock and Buttermere, are tied together by the river near whose mouth WORDSWORTH was born.

I witnessed an amazing spectacle one day last week. About 500 people were gathered in Room 624 at 641 Washington Street at 1 o'clock ready to take the final oath and obligation of citizenship. At 2:30 the presiding judge arrived; the clerk ordered the meek multitude to stand and raise their right hands; the oath of allegiance was hastily administered and the multitude was instructed to call later for final papers.

RYE, N.Y., July 19. -- Overcoming the handicap of a 9 on the ninth hole, Mrs. Russell Holman of Innis Arden won low gross honors in the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association tournament on the links of the Apawamis Club today. Her score was 84.
CLEVELAND, July 19 (AP). -- A round-the-world tour by seaplane which started yesterday at Chicago and nearly came to a fiery end here was halted for repairs today.

Half of the residuary estate of Charles S. Keene, retired vice president and director of the American Tobacco Company, appraised yesterday at $2,714,185 gross and $2,669,222 net, goes to Columbia University, while twenty-three other institutions and organizations get bequests.
PARIS, July 19 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

Foreign postcards with cheerful inscriptions have begun to come into Washington from Harry L. Hopkins, director of the Federal Emergency Relief Corporation and similar government activities. He went abroad on a trip which, with his usual candor, he described as "partly business, mostly pleasure."

In the Paris Figaro ANDRE MAUROIS pours gentle irony over the proceedings of an international conference. He describes the general type, not any particular gathering. So intimate are his touches that he must have been present himself at more than one gathering of the kind.

CHICAGO, July 19. -- Sensational reports of the wheat crop in the Canadian Northwest, coupled with heavy local and Eastern buying, created today a strong, bullish sentiment in all grains on the Board of Trade. The cereals advanced into new high grounds for the present upturn, while December wheat and rye reached the highest prices of the season.

A slaughter that would have saddened the heart of Maeterlinck took place yesterday at 535 West 162d Street. Thousands of honey bees, following a queen from New Jersey, Westchester, or Long Island, settled underneath the fire escape on the second floor of the apartment building there.

BROOKHAVEN, L.I., July 19. -- Conrad Michelson, 24 years old, of 1,045 Park Avenue, New York, and Mrs. Marjorie De Meyer, 22, of Niagara Falls, N.Y., were killed this morning when the automobile Michelson was driving turned over on a back road between here and Bellport Station. Henry De Meyer, Mrs. De Meyer's husband, who also was in the car, is in a critical condition.

CHATHAM, Mass., July 19. -- After an involuntary hair of twenty-four hours due to the grounding of their seventy-foot schooner yacht, Rhodos, on a bar off Harding's Beach light, last night, Lawrence Tibbett, the opera singer, his wife and their twin sons, Ivan and Richard, were able to resume their voyage early this evening when the Coast Guard cutter Mojave pulled the yacht into deep water just before high tide.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 19. -- Representatives of the Tennessee Valley Authority, the National Power and Light Company, the Tennessee Public Service Company land the city of Knoxville will gather in Washington or New York tomorrow to draw up a contract to wind up the sale of the private company's properties in East Tennessee to the Authority.

A GENERAL impression of Tibet is that it is one vast Matteawan. This is not entirely unjust. The last country to be discovered by the civilized world has some spectacularly eccentric national characteristics. Forty years' study at the University of Lhasa is necessary to win a first-class degree there. For one of the ordinary degrees one must study twenty years.

BRETTON VOODS, N.H., July 19. -- Mrs. Thomas F. Vietor gave a dinner at Pecketts on Sugar Hill for members of the younger set last evening, as did Mr. and Mrs. Joel S. Coffin Jr. of Iris Farm, Franconia.

CHICAGO, July 19. -- The Yankees had a difficult time in beating the last-place White Sox at Comiskey Park today before 4,000 spectators. But the McCarthymen eked out a 4-to-3 triumph and gained half a game on the league-leading Tigers, who were idle because of rain.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 19. -- The fastest and hardest played of the unofficial practice matches the season has seen yet among the probable candidates for the East team featured the polo today at Westbury, when a team of Reds turned back a team of Whites on Phipps Field, 10 to 5.
WASHINGTON, July 19. -- By conservative estimates American workers already have lost 15,000,000 days this year because of strikes or lockouts -- and all the returns are not in.

TORONTO, July 19 (AP). -- A heavy rainstorm cut short the opening of the Grand Circuit meet at Thorncliffe Park today after Cold Cash, speedy pacer owned by Walter Britenfield of Windsor, Conn., had won the first heat in the featured Royal York Hotel Stake.

Robert Connor, the hardy 21-month-old baby who endured the rigors of the outdoors without food or shelter for five days, showed such improvement yesterday at the White Plains Hospital that his father, Charles H. Connor of Hartsdale Manor, predicted he would soon be restored to normal.

A comprehensive transit handbook, to be issued today by the transit committee of the Citizens Budget Commission, hints at the advisability of unification of rapid transit lines on the basis of a "flexible" or "sliding scale" fare.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 19. -- One point removed from his most notable victory in several years, E.W. Feibleman defaulted to Gregory Mangin of Newark today and the fifth ranking playing player of the country and top-seeded player in the draw was saved in the annual invitation turf court tournament of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 19 (AP). -- A bombardment of base hits in the final innings, including Joe Hauser's second home run of the game, gave Minneapolis a 13-to-6 victory over the American Association All Stars today in a benefit game before 7,435 fans.

I wish I could say something new and striking about the need of more watering stations for work horses in New York. It is a need that has existed for many years, but the situation is acute this Summer because it is so hard to get money. There are at least 35,000 horses toiling under hard conditions.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 19. -- Hope for settlement of the truck drivers' strike without violence increased tonight as the third day of the walkout passed with no disorders.

On the eve of his departure last night for Washington, where he will discuss a $25,000,000 city housing loan with Harold L. Ickes, PWA Administrator, Mayor LaGuardia received a letter from General Hugh S. Johnson praising the local administration for carrying out the principles of the NRA.

Although an important witness in a scheduled General Sessions hold-up trial committed suicide by hanging on Wednesday night in his garage and the defense lawyer sent word he himself had been hurt in an automobile accident, Louis Wasser, Assistant District Attorney, announced yesterday he would insist the trial start before Judge Koenig today.

SEATTLE, July 19. -- Blockade of Seattle's municipal piers at Smith Cove, where non-union loading operations on vessels have been in progress for several weeks, was made effective today by striking maritime workers and sympathizers who held the ground they gained yesterday in a battle with police.

A steady ten-day advance to the highest prices in four years developed a weakened technical position yesterday on the Cotton Exchange and prices broke sharply $2 a bale at one time. Although drought areas received no relief and temperatures in Oklahoma and Arkansas were the highest of the season, a wave of profit-taking caught stop-loss limits and sent the October below 13 cents a pound.
Alfred E. Smith, the strongest political figure ever developed by Tammany Hall, returned yesterday to his old position as the man the organization will consult on major matters of policy.

PARIS, July 19. -- Andre Tardieu's bitter attack on former Premier Camille Chautemps yesterday before the Stavisky inquiry commission has produced a situation that threatens to disrupt Premier Gaston Doumergue's Cabinet of national union.

RYE, N.Y., July 19. -- Finishing with five birdies for a record-breaking 68, Ellis Knowles of the Apawamis Club today captured the medal in the qualifying round of the sixth annual invitation tournament of the Westchester Country Club.

There was little in yesterday's share market to excite comment in Wall Street. About the most that could be said was that prices were declining slowly in a market that was a trifle more active. The usual practice in recent weeks has been for the market to advance on a declining turnover and to fall on a shrinkage in business.
Three children of the late Rodman Wanamaker, department store owner, who died on March 9, 1928, began suit yesterday in United States District Court against trustees of the estate.
ST. LOUIS, July 19 (AP). -- Eight pitchers saw service today as the Browns won their fifth straight game, defeating the Senators, 8 to 7.

Bond prices fluctuated yesterday within narrow ranges in quiet trading on the Stock Exchange. United States Government long-term issues again moved up, closing 5-32 point higher to 3-32 lower. One feature of this group was the new high record touched by the Federal Farm Mortgage Corporation 3 1/4s due in 1964, which at the close were 102 22-32, up 3-32 point on the day.

The reserve balances of member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $85,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to reach a new high record at $3,987,000,000. At this figure the excess of reserves over requirements was about $1,900,000,000, also a new high mark.
BISLEY CAMP, England, July 19 (Canadian Press). -- Canada won the coveted MacKinnon Challenge Cup, one of Bisley's two great imperial team trophies, today.

Laundry owners charged with paying employes less than 31 cents an hour in violation of the State Minimum Fair Wage Act were warned yesterday by the State Labor Department that further non-compliance would be met with court prosecutions following promulgation of a mandatory order by the Industrial Commissioner.

Twenty-two children from the Netherlands, wearing their native costumes, visited yesterday the headquarters of the "New Amsterdam'' school system with gifts of blue Delft miniatures, Holland farm cheese and Dutch dolls for members of the Board of Education.

Mrs. Henry L. Ughetta's Royal Guard scored his third straight victory by capturing the featured race at Empire City yesterday. He led B.L. Squires's favored Carisbrooke home by two lengths, with Mrs. John Galvin's Easy Sailing third.

Whatever her final decision regarding payments on the Dawes and Young bonds, it has at least become plain that by including these bonds in her moratorium Germany has damaged her international credit out of all proportion to the actual amounts involved. The Dawes and Young loans call for interest payments of approximately 126,000,000 marks a year.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 19. -- More boats sailed in the fourth championship regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club's thirty-sixth annual race week today than have ever competed at one time on Long Island Sound before.

BUENOS AIRES, July 19. -- Both Bolivia and Paraguay apparently are preparing for another battle around Fort Ballivian. Both Asuncion and La Paz communiques today report the enemy is preparing for a new offensive.
The Dillingham-Sillman musical revue, New Faces," will close tomorrow night after nineteen weeks at the Fulton Theatre. A road tour is planned.

BERLIN, July 19. -- Prices on the stock market here tended further upward today. Rises of fractions to 2 points or so were made in the most active list. Declines were relatively few and the most marked of them were attributed to realizing sales by professional speculators.

The funeral for Robert J. Sullivan, vice president of the Travelers Insurance Company, who died early yesterday in Bellevue Hospital after he had been struck by an automobile driven by Harold C. Gottfried of Scarsdale, N.Y., at Forty-third Street and Sixth Avenue, will be held in his home city of West Hartford, Conn., probably tomorrow, business associates said yesterday.

The policy of the Federal Government in advancing funds for municipal electric light and power plants is causing serious apprehension among investors. Not only are their present investments threatened but, even more important, financial confidence is being undermined.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP). -- The NRA announced today that the public hearing on a proposed amendment to the Newsprint Manufacturing Code setting up a schedule of minimum prices and a control board would be reopened at the request of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

The board of directors of the American Institute of Steel Construction, Inc., yesterday notified General Hugh S. Johnson, NRA Administrator, that they had voted not to accept his changes in the proposed code for the structural steel and fabricating industry.

The Cunard-White Star liner Olympic will sail tonight for Channel ports. Dr. Blanch Colton Williams of Hunter College; C.L. Andrus, general counsel of the New York, Ontario and Western Railway; Miss Margaret Case, editor of Vogue, and Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Ottinger are among those who will sail on the ship. Other passengers will include:
NEWPORT, R.I., July 19. -- Yankee, the America's Cup yacht, had a race to get an injured man ashore today, and Yankee won.
On a modest amount of business, most of which represented routine requirements, all sections of the money market continued steady and unchanged in quotation.

Brokers' loans, as reported yesterday by local member banks of the Federal Reserve, declined $28,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to a total of $1,031,000,000. The reduction followed a decline of $10,000,000 last week.

The estate of Harry Payne Whitney, capitalist and sportsman, was appraised yesterday by Jacob Manicoff, Deputy Tax Commissioner, at $72,740,838 gross and $62,808,829 net. He owned securities worth $64,155,422, of which $47,462,302 was in stocks and $16,355,119 in bonds, mainly of State, Federal and municipal issues. New York State will collect a tax estimated at $9,513,013.

P.A.S. Franklin, president of the International Mercantile Marine Company, said yesterday that government subsidies to American merchant shipping, soon to be investigated at the order of President Roosevelt, were not excessive in view of the policies of foreign governments with respect to their merchant fleets.

With relays of motor cycle policemen clearing the way, Aaron Sirotowitz of 4,724 Avenue I, Brooklyn, drove his 10-year-old daughter Irene, who had been stricken with acute appendicitis, from Port Jervis, N.Y., to the Jewish Hospital in Brooklyn, a distance of 100 miles, in one hour and fifty minutes yesterday afternoon.

A sharp appreciation in the value of investments permitted the insurance companies in the America Fore group to reduce their contingency reserves from $16,722,613 to $164,113 in the six months ended on June 30. As contingency reserves represent the actual difference between the market value and the convention value of securities in insurance portfolios, an appreciation of at least $16,558,500 in the period is indicated.

ALBANY, July 19. -- Motor vehicle registrations for the first five months of 1934 gained 71,465 over a year ago, Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, reported today. The greatest increase, he said, was in passenger vehicles.

No one can look at the picture of TURNESA sinking his putt at the eighteenth hole without discovering, in a flash of illumination, why unemployment in the United States is proportionately twice as severe as in Great Britain.
BOSTON, July 19 (AP). -- Jerome (Dizzy) Dean, the Cardinals' eccentric but effective hurler, today led his team to a 4-to-2 triumph in the first game of their series with the Braves.

ALBANY, July 19. -- Hamilton F. Potter, the youthful Assemblyman from the Second Assembly District in Suffolk County, is regarded at the Capitol as the first choice of Chairman W. Kingsland Macy of the Republican State Committee for Speaker in the 1935 Assembly.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 19. -- Vivian McGrath of Australia, the wonderboy of the two-handed swipe off the backhand, is the pivotal point in the interzone final round of the Davis Cup competition opening at Wimbledon this Saturday.

BERLIN, July 19. -- The Reich Ministry of the Interior verified today the report that the ousting of special Storm Troop commissars had taken place all over the Reich, and not merely in Bavaria, where official announcement of the dismissal of such commissars had been made.

Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente reserved decision yesterday on an application by the North German Lloyd Steamship Company to dismiss a suit brought in behalf of all eligible bondholders to compel the company to pay through one action the interest on its bonds defaulted on Nov. 1 and May 1 last.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- Elation was high here tonight over the ending of the general strike in San Francisco, and officials who have remained at their desks night and day working on the problem expressed confidence that arbitration would be successful.

That the New York State Conservation Department, headed by Commissioner Lithgow Osborne, is carrying out its promise to improve trout conditions wherever needed is shown by reports received from Roscoe, N.Y., in the Catskills, where 11,600 brown trout fry were planted on Tuesday.

Stronger prices in a number of cotton goods lines brought out fairly substantial orders from dry goods wholesalers this week, they reported yesterday. Slight advances on percales, ginghams and tickings were put into effect, with jobbers covering moderately on other staples, such as sheets and pillowcases and muslins.

RUMSON, N.J., July 19. -- In a one-sided polo match, the opening game in the H.L. Herbert Memorial Cup tournament played today at the Rumson Country Club, the Rumson quartet of Sheldon Prentice of Harvard and the three Balding brothers overwhelmed the Monmouth Country Club, 18 to 7.

While the general strike of 1926 in England was under way Sir JOHN SIMON made a powerful argument in the House of Commons that it was illegal and could be enjoined by the courts. If there was any uncertainty about this it was removed by the Trade Disputes and Trade Unions Act of 1927.

BERLIN, July 19. -- Dr. Oscar Staebel, leader of the Reich students' organization, and Ernst Zaeringer, leader of the German Studenthood, have retired. In their place Bernhard Rust, the Minister of Education, has appointed Andreas Feikert, a political science student, who will combine the leadership of both offices.

The University Settlement today will begin milking a sound film depicting the drama of everyday life on the East Side and the. part which the settlement plays, particularly in providing children with an environment to combat the influence of the streets.

Yustin Sirutis of Brooklyn scored a knockout triumph over Eddie Karolak of Schenectady in the scheduled ten-round feature last night at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation in Brooklyn before 7,000 fans, the largest number to see a boxing show there this season.

LONDON, July 19. -- Adaptation of the ratio principle of limitation provided for in the Washington and London naval treaties to European land and air forces will be suggested it was stated authoritatively today, at the September meeting of the disarmament conference steering committee at Geneva.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- Creation of a unified air force (one of the most hotly contested questions in American aeronautical policy) is opposed in the report just made to Secretary Dern by the special aviation committee headed by Newton D. Baker.
GREAT NECK, L.I., July 19. -- There ought to be a great vogue for one-handed putting after Joe Turnesa's great success at the Lakeville Club this week.

BALBOA, July 19. -- An order permitting the transportation and possession of alcoholic liquors in the Canal Zone, effective tomorrow, was issued this afternoon by Secretary of War Dern, acting by authority of the President under the provisions of the Lea act of June 19.

The special committee of seven brokers who were appointed last week by Richard Whitney, president of the New York Stock Exchange, to investigate the foreign business of firms which are members of the Exchange sent yesterday a questionnaire to members as the first move in their survey.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 19 (AP). -- They took the wraps off Wimbledon's famous centre court today to permit American and Australian players to get in several hours of practice on the site of the Davis Cup interzone matches starting Saturday.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 19 (AP). -- A trusty convict guard was indicted today for first-degree murder and the prison official who accompanied him was indicted as an accessory before the fact in the killing of Helen Spence Eaton, escaped convict, July 11.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 19. -- General Johnson, NRA Administrator and special representative and spokesman for President Roosevelt's National Longshoremen's Board here, made this statement tonight:
NEWARK, N.J., July 19. -- Newark lost a golden opportunity to gain on Rochester tonight and its lead was still a game and a half after a 7-to-4 setback at the hands of the tail-end Baltimore Orioles.

HUNTSVILLE, Ala., July 19 (AP). -- Three persons were wounded in disorders at Decatur today in Alabama's three-day-old textile strike, which union officials claim has called more than 20,000 men from their looms.

BISMARCK, N.D., July 19. -- Ole H. Olson, sturdy, gray-haired farmer of New Rockford, took possession of the Executive chambers in the State Capitol this morning and assumed the office of Acting Governor.
WASHINGTON, July 19. -- Creation of a new section in the Bureau of Air Commerce charged solely with developing safer flying equipment was announced today by Eugene L. Vidal, director.

Police Commissioner O'Ryan announced yesterday the awarding twenty-two Police Department medals for "extraordinary heroism at imminent risk of life." In announcing the annual awards, covered by every member of the force, Mr. O'Ryan said he was pleased with the general conduct of the men since he took command.

QUEBEC, July 19 (AP). -- Prime Minister J. Ramsay MacDonald of Great Britain started a "roving vacation" in Canada today. He arrived here on the Duchess of Richmond and was accompanied by his daughter, Ishbel, and Inspector Allum of Scotland Yard.

Generally favorable results for June, the first month of the Police Department's six months' intensive program to reduce street traffic accidents were announced yesterday by Police Commissioner O'Ryan. New York, he said, has moved to second place from fourth in the nation-wide, big-city record compiled by the National Safety Council.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- Loans of $1,177,135,106.20 were disbursed by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation during the fiscal year ended June 30 and exceeded repayments of $931,340,827.93 by only $245,794,278.27, Chairman Jones announced today.

The record of business conditions in Canada during the second quarter of this year was one of moderate sustained improvement, says the Bank of Nova Scotia in its monthly review for July. The index of industrial production, after a slight reaction, has turned upward once more; the indices of general industrial employment and revenue carloadings have maintained previous gains, while the index of the rate of turnover of bank deposits advanced substantially lately.
ICharles Diaz of the 'West Side i Y. M. C. A. knocked out Sam Meadows, unattached, in the 13S-pound class final at the amateur boxing tournament of the Grand Street Boys Association last night.

LONDON, July 19. -- The increase in the British air force under the government's new armament policy will be forty-one new squadrons. This figure was stated by Acting Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin in the House of Commons today. It means 460 new fighting planes, the construction of which will be spread over five years beginning immediately.

An all-Russian program brought an audience of 8,000 persons to the Lewisohn Stadium last night. Eugene Ormandy conducted the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in Liadoff's Eight Russian Folk Songs, Stravinsky's "Fire-Bird" Suite, Gliere's "Dance of Russian Sailors" and Tchaikovsky's Fifth Symphony.

Boy fishermen found the body of Willie Shapiro, 24 year old, of 1,845 Sterling Place, Brooklyn, buried in a sandpit last night in the marshes of Canarsie, about 100 feet from Fresh Creek, between Flatlands and Conklin Avenues.

BRIDGETON, N.J., July 19. -- A general defense plan, including a cooperative group of "minute men," has been organized by Southern New Jersey farmers and canners to cope with the threatened strike of farm and cannery workers and truck drivers.

Bank clearings gained, for the third successive week, over the preceding week, but the total is still under a year ago, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Clearings at twenty-two leading cities in the week ended on Wednesday amounted to 85,163,387,000, against $5,584,276,000 last year, a decline of 7.5 per cent.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended July 18, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,471,000,000, an increase of $3,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $275,000, 000 compared with the corresponding week in 1933.

Herbert Myers, alias Brooks, alias Davis, whose picture appears on a postoffice circular over the legend "wanted for major crimes, such as robberies of United States mails and murder," found it hard going after his arrival in New York five weeks ago.

A fire, the smoke from which was seen from elevated sections throughout Brooklyn and from lower Manhattan, St. George and Bayonne, last night destroyed Pier B, a 400-foot wooden structure at the foot of Richards Street in the Erie Basin, Brooklyn.

Speaking over a nation-wide radio hook-up last night, Mayor Angelo J. Rossi of San Francisco thanked the leaders of organized labor for their efforts to end the general strike and said that he would "deal effectively with a small group who opposed peace and plotted revolution."
WASHINGTON, July 19. -- Government refunding issues, totaling possibly more than $1,000,000,000, are expected on Sept. 15, provided there is no substantial change in the bond market.

The State of Illinois will offer a new issue of $5,000,000 of notes for award on July 31, according to an announcement made yesterday. The issue will bear interest of 5 per cent, will be dated Aug. 2, and will be redeemable not earlier than Dec. 1.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- Wholesale commodity prices dropped slightly again during the week ended July 14, Commissioner Lubin of the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The index for the week based on 1926 averages was 74.5 from 74.7 the previous week.

The executive committee of the Associated Marine Workers; an organization composed of about 3,000 men working on towboats in New York Harbor, last night voted to submit to its membership on Sunday, July 29, a proposal to strike.

The first public offering of New York City long-term bonds since 1931 met with instant success yesterday, when the syndicate books on the $58,000,000 issue of bonds were closed in less than an hour with heavy oversubscriptions. Insurance companies, trust funds, corporations and individuals were heavy buyers, according to the Chase National Bank, which headed the banking group.

NORTHPORT, L.I., July 19. -- In a thirty-five-foot sloop two men and a woman more than 50 years old -- the mother of one of the men -- sailed out of Northport early this morning bound for Morocco, North Africa.

CALCUTTA, July 19. -- It is confirmed that Maurice Wilson, a former British Army captain and a member of the London Aero Club, attempted to climb Mount Everest alone and perished, his porters estimated, at an altitude of about 23,000 feet, about 6,000 feet from the summit.

The gram of radium received by the late Mme. Marie Curie as a gift of the Women of America was deeded last March 25 to the University of Paris, according to word received here yesterday by Mrs. William Brown Meloney, founder and chairman of the Marie Curie Radium Fund.

MUNICH, July 19. -- The recent warning of Viktor Lutze, chief of staff of the Storm Troops, to would be informers -- in which he mentioned that plotters within the party were already being dealt with -- has led to the disclosure that since the Cabinet meeting in Berlin July 4 there has existed a Nazi court-martial.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 19. -- Mr. and Mrs. George Barton French gave a reception this afternoon at Darena, their place in Ox Pasture Road, for Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Hamilton Tyng. Receiving with the host and hostess was Mrs. Lawrence Dilworth, who has joined Mr. and Mrs. French for a visit. During the afternoon tea was served, At the tea table was Mrs. Patrick A. Valentine.

Eddie Guerra of the Unionport A.C. scored a two-round knockout victory over Frank Fleming, German-American A.C., in the 147-pound special bout that featured the card of amateur boxing contests at Starlight Park last night.
Support of the church campaign against objectionable motion pictures was announced yesterday by the Emergency Council of Fraternal Organizations in the U.S.A., with headquarters at 150 Nassau Street.

CHICAGO, July 19. -- A weaker tone prevailed today in the market here for hogs, although prices were at about the same level as yesterday or a shade lower. The top for butcher hogs was $4.95 a hundred pounds, the same as yesterday, and the average was $4.65, also unchanged.

CHICAGO, July 19. -- Faced with the problem of obtaining additional revenues to meet expenses estimated at $360,000,000 annually, which were recently imposed, chief traffic executives of the nation's railroads met here today to discuss means of increasing income.
The Annalist issued yesterday its index of wholesale commodity prices for the week ended on Wednesday and also its report of industrial activity for the first half of this year.

PITTSBURGH, July 19 (AP). -- Invaders from as far West as Kansas City and as far East as New York shoved native sons into temporary retreat today in the first thirty-six holes of the Pennsylvania open golf championship at Oakmont, grabbing six of the first eight positions.
PHILADELPHIA, July 19 (AP). -- Four-hit hurling in which Pat Malone and Lon Warneke collaborated gave the Cubs a 2-to-1 victory over the Phillies today.

The appraisers set a total valuation of $4,075,270 on Mr. Whitney's real estate in New York State. The major part of this sum was represented by two properties, his town house on Fifth Avenue and the extensive estate and stables at Old Westbury, L.I.
Another heat wave arrived in the city yesterday, sending the temperature to 88 and bringing a promise of continuing warm weather today.

HAVANA, July 19. -- In an effort to solve the Cabinet crisis which has greatly shaken the government, representatives of the Liberal Republican party, headed by Dr. Miguel Mariano Gomez, Mayor of Havana, this afternoon presented various demands to President Carlos Mendieta.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP). -- The motion picture industry, even while suffering a loss of $19,589,393 last year, was shown today to have given 110 persons larger salaries in 1933 than that received by President Roosevelt.

The commander-in-chief of the city's perpetual war on mosquitos, Health Commissioner John L. Rice, visited a part of the far-flung battle line yesterday. On a tour of the trenches, which are the drainage ditches criss-crossing the salt and fresh water marshes, he was accompanied by Russell W. Gies, the departmental sanitary engineer who directs mosquito control, and other officers.

By a vote of 3 to 2 the Appellate Division decided yesterday that Timothy J. Mara, sports promoter, and Patrick F. Kenny, Yonkers contractor, must pay notes for $50,000 and $20,000 made to the County Trust Company in 1928 for contributions to the Smith Presidential campaign.

PORTLAND, Ore., July 19. -- Governor Eugene L. Meier today ordered a regiment of the National Guard to mobilize for riot duty and was immediately answered by a threat of a general strike should the militia move to the waterfront here.
ALBANY, July 19. -- Governor Lehman is expected to open the way for action at the special session of the Legislature on at least three new questions:

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., July 19. -i Fire of undetermined origin early this afternoon, which was believed to have started in the H. R. Jones Varnish Works, West Eighth and' Monroe Streets, caused an estimated damage of $100,000.

A rise of nearly a cent in the German mark to 39.50 cents, the highest price since May 23, was the feature of yesterday's dealings in the foreign exchange market. Like most recent movements of the mark, this advance had its origin abroad.

The receiver of the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company was authorized yesterday by Federal Judge William Bondy to settle for $2,866,950 with ten of the twenty member banks of the New York Clearing House Association, who are all being sued by the government to make good the losses of the Harriman depositors.

WORD comes from Chicago and Woodsfield, Ohio, that Pitcher Samuel Pond Jones will be 42 years old on July 26, on which occasion there will be a Sam Jones Day at Comiskey Park. Sam will celebrate not only his birthday but the twentieth anniversary of his arrival in the big league.

Loans of about $70,000,000 to the American and Foreign Power Company, a subsidiary of the Electric Bond and Share Company, have been extended for one year, it was announced yesterday by C.E. Calder, president of the subsidiary.

Jack Mahoney and Bernard Freedman, seeded first and second, respectively, both were eliminated, as play in the Eastern junior singles tennis championship entered the final round at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills yesterday. Mahoney was defeated by Jack Behr, Roxbury school star, 6 -- 4, 7 -- 5, while Freedman lost to Gerard Podesta of Montclair, N.J., 6 -- 4, 6 -- 0.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 19. -There was a large attendance of the Summer colony tonight at Chateau Sur Mer, home of the Misses Wetmore, for the first of a series of three evenings of chamber music arranged by Mrs. Lewis A. Armistead.

ABOARD CRUISER NEW ORLEANS, ACCOMPANYING PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT, July 19 (AP). -- The navy dirigible Macon made contact with the cruiser Houston, carrying President Roosevelt to Hawaii, 1,200 miles off the Pacific Coast today.

A score of properties were listed for sale at foreclosure in Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday. Fifteen of the parcels are in the former borough and all save one were struck down to the plaintiffs. .ale of one parcel was adjourned.

A series of "new and cheaper editions of good books," carrying the general title "The Albabooks," will be started on Aug. 13 by Alfred A. Knopf, according to announcement yesterday. The books will be issued in a uniform binding designed by W.A. Dwiggins and will be priced at $2.50 each.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 20. -- Frank Parker's initial grass court venture of the year came to grief on the turf of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club today.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- "Fullest cooperation" with the administration's huge housing program, which would free local credit for improvement to millions of American homes, was pledged to Administrator Moffett today by manufacturing, railroad and labor leaders of the country.

Retail collections on charge accounts in June registered a gain of 3.28 per cent, according to the index of twenty local key stores issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York, Inc. This increase is the fourteenth consecutive monthly gain and compares with rises of 3.98 per cent in May and 2.72 per cent in June of last year.

ROME, July 20 (AP). -- Italy's power in Africa will be substantially enhanced through land concessions she received today from Britain and Egypt. And in addition to a piece of territory in the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan, the territory of Tibesti in the Sahara will be ceded to Premier Mussolini's government by the French, well-informed circles said today.

Yesterday afternoon, the temperature being roughly about 120 and the humidity, from the feel of the thing, about 250, it was a relief to know that not all humanity was suffering. "Jersey is Cool to Candidates," said The Sun over a Trenton story about the very small crowd for the first Governor's Day at the Summer capital at Sea Girt.

PITTSBURGH, July 20 (AP). Willie Macfarlane, representing the Oak Ridge Country Club of Tuckahoe, N.Y., won the annual Pennsylvania State open golf championship today with a seventy-two-hole aggregate of 294, four strokes below the all-time record for the Oakmont Country Club course.
CINCINNATI, July 20 (AP). -- The reign of the flapper is over, Dr. Ernest L. Talbert, University of Cincinnati psychologist, said today, and the nation is going conservative.

BRIDGETON, N.J., July 20. -- While police were investigating the cause of a fire today in two barracks of the Seabrook Farms which caused damage estimated at $8,000 another blaze tonight destroyed a large warehouse containing 35,000 fruit crates on the farm property.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 20. -- Joining the organized labor return to conservative leadership here, the powerful Teamsters Union voted 4 to 1 tonight to go back to work unconditionally. The vote, by secret ballot, was 1,138 to 283 in favor of the following resolution:...
Several small flats and various dwellings were among the New Jersey properties reported sold yesterday.

BERLIN, July 20. -- Dr. Hugo Eckener announced today that the crude oil motors to be installed in the new Zeppelin LZ-129 had proved a complete success. The mammoth airship will be ready for her maiden flight in five or six months.

PORTLAND, Ore., July 20. -- The mobilization of Oregon National Guard troops, eneamped within eight miles of the waterfront zone, afforded protection today for the partial opening of the port of Portland to commerce after seventy-three days of stagnation and idleness.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 20. -- Fog covered the sea off here today and the planned race between the America's Cup yachts, Yankee and Rainbow, had to be given up.

Offerings of new bonds and notes this week, aggregating $127,800,000, made the heaviest weekly total in a month. Last week new bonds in the amount of $38,355,000 were marketed, and this week a year ago new financing amounting to $2,902,000 was done.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 20. -- One of the largest fashion shows ever held in this section, benefiting Spring Lake Hospital, attracted 1,500 today to Ross Fenton Farms. Two hundred gowns used were auctioned later by Rex Reynolds of Ross Fenton Farms.

When the automobile show opens here in January, for the first time arranged by dealers instead of manufacturers, it will not have the competition of private showings in hotels and other places by individual companies, it became known yesterday.

LONDON, July 20. -- There were several bright features on the Stock Exchange here today, but business was at a low ebb. British government stocks again advanced on a fair amount of investment support.

CEDARHURST, L.I., July 20. -- The Yale Club of New York retired the second Adee-Parker Trophy by defeating the Harvard Club of New York in their annual baseball game at the Rockaway Hunting Club today, 5 to 3.

RYE, N.Y., July 20. -- A return match between Richard D. Chapman, newly-crowned Westchester champion, and Willie Turnesa, whom he defeated for the district crown earlier in the year, will feature the semi-final round of the Westchester Country Club's annual invitation tournament tomorrow.

An international exhibition of fine and applied arts by deaf artists of twelve nations will open this afternoon at 4 o'clock in the galleries of the Roerich Museum. 310 Riverside Drive. It will continue until Aug. 11 and is being held in conjunction with the seventeenth triennial convention of the National Association of the Deaf, as well as in cooperation with the International Art Centre of Roerich Museum.

Only a small amount of new municipal financing is scheduled to be done next week. It is $6,786,700, compared with this week's revised total of $20,042,900, and with the weekly average for the year thus far of $21,687,727. In other years also new financing in July and August usually has been light.
SEATTLE, Wash., July 20. -- Led by Mayor Charles L. Smith, a former football player, 300 policemen today drove 2,000 dock strike pickets from the Municipal Piers at Smith's Cove.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., July 20. -- Miss Maureen Orcutt, metropolitan, Eastern and New Jersey State women's golf champion, today scored a 76, establishing a competitive course record for the centre and west nines of the Ridgewood Country Club, to win the women's New Jersey Golf Association one-day tournament.

r n a move to aid corporations in keeping a closer record of their stockholders for meeting and dividend purposes, the Stock Exchange has asked all its members to transfer stock certificates to their own names or those of accounts over which they have control whenever possible. The notice sent members yesterday reads:
PRAGUE, July 20. -- Details of the killing of the poet Erich Muehsam in a German concentration camp were given tonight by his widow, who has just reached Prague from Germany.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 20. -- C.E. Grey Jr.'s Interclub Vision Jr. was dismasted and W.P. O'Connor Jr.'s Atlantic Class sloop Alibi had her mainsail blown out as a squall followed by a heavy shower cracked down on the yachts sailing in the fifth championship regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club's race week today.

Recommendations for reform and improvement of the administration of criminal law in the United States were made by the committee on criminal courts of the New York County Lawyers Association in a report issued yesterday.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations, including processing tax, on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

The golden jubilee number of Editor Publisher, appearing as section two of the regular issue today, views the journalistic scene in half-century retrospection and sees the future newspaper as a more exacting instrument which will play more importantly on the intelligence and conscience of its readers.

Negotiations for rapid transit unification are being conducted by the LaGuardia administration "so as to insure the continued maintenance of the five-cent fare," according to a statement issued yesterday by Samuel Seabury, special counsel for the Board of Estimate in transit matters.

In an effort to obtain united insistence upon a governmental survey of salt-water problems, two meetings have been arranged in New York and New Jersey by the Salt Water Anglers of America, of which Mrs. Oliver C. Grinnell, famous big game angler, is president.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 20. -- Miles Dunne, principal leader of striking truck drivers, tonight asked for a general strike as Governor Floyd B. Olson issued a statement blaming a broken truce for the violence which inflicted injuries and shotgun wounds on sixty-eight persons today.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP). -- Within six weeks the new Communications Commission expects to have the groundwork laid for its study into the reasonableness of telephone rates.

An effort to enlist church support, on a national scale, for a plan which would subject the motion picture industry to permanent control by a supervising committee will be started here next week, it was announced yesterday.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 20 (AP). -- After Uncle Sam's four Davis Cup players held a final rehearsal today on Wimbledon's historic centre court, where they will open tomorrow against Australia for the right to challenge the cup-holding English team, Captain R. Norris (Dick) Williams, the squad leader, spoke confidently and enthusiastically of the Americans' prospects.

SOUTHAMPTON. L.I., July 30. -- Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edward Merrill gave a dinner, followed by bridge, tonight at The Orchard, their place in Hill Street, for Mrs. Randolph Turnbull of Jacksonville, Fla.. who has joined them for a visit.

LONDON, July 20 (AP). -- New charges of misconduct during recent months were made today against Douglas Fairbanks Sr. and Lady Sylvia Ashley on behalf of Lord Ashley, who is suing for a divorce from his former chorus girl wife.

The picture in THE TIMES taken of the Dutch school children who have come "for a two weeks' whirlwind conquest of the city" rustles the pages of history and shakes forgotten dusty souvenirs. Rightly do they come as conquerors. Rightly may they glory in their Dutch spirit, Dutch courage and Dutch foresight that built so well upon a strange and unexplored island the foundations of a great city.

LONDON, July 20 (AP). -- A band of American college athletes, hoping to stem the tide of sports supremacy that has swept toward England in recent weeks, completed training today preparatory to an engagement with the combined track and field forces of Oxford and Cambridge Universities tomorrow in the White City Stadium.

Several promotions and three transfers were announced yesterday by Police Commissioner John F. O'Ryan. Inspector Joseph Reynolds, formerly in command of the Fourth Division, on the upper East Side, was made a deputy chief inspector and placed in charge of the uniformed force of the Bronx.

Housing properties formed the bulk of real estate offered at foreclosure sales in Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday. Auctioneers put up nine parcels in the former borough and eight in the latter. All but one of the seventeen properties were bought in by the plaintiffs, who atced to protect their mortgage investments.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

BOSTON, July 20 (AP). -- A home run by Wally Berger saved the Boston Braves from a shutout at the hands of the St. Louis Cardinals today as they dropped their second game of the current series, 5 to 1.

John Wexley, playwright, who recently became affiliated with the Columbia Pictures writing staff, will prepare the screen script of Percy S. Mandley's play, "Eight Bells," in which Jack Holt and John Buckler will appear.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- The number of families and single persons receiving Federal relief dropped 2 per cent and relief expenditures 4 per cent during May and June, according to reports from 143 cities and urban counties announced today by Aubrey Williams, Acting Relief Administrator.

ST. LOUIS, July 20 (AP). -- Winning their second consecutive game from the Senators, and their sixth straight, the Browns today defeated Washington, 7 to 4, and advanced to fifth place in the American League standings.

MANCHESTER, Mass., July 20 (AP). -- Due more to the fortunes of the draw than to any other cause, the Essex County women's invitation tennis tournament narrowed down to its third East-West final in its ten-year history today when the top-seeded Mrs. Marjorie Mor rill Painter of Dedham entered the last round with a 7-5, 6-1 victory over Miss Norma Taubele of New York, the national indoor champion.

The Regional Labor Board acted yesterday to prevent a strike of employes of ship lines serving this port after the Seafearers Council of the Port of New York reported that the ship lines were unwilling to confer with its representatives on its demands for a new contract covering hours and working conditions.

Following a conference in Washington yesterday with PWA Administrator Harold L. Ickes, Mayor LaGuardia said New York City could borrow up to $100,000,000 of PWA funds to finance its local improvements.

BATON ROUGE, La., July 20. -- Twenty-four hours after a conference with Senator Huey P. Long, Governor O.K. Allen today threatened city officials of New Orleans with prosecution and removal from office unless they acted to rid the city of gambling, vice and "other crimes."

In a series of articles on housing appearing in The Annalist, Mr. W.R. INGALLS estimates that about 500,000 more units a year are required in this country merely to house the annual increase in population. Applying this estimate to the actual building in the ten years from 1920 to 1929, his calculations show a total of 5,058,000 dwelling units erected in that decade.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in this State, now offered by dealers:

LONDON, July 20. -- The Hitler government's first concession to the 60,000 German exiles in other countries was announced today by James G. McDonald, the League of Nation's High Commissioner for Refugees.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- Despite seasonal recessions, the general business situation in Canada "is definitely better as a result of the improved outlook in agriculture consequent upon the breaking of the drought in many areas," the Department of Commerce reported today in its weekly survey of foreign business.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP). -- The Securities and Exchange Commission intends to use moderation in exercising its powers over corporation accounting, powers which critics have said involved unusual authority to regulate business.

Prices on the Stock Exchange slipped further yesterday and with no more logical explanation than has been offered for other contradictory movements of the recent past. The news developments of the day were generally encouraging, but the share market chose to ignore them.

The Northeastern Group of Presidents and Secretaries of State Farm Bureaus requested President Roosevelt yesterday "to act immediately in increasing the price of gold to $41.34 per ounce, the maximum price permitted by law."

DIGBY, N.S., July 20. -- A famous native of Lossiemouth, Scotland, J. Ramsay MacDonald, Prime Minister of Great Britain, arrived here today for a holiday, during which he plans to get acquainted with those parts of Nova Scotia, the New Scotland, that are predominantly Scottish.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended July 14 totaled 344,187,000 barrels, an increase of 95,000 barrels over the total of 344,092,000 barrels on hand at the end of the preceding week.

Staging a gallant uphill battle, Jack Behr, Roxbury School star, came from behind and defeated Gerard B. Podesta of Montclair, N.J., in the final of the junior Eastern singles tennis championship at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, yesterday.

All surface developments yesterday were considered in Wall Street to be favorable to the advance on the Stock Exchange, but the market was in one of its perverse moods and prices fell. The combined averages were down 1.98 points on the day; the industrial group declined 2.57, and the rails 1.39.

CHICAGO, July 20. -- All steam locomotive records for speed, maintained over a distance of fifty miles or more, were broken today by a regular passenger train of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad between Chicago and Milwaukee.

BERLIN, July 20. -- The annual Wagner festival at Baireuth, opening on Sunday, will be notable this year for the attendance of Chancellor Adolf Hitler with several members of his Cabinet and some of the higher officers of the National Socialist party.

The steadily increasing volume of newspaper advertising in the last twelve months strongly indicates that the national recovery is a permanent and not a temporary movement, in the opinion of James M. Mathes, advertising authority.

HALIFAX, July 20 (Canadian Press). -- A Halifax newspaper woman sat down to the telephone today to interview the Prime Minister of Great Britain by long distance: "I'd like to talk to Mr. Ramsay MacDonald," she said after being connected with his cottage at Digby, N.S.

Arrangements for the famous D'Oyly Carte Opera Company of the Savoy Theatre, London, to present Gilbert and Sullivan operas at the Martin Beck Theatre, starting Monday, Sept. 3, have been completed by Martin Beck, the producer.

LONDON, July 20. -- While the government was announcing its five-year plan to add nearly 500 war planes to the Air Force, it was revealed in The Daily Express that the Imperial Airways was arranging a direct regular passenger service across the Atlantic.

MANORVILLE, Pa., July 20. -- L.H. Samuels's fifty striking mirror makers today rejected his unusual proposal that they take over the management of his plant, but indicated that they would return to work Monday.
CLEVELAND, July 20 (AP). -- The Indians stretched their winning streak to four games today and climbed into third place in the league standing by defeating the Red Sox, 5 to 3.
NEWARK, N.J., July 20. -- Vito Tamulis weakened in the tenth inning after nine scoreless frames today and Newark lost the final game of its series to the Baltimore Orioles, 3 to 2.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 20. -- Admiral Joseph Mason Reeves, Commander-in-Chief of the United States Fleet, was an honor guest early this afternoon at a luncheon given by Mr. and Mrs. Eugene S. Newbold of Philadelphia, Summer residents of Jamestown, at the Beavertail Golf Club. There were fifty guests present.

LOS ANGELES, July 20. -- With the declaration that the general strike in San Francisco was "the most critical moment in recent history" and that it was "dictatorship, tyranny, minority rule," General Hugh S. Johnson, NRA Administrator, disclosed today what he said was the "inside story" of the widespread walkout of union workers.

RYE, N.Y., July 20. -- A large assemblage of Westchester society attended the opening of the fourth annual horse show of the Westchester Country Club here today on the polo field of the clubhouse. It will be continued tomorrow and Sunday.

MANY men in many lands have wondered what was "good" about the new Germany. Economically it has been no success, it has hardly been a good neighbor, and its internal policies have been pretty messy. Now comes Darwin L. Teilhet with an answer. As a set-up for a mystery-adventure novel the reborn land seems to have reached nearest toward perfection.

Barring the activity in the commercial paper section of the money market, where bills are moving as quickly as they come in, there was little else of significance in the day's trading. Stock Exchange call loans, maturity money and acceptances were dull and unchanged in quotation.
It is a matter of fact and record that in all the wide realm of sport a chronic loser can never receive a break, unless it is another bad one.

BISLEY CAMP, England, July 20 (Canadian Press) -- Sharpshooting Canadians today added the historic Kolapore Challenge Cup to the MacKinnon Cup, making a clean sweep in the two great team trophies of the Imperial meeting of the National Rifle Association.

VIRGIL tells in the most beautiful of the Georgics of an old Corycian who had a few acres of unclaimed land that was not rich enough for the plow, was unfitted for the grazing of sheep and was unkind to the vine. Yet did he match in contentment the wealth of kings.

PARIS, July 20. -- France's political crisis has been postponed, for for how long it cannot be certain. At least an effort is being made to let the anger subside that was aroused by Andre Tardieu's flaming accusations against Camille Chautemps and indirectly against the Radical Socialist party and its Cabinet members.

For seventeen years -- ever since he escaped from Clinton Prison, Dannemora, N.Y., where he was serving from five to nine years on a grand larceny conviction -- Michael Lobracio lived within two blocks of Police Headquarters at 171 Spring Street, coming and going as he pleased with his bootblacks' box.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 20. -- The week-end of the annual men's invitation tennis tournament at the Maldstone Club is bringing an unusual number of visitors.

ll-feeling growing out of bankruptcy litigation led to a physical attack yesterday by one lawyer upon another outside the office of Robert P. Stephenson, Federal referee in bankruptcy, on the seventeenth floor of 29 Broadway. In the encounter Tobias A. Keppler, 55 years old, who has an office at 25 West Forty-third Street, received serious injuries. He was taken to Broad Street Hospital.

CHICAGO, July 20. -- The plan for liquidation of the American Bond and Mortgage Company was approved today by Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson. It provides that a new corporation, known as the American Bond and Mortgage Liquidation Corporation, is to be formed. It will have capital stock of $50,000, which will be held in trust.

PARIS, July 20. -- A unanimous chorus of praise and delight has come today from the press and political circles over the announcement by Stanley Baldwin, Acting Prime Minister, of Britain's proposed increase in her air power.

The Newtown Creek Coal and Coke Company, 197 West Street, Brooklyn, one of the largest independent retail coal dealers in the city, defying the NRA, announced yesterday that it would stand on its constitutional rights in refusing to abide by the prices fixed by the NRA Retail Solid Fuel Authority.

The Grand Duchess Marie of Russia, Irving Berlin, Countess Elise de Fondeville, Mr. and Mrs. Richard P. Lydon and Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Sturm are among the passengers leaving today for Mediterranean ports on the Italian liner Rex.
Sale of a house abutting the St. Ignatius School in Yorkville and the leasing of buildings in scattered sections of Manhattan featured realty activity in the city yesterday.
