J.L. Barry's letter regarding compulsory automobile liability insurance misses entirely the object of this insurance. It is not to make drivers more or less careless, but merely to provide the only possible compensation for negligent injury -- namely, money damages.

CRILLON LAKE, Alaska, July 20 (by Radio) -- The Mount Crillon expedition's first major objective was achieved with complete success when the writer, Richard Goldthwait and Pilot Gene Meyring, of Alaska Southern Airways, made the first flight in history over the entire Malaspina Glacier, one of the largest coastal glaciers in the world.

A basis for a settlement of the controversy between the City Controller and stockbrokers over the city's new tax of one-tenth of 1 per cent on the gross income of a financial business was submitted yesterday by William Reid, City Collector, to Raoul E. Desvernine, counsel for the Association of Stock Exchange Firms.
Attractions scheduled to end their Broadway engagements this evening are "Roberta," at the New Amsterdam Theatre, and "New Faces," at the Fulton.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP). -- The cotton spinning industry was reported today by the Census Bureau to have operated during June at 72.7 per cent capacity, on a single shift basis, compared with 98.2 per cent in May this year and 129.1 per cent in June last year.

CHICAGO, July 20. -- A rush of buying of all grains at the opening based largely on poor crop reports from the most important sections in Canada and the American Northwest, carried prices of wheat to new high levels, while other grains advanced in sympathy. Profit-taking by local and outside holders was too heavy for the buying support, however, and sharp price recessions resulted.

BERLIN, July 20. -- The film chamber created last year, with wide powers over the industry, has drawn up a new set of regulations intended to force exhibitors to place so-called culture films in their programs. Measures are also to be taken to reduce the number of films produced and to obtain higher quality in the productions.

Members of the Charter Revision Commission saw yesterday little hope of reversal of the verdict by which the commission decided to retain provision for separate governments for the five boroughs of the city in the new charter which it is proposed to submit to the voters of the city.

BRUSSELS, July 20. -- The Belgian Parliament today adopted the so-called special powers bill which gives the government virtually a free hand in tax reform and in the regulation of financial and economic affairs until next Fall.

United States Government long-term issues, which accounted for 30 per cent of the dealings in bonds yesterday on the Stock Exchange were generally higher, closing up 4-32 to down 2-32 point. Foreign loans, with the exception of German issues, pointed higher.

CHICAGO, July 20. -- Hogs sold at $5 a hundredweight early today but the market declined 10 to 15 cents. The day's average was $4.55, a drop of 10 cents from yesterday, when the top was $4.95. Most sales today were at $4.70 to $4.85. Five packers bought 2,900 hogs; city butchers, 2,500, and shippers, 2,500.

The preliminary report of the Atlantic Refining Company and subsidiaries for the six months ended June 30, issued yesterday, shows a net profit of $2,990,000 after interest, depreciation, depletion, taxes and other charges. This is equivalent to $1.12 a share on 2,665,904 shares of $25 par common stock.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 20. -- About fifty persons were wounded by bullets and twenty others were injured by beatings when police opened fire in a battle with striking truck drivers near the market section here today. The fight started as pickets attempted to halt a wholesale grocery truck moving under guard from the area.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., July 20. -- Mortimer Auerbach, driving under the colors of the Columbia Yacht Club of Chicago, made a successful start in the defense of his national 125 cubic-inch hydroplane title today, winning the opening ten-mile heat of the championship series with Emancipator III.

BUENOS AIRES, July 20. -- Mischa Elman's "Tango" almost caused a riot at Rosario Wednesday night. The violinist played his first concert in Argentina's second largest city before an audience that cheered and shouted.

BERLIN, July 20. -- Chancellor Hitler is out of Berlin today and his whereabouts is unknown. He may have joined General Werner von Blomberg. Defense Minister, who left Copenhagen yesterday on the naval tender Hela and is cruising in the Cattegat, or he may have flown to Berchtesgaden, Bavaria, for a brief rest before appearing at Baireuth Sunday for the opening of the festival.

Having received information that the officials of The Long Island Press of Jamaica were continuing efforts to discourage its editorial employees from membership in the Newspaper Guild of New York, the guild in a general meeting last night at the Hotel Astor protested to Mayor LaGuardia that the agreement signed by S.I. New house, publisher, and officers of the guild in the Mayor's office last Saturday was being violated.

Declines were the rule yesterday on local commodity futures exchanges, reflecting the weakness of stocks, cotton and wheat, but sugar was somewhat higher and metals were mixed in tone. In the cash markets raw sugar and lead advanced, while declines appeared in wheat, corn, rye, coffee, cocoa, lard, cotton and rubber.
BERLIN, July 20. -- Speaking in Halle, General Hermann Wilhelm Goering, Premier of Prussia, tonight reasserted in almost religious phraseology his absolute loyalty to Chancellor Hitler.

The cost of another year's operation of the special rehabilitation employment service of the Charity Organization Society has been assured as the result of recent action by the trustees of the Riverside Church, of which the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick is pastor, it was announced yesterday at the offices of the organization, 105 East Twenty-second Street.

GOSPORT, England, July 20. -- T.O.M. Sopwith arrived here today to make final arrangements for the departure of his America's Cup challenger, Endeavour, to New York. He gave instructions to start the voyage Monday morning at the earliest possible moment.

SANDOWN PARK, England, July 20. -- King Salmon today defeated the pick of England's 3-year-olds, including this year's Derby winner, Windsor Lad, to triumph in the rich Eclipse Stakes. Windsor Lad finished third, behind Umidwar, the Aga Khan's leading 3-year-old.

CORBEIL. Ont., July 20. -- A small discoloration originally believed to be a birthmark on the left leg of baby Marie, smallest of the Dionne quintuplets, was diagnosed today as a naevus tumor, believed not to be malignant. Radium treatments will be used later.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., July 20. -- A shake-up in the administration of local relief departments was ordered today as the Common Council prepared to begin Monday its investigation of city departments.

BERLIN, July 20. -- In moves during the last forty-eight hours the State and the Nazi party respectively have taken up the fight against the "national Bolshevist" tendencies of Germany's university students.

MADRID, July 20. -- Boris the First, self- appointed Sovereign Prince of Andorra, was arrested today at Seo de Rugel on the Spanish side of the tiny State's frontier and taken to Barcelona after it had been decided at a Cabinet meeting here today that "the comical antics of this adventurer have gone far enough."

Director Fritz Beck of Munich, loved by all foreign students, international leader, pioneer of student self-help activities and incomparable host, was shot and killed along with Stabschef Roehm and others. Dr. Beck's death was a ghastly mistake.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- Wholesale commodity prices, advancing 1.2 per cent last month, were the highest on June 30 of any month since April, 1931, when the index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, based on 1926 averages, was 74.8. The index for June, 1934, was 74.6 as compared with 73.7 for May, 65.0 for June, 1933; 63.9 for June, 1932, and 72.1 for June, 1931.

In 1976 the population of Great Britain will be less than 33,000,000. The young will be outnumbered by the old, and the old will, in turn, comprise more women than men. Such are the conclusions reached by Professor HJORT of London's Imperial College of Science and Technology in his Huxley Memorial Lecture on the "Restrictive Law of Population."

Subscriptions from institutional and private investors for New York City's $58,000,000 of serial bonds were approximately three times the amount of the offering, according to tabulations made yesterday by the Chase National Bank, which headed the offering group. The deal was described as "a tremendous success."
SAN FRANCISCO, July 20. -- Determined efforts to remove radical agitation from California industry and agriculture were reported today from various points.

An unsuccessful attempt at sea to save the life of a stricken merchant marine officer was reported here yesterday in a radio message from Captain Schuyler F. Cumings of the United States liner Manhattan. He told of the transfer by lifeboat of Francisco Pertot, chief officer of the Cosulich Line freighter Alberta, to the Manhattan, when that vessel was about 650 miles east of New York.

" Sundown," an autobiographical novel by John Joseph Mathews, a member of the Osage Indian tribe, has been accepted for Fall publication by Longmans, Green Co. This author's previous book, "Wah 'Kon-Tah," was a Book-of-the-Month Club selection in 1932.

BISMARCK, N.D., July 20. -- Appearing before a crowd of farmers belonging to the holiday movement, William Langer, ousted Governor of North Dakota, tonight declared that the mortgage situation in the State demanded a special session of the Legislature. Langer spoke in front of a hotel occupied by most of his legislative leaders.
William Green of the American Federation of Labor states that the National Housing Act, H.R. 9620, should furnish employment for 5,000,000 men.
CHICAGO, July 20. -- Pop bottles flew at Comiskey Park today as the Yankees dropped a thirteen-inning struggle to the White Sox and lost a chance to gain on the league-leading Tigers.

Democratic leaders of the five boroughs of New York City will meet Wednesday to consider whether to name an organization candidate for Controller or to endorse Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick, Fusionist, whom Mayor LaGuardia appointed to fill the vacancy caused by the death of W. Arthur Cunningham.

HOLLYWOOD, July 20 (AP). -- A "percentage arrangement," such as Sol A. Rosenblatt, Film Code Administrator, has suggested on movie wages, long has been discussed in Hollywood, but little ever has been done about it.

Marion McGonigle's Jesting kept her Empire City record clean by triumphing easily in the featured Greenwich purse at the hilltop track yesterday. The Ascot Stable's Spanish Way ran second in the mile and a sixteenth contest, with J.H. Louchheim's Ward-in-Chancery third.

Washington dispatches were unanimous recently in stating that thenceforth all labor difficulties would be in complete charge of Secretary PERKINS and the National Labor Relations Board, with General JOHNSON and Senator WAGNER relegated to the background.

Payments of $28,214,543 in interest in the first six months of 1934 to mortgagees and certificate holders of the seventeen title and mortgage companies in rehabilitation were reported yesterday by George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance.

BERLIN, July 20. -- Alfons Sack, counsel for Ernst Torgler in the Reichstag fire trial and now among the prisoners held by the secret State police, seems to have been cleared of any complicity with Karl Ernst, executed Berlin Storm Troop leader. It is learned he is now being retained in prison while his contacts with the American lawyers Arthur Garfield Hays and Leo Gallagher and other "internationalists'' suspected of communistic tendencies are investigated.

Labor and pension laws having been passed at the last session of Congress against the wishes of the railroads, the Association of Railway Executives has under consideration a proposal for the formation of State organizations to influence legislation, it was learned yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 20. -- Costs of the San Francisco and Alameda County general strikes had mounted to incalculable heights when they were called off.

ALBANY, July 20. -- Governor Lehman is looking forward to action next week by the Senate and Assembly on the county reforms measures with every assurance that the three major concurrent resolutions, providing for the preliminary amendments to the Constitution, will be put through in the form advocated by the Governor and the New York City Charter Commission.

Despite the many adverse influences, business throughout the country maintained a surprising degree of steadiness last week, according to the survey by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. While retail sales were somewhat under expectations, volume was bolstered by successful clearance promotions, with the volume rising 8 to 10 per cent above a year ago.
DETROIT, July 20 (AP). -- The Tigers were brought up smartly by a mighty swing of Jimmy Foxx's bat in the eighth inning today and lost their series opener against the Athletics, 5 to 4.

RYE, N.Y., July 20. -- Spirited competition in all divisions marked the first two sessions of the fourth annual Country Club Horse Show, which opened this morning on the polo field of the Westchester Country Club.

Representatives of the city administration, organized labor, consumer and civic organizations and the laundry industry -- employers as well as employes -- united yesterday in urging Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews to make the minimum wage scale as applied to laundries mandatory.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 20. -- after nearly four years as head of he provisional government which he set up, Dr. Getulio Vargas was inaugurated today as the first President under the new constitution.

In announcing the British Government's plan to enlarge its air force, Acting Prime Minister BALDWIN made a frank statement. Disappointment at the slow progress, and the present stalemate, of negotiations for disarmament necessitated a change in the previous British policy.

MOSCOW, July 20. -- "Despite the drought in the early Summer, the harvest will be no worse than last year in total volume and in some important regions it will be considerably better," was the statement of Sergei Kiroff, member of the Communist Political Bureau and leader of the Leningrad Communist party, in his report to the Leningrad Province Communist party committee.

SALEM, N.H., July 20 (AP). -- J.D. Mikel's Gaillardia, 6-year-old gelded son of Blink II, easily defeated a field of seven other starters in the featured fourth event, a $1,000 claiming affair, at Rockingham Park today.

Orders for twenty-eight electric passenger locomotives of a design which will provide greater safety for the crews than did previous models were announced yesterday by the Pennsylvania Railroad. The locomotives will cost more than $6,000,000.

BLUFF POINT, N.Y., July 20 (AP). -- Mrs. Dorothy Campbell Hurd, former American and British champion, won her 750th golf prize today when she defeated 16-year-old Miss Marjorie Harrison, 2 up, in the women's invitation tournament. Miss Harrison won the cup last year.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- Organized workers in San Francisco acted wisely when they called off the general strike, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, declared tonight in a statement which called the sympathetic strike a "grave mistake."

ON BOARD THE CRUISER NEW ORLEANS, accompanying President Roosevelt, July 20 (AP). -- President Roosevelt studied reports dealing with his social program today as he cruised toward Hawaii on the Houston under a clear sky and smooth water.

A miniature tidal wave engulfed hundreds of persons who went to Coney Island yesterday in search of relief from the second day of intense heat and high humidity. As the water receded, it carried several bathers out beyond their depths.

To maintain their position in the cotton markets of the world while the American crop is being restricted, some of the largest spot houses of the United States are increasing facilities to handle the production of cotton in foreign countries, which is expected to be heavier than ever before.
BERLIN, July 20. -- The phantom blockade imposed on Germany by her shrinking exports and vanishing gold reserve is beginning to cripple German industry.

Whatever the fortunes of the latest "New Tammany" may be, it will stand better in public estimation because of the return to it of the most engaging sachem and werowance that ever sat in the Wigwam. It is no use to dwell on far-off unhappy things. In the years of AL SMITH'S absence the councils of the tribe have not been eminent for wisdom.

Three more contracts were awarded yesterday by the Board of Transportation as part of the program for completion of the city's independent subway system with the aid of Federal funds. Two contracts were awarded early this week. The five contracts will be sent to the Board of Estimate for approval and will then go to the State engineer of the Federal Public Works Administration for final sanction.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 20. -- The condition of 21-month-old Robert Connor had improved to such an extent today that Dr. Charles L. Suttles, the child's physician, declared in his noon bulletin that no further statements would be issued unless some unforeseen reversal should develop.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- Complaints against the agreement the NRA signed with the Harriman Hosiery Mills in Tennessee were made to recovery officials by a strike spokesman at the mills today, but it was announced that the action of A.R. Glancy, assistant NRA administrator, in negotiating the agreement and restoring the Blue Eagle to the corporation would stand.

TOKYO, July 20. -- A statement was issued by the Cabinet this evening setting forth the domestic and foreign policies that it means to follow. The statement contains little that is surprising and it confirms the general belief that Premier Okada does not intend to depart from the course Admiral Saito set.

BERLIN, July 20. -- Prices on the Boerse were stronger today as interest spread to many securities that had not been touched so far by the present rising tendency. Heavy industrials were especially active. Textiles were mixed. Increased steel production and reports of improvement in Ruhr coal production had a buoying influence.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 20. -- Giraud Foster gave a buffet supper tonight for seventy persons on the terrace at Bellefontaine, Lenox, in compliment to his daughter-in-law, Mrs. Giraud van Nest Foster, who celebrated her birthday.

SANTIAGO, Chile, July 20. -- The monthly report of the Central Bank, reviewing general conditions in Chile, shows a more optimistic outlook than previous bulletins. Improvement noted in nearly all businesses is enterpreted as indicating Chile is gradually emerging from her severest economic crisis.
MADRID, July 20. -- Catalonia's dispute with the Central Government, beginning with the generalidad's defiance of Madrid's authority six weeks ago, appeared today to be finally and peaceably settled.

LEEDS, England, July 20 (Canadian Press). -- In strong contrast to the third test match which dragged to a draw as the bowlers were helpless, the attack had the upper hand when the fourth test between England and Australia got under way today.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 20. -- William E. Mancusi, a New Rochelle detective, was killed and his companion, Chief Edwin A. Decker of the Mamaroneck (N.Y.) Police Department, was seriously injured when their automobile crashed into a parked truck at daybreak today on Noroton Hill on the Boston Post Road.

JOE TURNESA, tall and dark, won the Long Island open golf championship the other day. He didn't do it with one hand tied behind his back, but he used only one hand when putting and thus may be hailed as another worthy pioneer for simplified golf. The game is entirely too complicated now.
I wish some of the farmers and other people who think Wall Street is peopled wholly by hard-boiled brutes had been there yesterday when news of the finding of the Connor baby first "broke."

WESTBURY, L.I., July 20. -- A sixty-yard shot by Skiddy von Stade after three minutes of overtime enabled Princemere to down William Ziegler's Great Island riders, 6 to 5, and advance into the semi-final round of the Wheatley Cups tournament at the Meadow Brook Club today.

" The committee favors the continuance " in each borough of a separate "borough government enjoying the "widest possible borough autonomy "consistent with efficient and economical " government." Obviously that leaves unanswered the essential question just how much borough autonomy is consistent with efficient and economical government.

WHITEFIELD, N.H., July 20. -- The Forty-Niners gave their second revival, "The Streets of New York," at the Chase Barn Theatre here tonight. There was again a prelude of mountain thunderstorms such as attended their season's opening in "The Two Orphans" last week.

The performance of Bizet's "Carmen" last night at the Lewisohn Stadium proved one of the most successful opera presentations given there this Summer season. An audience of good size was obviously delighted and stirred by one of the greatest of operatic masterpieces, which is at once very-popular and very distinguished music drama.

The District Attorney's office in Brooklyn investigated yesterday the death of Irving Greenberg, 18 months old, who was scalded in the nfants Home of Brooklyn, 1,358 Fifty-sixth Street, on July 13, and died shortly afterward at Israel Zion Hospital.

Owen Madden, paroled Sing Sing convict and former gang leader, appeared yesterday at the Criminal Courts Building and testified in the grand jury investigation of alleged fraud in the sales of coal to the city during the last five years.

A lone civilian, equipped with a rowboat and a nickel-plated revolver, gave the United States Army one of its most embarrassing moments yesterday by hijacking a military prisoner from Governors Island and rowing him a mile and a half to the freedom of the lower Red Hook section of Brooklyn.

John Haynes Holmes, in his criticism of the Oxford Group quoted by THE TIMES, seems also somewhat in error. His assertion that "sin today is not individual but social," that "there can be no saving of the individual until society is saved," appears to be a clear confusion of effect for cause.

Plans for forming a city-wide chain of neighborhood clubs were discussed by delegates from eleven organizations last night, who emphasized the need of such clubs for the defense of their economic interests as well as those of white-collar and professional workers generally.

BERLIN, July 20. -- It is said in official quarters that Germany will not reply to the Franco-Russian pact proposals submitted to the Wilhelmstrasse with the blessing of Downing Street until the proponents of the new pact system have agreed among themselves on its implications.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- Miss Louise Breckinridge, 17-year-old daughter of Colonel Henry Breckinridge of New York City, was killed today by a bullet accidentally discharged from a target rifle which she was carrying.

The United States Lines will start a freight and passenger service between New York, Cobh, Liverpool and Manchester with the sailing today of the liner American Shipper from the Chelsea piers at 11 A.M. The second sailing will be Aug. 4 by the liner American Importer and thereafter the lines will continue fortnightly sailings.

JERUSALEM, July 20. -- The Court of Appeal today quashed the death sentence passed by the District Court on Abraham Stavsky on June 8 for the murder of Dr. Chaim Arlosoroff, prominent labor leader and member of the Jewish Agency Executive of Palestine.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP).-- Grants totaling $20,261,077 to five States were announced today by Aubrey Williams, acting Federal Relief Administrator. These included $7,000,000 for New York State as the first instalment of $18,347,000 for July.
TORONTO, July 20 (AP). -- Two new records were established during the second's day's program of the Grand Circuit meeting at Thorncliffe Park today.
WASHINGTON, July 20. -- Postmaster General Farley has informed President Roosevelt that a long-elusive goal of the Postoffice Department, a balanced budget, has been achieved.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange broke $1.50 a bale yesterday and closed at the bottom, with losses of 24 to 31 points.

The twenty-two children here on a good-will visit from the Netherlands officially were welcomed yesterday to the city on behalf of Mayor LaGuardia by Commissioner Frederick J.H. Kracke of the Department of Plant and Structures. His address of greeting was delivered at a reception at the headquarters of the Merchants Association in the Woolworth Building.
JONES BEACH, L.I., July 21. -- Miss Dolores Smith, unattached, captured the 300-yard free style swim at the metropolitan A.A.U. handicap meet in the outdoor pool tonight.

The Forked River public yacht basin illustrates the enlightened attitude of the New Jersey State Board of Commerce and Navigation toward yachting and motor boating. This modern, newly equipped basin comes as near as anything to being the yachtsman's paradise.
WESTHAMPTON, L.I., July 21. -- Forty-five yachts started in a light southwest wind in the weekend regatta of the Yacht Racing Squadron of the Westhampton Country Club on Moriches Bay today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 21. -- The decision of authorities that little Robert Connor had not been kidnapped, but had wandered off into the woods, was a source of considerable relief to Westchester parents.

BRUSSELS, July 9. -- "They are all pigeon fanciers and, unfortunately, the pigeon-racing season and the tourist season coincide," sighed a hotelkeeper on the Belgian coast, when asked why he was so unpatriotic as to employ foreign labor when Belgians are out of work.

Normal schools must modify their curricula to meet the demands of rural schools which have only one or two teachers, according to a report made by Professor Fannie Dunn of Columbia University at the final session yesterday of a conference on the education of teachers at Teachers College.

In his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES, Richard Porter Scoville pays tribute to Mrs. Emma E. Beebe for her description of a New England boiled dinner and remarks truly that the "succulent dish of hash that can be made from the leftovers is the best part."

ATLANTA, July 21 (AP). -- The government's effort to collect $20,148 as taxes on football gate receipts at Georgia Tech, which is considered a test case for similar actions throughout the country, will be considered at a Federal court hearing here Saturday.

SUMMER rugs -- which in many households regularly replace the heavier pile weaves during hot weather -- are this year cooler and smarter than ever. Bright in color and novel in pattern, they bring a welcome change to living room or bedroom: and on roof, terrace or porch they seem comfortable and luxurious.

PHILADELPHIA, July 21 (AP). -- Only 100 of the striking employes of the Gulf Refining Company will be taken back, C.B. Buerger, vice president of the company, stated today, and those only if they apply for work at once.

The last word in parallel passages, literary adaptation, poetic quotation, or what have you, is the triangular case of William Congreve vs. Alfred Tennyson vs. the songwriting team of Arthur Johnston and Sam Coslow, collaborators in the lyric "Thanks," from "Too Much Harmony," screen play de luxe, with music.

State warrants and city tax-anticipatory notes were the principal securities called last week for redemption in July before their dates of maturity. For retirements in future months parts of several domestic and foreign industrial issues, a large block of State bonds and smaller amounts of bonds of various municipalities were called.

BOSTON, July 21 (AP). -- Jim Mooney of the Cardinals stepped into the breach today, after Bill Hallahan was injured by a line drive, and proceeded to pitch his team to a 5-3 victory over the Braves. It was the third victory in a row for the Missourians over Boston.

GREAT BRITAIN recently served notice on rival air powers in Europe that she would build to parity against any other nation, having abandoned hope that a disarmament convention would be concluded at Geneva.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 21 (AP). -- The G.O.P. Weekly News Letter, voice of Republican State Chairman W. Kingsland Macy, today predicted the downfall of Speaker Joseph A. McGinnies, "Old Guard" leader of the Assembly.

BOSTON, July 21. (AP). -- Heat and clear sky seared Southern New England crops today as Northern New England States gained temporary respite from the drought menace with scattered thunder showers last night.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, July 19. -- While there is no immediate prospect of extensive labor trouble along the Texas Coast, with the exception of a small strike at Houston involving two steamship companies, a stevedore contracting company and about 300 men, the question of extending the control of the International Longshoremen's Association over work which has heretofore been done by non-union men looms as a menace.

PHILADELPHIA, July 20. - Prolonged hot weather has been exceedingly beneficial to merchandising, creating a brisk and constant demand for seasonable goods of large variety, which is leading to repeat orders and thus stimulating business for wholesalers, and jobbers.

ONLY 44.7 per cent of eighth-grade pupils in the public schools show a mastery of the essentials of English usage, only 30.9 per cent show a mastery of niceties and only 15.5 per cent a grasp of the least important phases of usage.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 21. -- Acceptance of arbitration by the ship-owners and water-front employers should mean the reopening of the port of San Francisco to commerce "without hindrance or trouble" according to a statement made today by Mayor Angelo J. Rossi.

Nine-year-old Audrey Rainier, 'cellist prodigy, arrived here last week with his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. Billson of London, on the steamship American Merchant. Rainier is his professional name.

The writer of THE TIMES editorial "Eating Under Capitalism" apparently does not realize that the American revolution of 1932 ha taken place. He ascribes the present feeding of a considerable part of the population to the Old Order. If he will analyze the present order he will find that we are now living in a New Order.

THE American edition of this little book comes at a most timely moment, when events in Germany are again holding the shocked attention of the whole country and the new Germanic "religion," with which the volume is concerned, is giving proof of its nature by its fruits.

Joseph Sullivan, 37 years old, of 30-19 Forty-ninth Street, Long Island City, a conductor of the Manhattan Queens Railway Company, was caught between two colliding trolley cars and critically injured yesterday afternoon on the approach to the Queensborough Bridge on Fifty-ninth Street, between First and Second Avenues.

No adequate relief for the unemployed "short of" Federal unemployment insurance is possible, according to a resolution framed yesterday by a committee of delegates from nine unemployed and relief workers' organizations representing a membership of 45,000 in five Eastern States.

The two murders with which this story opens are incidental to a plot that threatens the security of the British Empire. Consequently, when Harry Buckley conceals a vital clue, because he fears that it may implicate the father of the girl with whom he has fallen in love, he creates a lot of trouble not only for himself hut also for the Scotland Yard detective who is investigating the case.

CHICAGO, July 19. -- Visitors to Chicago have gaped in astonishment when suddenly speeding down the crowded highway came two motorcycle policemen with loud sirens screaming for right of way. Thrilled, the stranger supposed that at least some notorious gunmen were being pursued.
Creation of a Federal Department of Education was advocated by Professor George D. Strayer in his speech at a conference in Teachers College, Columbia University.

THE drought enters conversation early in any journey to the Middle West. You may begin to hear about it at a wayside inn outside Pittsburgh. The bathtub faucets are padlocked against itinerant water-wasters. The innkeeper explains that his artesian well has failed; he has only a cistern of rainwater; the water level there is the lowest in years.

Congress should not continue the code system beyond June 16, 1935, the date for its expiration, except in such basic materials industries as coal, oil and power, declares William A. Orton in an article entitled "Should the Codes Survive?" in August Current History.

Although retail buyers came into the markets in larger numbers last week, their purchases in most instances were rather conservative, being limited to opening needs, according to the report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer.

In an effort to expand wool goods markets and to alleviate the current difficult price situation, the industry will shortly make an attempt to introduce a new promotional set-up, it was learned here yesterday. The campaign will, if generally approved, be the most comprehensive ever undertaken by the industry, with all divisions uniting to put it over.
WASHINGTON, July 21. -- General Johnson plans to fly back from the Pacific Coast to Washington tomorrow or Monday because of the illness of his wife.

APLEASANT link of sentiment brings together this book by the Professor of Ancient History in the University of Cologne and the American readers for whom it has been made possible by this excellent translation. For he dedicates the edition in English to the memory of his grandfather, "Herman Johannes Hasebrook, citizen of the United States of America, born 1820 in Leyden, Holland; died 1866 in St. Louis, Mo., U.S.A."

Ernest Koslan and Bernard Freedman, third and fourth seeded players, reached the semi-final bracket in the Bronx municipal tennis championship at Crotona Park yesterday. Koslam defeated Isadore Edelstein, 6 -- 2, 6 - 2, while Freedman won from Abram Goldsholl, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4.

DES MOINES, Iowa, July 21. -- Youths of America -- drifting down-and-outers, hopeful job seekers and those merely out for adventure -- are not cluttering up the freight trains that rumble through Des Moines this Summer as they did a year ago.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- The running of the Postoffice Department at a profit of $5,000,000 in the fiscal year closed June 30 was accomplished without impairing the service, Acting Postmaster General Howes said today in commenting upon this achievement, the first time in fifteen years that the Postoffice Department has been "out of the red."

AMATEUR gardeners have been often advised to plant lilies in masses; and it must be conceded that broad sweeps of color are very effective, with lilies as with other garden material. Nature generally plants her gardens in that manner.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 21. -- Suffering acutely from the worst drought in its history, the Midwest and Southwest tonight counted its crop loss in the hundreds of millions of dollars.

THIS little novel, the work of a distinguished South American writer, attacks a psychological problem of unusual difficulty and fascination. Senor Galvez has attempted in "Holy Wednesday'' to lay bare the soul of a priest, to analyze the life-long struggle between his sincere passion for good and what he feels to be the evil within himself.

The first part of the fourteenth annual exhibition of the Rockport Art Association opened a fortnight ago in the galleries of the association and will continue through Aug. 5. The second part will be shown from Aug 8 through Sept. 9.

THE following letter from Robert Ulrich Godsoe, director of the Uptown Gallery in the Continental Club, 249 West End Avenue, replies to charges made by two correspondents last Sunday and reaffirms the theory upon which the artists of the Uptown Gallery group are working:

THE TIMES spoke last week of Mussorgsky's experiments with musical prose in his setting of Gogol's "The Marriage" and his statement that this was not only a special experiment in itself but also a training for his -- Mussorgsky's -- operatic future.

CHICAGO, July 19. -- Michigan Boulevard, impressive front to Chicago's downtown district, is going Continental. Permits are to be issued to hotels and restaurateurs for chairs and tables on its broad pavement and the service of al fresco refreshments.

A further extension of its position in the insurance field is being made by the Equity Corporation through the acquisition of at least a 26 per cent interest in the General Alliance Corporation, an insurance holding company. This is revealed in the semi-annual report of Equity made public yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, July 19. -- The explanation of Huey Long's sweeping success in the Legislature which has just adjourned can be found in a few simple facts. Although certain prophets were dooming him five months ago after the defeat of his candidates in the New Orleans Mayoralty and the Sixth District Congressional contest, his unparalleled domination of the Legislature was not a political miracle.

CAMP DIX, N.J., July 21. -- Officers of the 307th Infantry who have been conducting the opening training period for 800 Citizens Military Training Corps candidates here will be relieved by officers of the 306th Infantry of New York's Seventy, seventh Division who will mobilize at the camp Monday to take over the final phases of the training.

MOSCOW, July 20. -- The visit to Moscow next week of the Estonian and Lithuanian Foreign Ministers -- following a conference of the Baltic States of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania in the latter's capital, Kaunas -- indicates that the field of the Eastern Locarno pact will not be left to lie fallow while Germany and Poland make up their minds.

SEASIDE PARK, N.J., July 21. -- The Island Heights Yacht Club was host today to 113 yachts of the seven member clubs of the Barnegat Bay Yacht Racing Association and visitors from the Barnegat Light Y.C. of Harvey Cedars, the Evening Star Y.C. of Atlantic City and the Little Egg Harbor Y.C. of Beach Haven.

In The American Magazine Mr. H.G. WELLS sees, by some gift that must involve a good deal of eyestrain, "the "realization of the organized world-"state as the rational common objec-"tive * * * even now seeping steadily "into the human consciousness." It needs a penetrating vision to discover this in these days of intense nationalism.

Newspaper editors in Paris and Moscow have a just grievance against the San Francisco labor leaders who called off the general strike with such unseemly haste. Here was the French press discussing the grave situation in the United States; in the opinion of the sober and erudite Temps it was "one of the gravest social crises which has ever occurred in the United States."

BALBOA, C.Z., July 21. -- An earthquake shock at 5:40 A.M. today caused the collapse of more houses at David City, which had been weakened by prior shocks, but no loss of life was reported. It was reported the church bells in David City began to toll before the shock.

Lake Sebago, at Sloatsburg, N.Y., will be the scene of the annual Atlantic Division of the American Canoe Association canoe-paddling championships today. Eighteen events are slated for the 800-meter course. The first three finishers in each will qualify as the divisional representatives in the national canoeing championships to be held on the Delaware River at Trenton, N.J., next Sunday.

JERSEY CITY, July 21. -- The dispute in this city over the right to picket in labor disputes, marked by the arrest of twenty persons, including Corliss Lamont, was settled by the Hague administration just as it threatened to become a serious political issue

The plight of German academic and professional groups who have been affected by Nazi persecution and their future prospects of gaining a livelihood and continuing their work in foreign countries were outlined in a statement yesterday by the Emergency Committee in Aid of Displaced German Scholars, 2 West 45th Street, New York City.

CHICAGO, July 21. -- Another "solution" of the Lindbergh kidnapping case was offered to authorities today, this time by .John Pawelczyk, 44, who is serving one to fourteen years for manslaughter in the Joliet penitentiary.

BARCELONA, July 6. -- The technical question of whether radio broadcasting may also be classed as radio communication has caused a political row between the Catalan and the Madrid Governments. The Spanish Constitution reserves to the State control of all forms of communication, including radio, although it conceded to the autonomous region control of broadcasting.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- Recommendations by a marine corps selection board of promotion of ninety-two captains to be majors and eighty-nine first lieutenants to be captains were approved by President Roosevelt today in a message from the cruiser Houston to Secretary Swanson.

THE French are congratulating themselves on the "most beautiful film of the year" -- "Lac-aux -- Dames," from Vicki Baum's novel. At least, a majority of French critics are calling it that for it is one of those films unusual enough to arouse a storm of controversy.

BEHIND the drive on the Nazi radicals, which so recently stirred the world, there looms the figure of Fritz Thyssen, one of Germany's most powerful industrialists. In the conflict between Right and Left, the Nationalistic and Socialistic aspects of the National Socialist party, his view has won Hitler's Third Reich is Thyssen's Germany.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- Some of the ground lost in productive activity in the preceding holiday week was regained in the week ended on July 14, but the composite business index was still below the pre-holiday level, the weekly survey of domestic business conditions by the Department of Commerce showed today.
WASHINGTON, July 21. -- Two hundred thousand roving Americans have given up the highway for havens, if only temporary ones, in the network of transient camps dotting the countryside.

PHOTOGRAPHY, both still and moving picture, has been developing along regular progressive lines since such gentlemen as Daguerre, Niepsce and Hill made it something more than just a pictorial record about seventy-five years ago.

NEWPORT. -- This is to be locally a week with numerous out-of-door sporting events. All that is needed to make the program a success is a continuation of good weather. There will be a golf tournament at the Newport Country Club for the golfers among the officers of the battle force of the United States Fleet now basing on Narragansett Bay.

BALTIMORE, July 19. -- An exhibition of sang-froid that illustrated both the possible envy and despair of rival candidates was Governor Albert C. Ritchie's most recent contribution to Maryland politics. Although his candidacy for another term is being seriously opposed by his own party for the first time since his first election fifteen years ago, the Governor confidently turned his back on primary activities and sailed for Europe.

ASIA is well represented on the September list of E.P. Dutton Co. On the 14th of the month this firm will publish "The Message of Asia," by Paul Cohen-Portheim, and "Buddhists and Glaciers of Western Tibet," by Giotto Dainelli.

RYE, N.Y., July 21. -- Richard D. Chapman of Blind Brook continued his triumphal march through Westchester today by winning the Westchester Country Club's invitation tournament, the victory being his third in the district this season.

GATHER berets while you may. The open season for them is upon us again. There is a veritable epidemic this year, and like all epidemics it is likely to be short-lived. These devil-may-care hats (is our fondness of them based on memories of the Blue Devils?) come in a variety of forms.

ROME, July 20. -- It is, perhaps, useless to inquire now whether Premier Mussolini's sudden and unexpected conversion to the principle of the regional pacts of security sponsored by Foreign Minister Barthou of France and Foreign Commissar Litvinoff of Russia was spontaneous or was forced upon him by the turn of events.

IN the manner of some of the older fiction of this century, say, for example, "K" and "V. V.'s Eyes," which used to be read more for story than style, this book is a good yarn. It is plot for plot's sake, and almost reads itself.

HARRIMAN, Tenn., July 21 (AP). -- Strikers of the Harriman Hosiery Mills late today voted to reject an agreement under which the Blue Eagle would be restored to the mills, which closed after the emblem had been removed.

ONE of the earliest and most prolific authors to exploit the prohibition gangster fictionally, Mr. Coe here keeps level with the times by staging the greater part of this thriller in the first year of Repeal.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H. -- Social and sports activities at the White Mountain resorts are increasing, with theatrical events first on the program. The Barnstormers open Monday at Tamworth Gardens in "Ten-Minute Alibi," the Notchland Players hold their weekly premiere at Notchland on Thursday evenings and the Forty-Niners will present their new play on Friday evening at the Chase Barn Theatre, Whitefield.

RAPID CITY, S.D., July 21. -- Rigging of ropes to the lower catenary band of the stratosphere balloon, the last preliminary to inflation, was to start at 3 o'clock tomorrow morning unless the night weather map or local observation showed immediate storms.

LOS ANGELES, July 19. -- California presents a somewhat more somber picture than usual this week. It is riot torn, drought stricken and a political campaign is getting under way that for mysterious goings on and doubtful results beats anything the past has offered.

PORTLAND, Ore., July 21. -- Balked for the time being at least in its effforts to prevent waterfront activities by the near presence of 1,000 well-armed Oregon National Guardsmen, organized labor was shaping new weapons of warfare today

ISTANBUL, June 30. -- Ibrahim Tali Bey, recently appointed Inspector General of Thrace, with jurisdiction over the vilayets of Adrianople, Kirk-Kilisse and Tekirdagh (Rodosto), has taken up his new duties.

DETROIT, July 21. -- It is the conviction of Henry Ford that plain old-fashioned Americanism, which he defines as "the pioneer spirit that isn't afraid to tackle anything," is the force that will save the nation from its economic and social afflictions.

PHILADELPHIA, July 21. -- The Academy of Music will be equipped with a cyclorama, similar to those used in the most modern opera houses in Europe, as a means of achieving lighting effects desired by the Philadelphia Orchestra Association in its production of opera next season.

WHEN San Francisco comes into the news as a storm centre that fact is partly a sign of the times and partly an evidence that the city's temperament has not changed. From the days of the Vigilantes, clash and struggle have again and again rocked the peninsula beside the Golden Gate.

EXTREME remedies are needed for ready relief. This is no time for dallying. The crisis is such that it calls for direct action, something like the method suggested, according to the old chronicles, in the case of a patient seeking medical advice. "What's the quickest way of getting rid of a cold in the head?" "That's easy. Cut your head off."

The Majorca Sun, published in Palma de Mallorca in the Balearic Islands, opposite Barcelona, occasionally annexes to its staff a number of once widely-known newspaper men, who have found the soft climate of the place congenial to their declining years.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP). -- NRA officials indicated today that the new settlement with the Harriman Hosiery Mills, which stirred a whirl of controversy in Blue Eagle and labor ranks, probably would stand unchanged despite its rejection by strikers at Harriman.

RYE, N.Y., July 21. -- For the second year in succession, the black gelding Sun Eclipse today captured a leg on the Heather Trophy, one of the major prizes of the fourth annual Westchester Country Club Horse Show.

The Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers will request the industry's Code Authority at its meeting here on Tuesday to apply for an amendment to the code, permitting price registration, Samuel Klein, executive director, announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- The petition filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission by the Railroad Credit Corporation, seeking to speed up adoption of a reorganization plan for the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway was made in a determination to protect the corporation against any loss in connection with advances which it has made.

HYDRANGEAS, like dahlias, have suffered undeserved neglect at the hands of many gardeners because of the use, in inartistic ways, of a single huge-flowered type which came to be regarded as representative of the whole family.

THIS week marks the fortieth anniversary of an incident that was destined to prove significant throughout the world. On July 25, 1894, near Phung Island, off the coast of Korea, there was a naval engagement that marked the outbreak of the Chinese-Japanese War, in which Japan gained military prominence.

CHICAGO, July 21. -- Riskulus, a temperamental colt which turned out to be nothing but a losing risk since he left Agua Caliente, ran the race of his life today to beat Mrs. John D. Hertz's Watch Him in the $10,000 added Arlington Handicap.

WASHINGTO, July 21. -- With the Federal housing program designed to encourage building all over the country just getting under way, the Labor Department today reported a 11.9 per cent decrease in the number and a 26 per cent decline in the estimated cost of construction projects between May and June.

Newspapers like THE NEW YORK TIMES show us daily, by means of their able and comprehensive dispatches from abroad, how tremendous a portion of the highest human thought is at this moment being devoted to the supreme problem of problems: How shall we govern ourselves?

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- A total of 206 registration statements, involving gross proceeds of $354,936,848, were filed under the Securities Act of 1933 during the first six months of this year and became effective, the Federal Trade Commission announced today.

LOS ANGELES, July 20. THE annals of the local theatre are, at the moment, short and almost painfully simple. All the playhouses of downtown Los Angeles are slumbering darkly through the belated Summer nights, with only two Hollywood theatres offering legitimate productions.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP). -- In the morning hours of March 4, 1933, Franklin D. Roosevelt made a promise to the man he was soon to succeed in the Presidency that Walter H. Newton, Hoover political secretary, would be given a job in the new administration.

WARSAW, July 21 (AP). -- Flood waters of the Vistula River, which took more than 200 lives in Southern Poland, swept into Warsaw today, forcing many citizens from their homes as the streets of suburbs were turned into canals.

Many neighborhood houses and community centres are providing thousands of New York City children with excellent substitutes for vacations in the country this Summer, it was said yesterday by Louis C. Schroeder, bead of the recreation division of the Department of Public Welfare.

The New Deal makes for a larger exercise of civil liberty in fields not involving economic issues of power and privilege, but it is timid and ineffective in regard to civil liberties in industrial struggles, according to "Liberty Under the New Deal," the annual report of the American Civil Liberties Union, published yesterday.

PARIS, July 10. -- Although it seems almost too good to be true, France is going to have another wonderful wine year if the present weather holds. Last year was a "vintage" year of high order -- the first since 1929 -- and no one dared hope for two such years in succession.

LONDON, July 5. RONALD MACKENZIE'S early death robbed the English theatre of its most promising dramatist. "The Maitlands," presented at Wyndham's Theatre last night, was completed while "Musical Chairs" was still on the stage, and though a less good play than the Polish tragedy, it is far from being a source of embarrassment to Mackenzie's admirers.

The twenty-two Dutch children who are here on a good-will visit from the Netherlands voted unanimously yesterday that New York: was a wonderful city except for two things, the hot weather and the beer. They came to this conclusion after another busy day which included visits to Roosevelt House, 28 East Twentieth Street, and the American Museum of Natural History.

JAMES HENDRICKSON of the tragic firm of James Hendrickson-Claire Bruce Co. is one actor who does not dream of playing Hamlet. He plays Hamlet. Besides being a master printer in the true medieval sense, a creator of exquisite limited editions, a gentleman and something of a scholar, Mr. Hendrickson is at once the most practical and the most impractical of men.

RUMSON, N.J., July 21. -- The Burnt Mills polo team, which had furnished a surprise with the defeat of Rumson earlier in the tournament, carried on over another favorite today to defeat the United States Army, 5 to 4, and win the thirty-first annual national junior championship on the turf of the Rumson Country Club.

Wherever yachtsmen sail the seven seas, wherever canvas is filled and main sheets are taut, wherever tempestuous gales or soft zephyrs give the sailormen their thrills there will be found skippers who owe a debt of genuine gratitude to the Manhasset Bay Y.C. of Port Washington.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 21 (AP). -- James A. Farley, in the dual capacity of Cabinet member and National Democratic Chairman, struck back today at critics who say the government is building a "bureaucracy."

IT may be remembered that 1933 was a Brahms year. During it, had the composer been with us, he would have attained the ripe age of 100. Failing that personal achievement, the various recording companies took the matter in hand and celebrated on his behalf, vouchsafing us much for which there had been persistent clamor to the further strengthening of their lists and, it is to be hoped, bank balances.

Exploiting the theory that nothing ventured means nothing gained, Bob O'Farrell, who has dropped twenty-five pounds managing the Reds this intensely overheated campaign, started Allyn Stout against the Giants at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

NEW LONDON, Conn. -- The Shenecossett Yacht Club, of which R. Rees Mitchell is commodore, will be host to the Eastern Connecticut Yacht Racing Association, which will hold its regatta here on Saturday and Sunday.

ONLY one phase of his subject's long and many-sided life is considered by Mr. Yeager in this interesting study of Chauncey M. Depew as an orator. It is very fitting that he should be the author of such a monograph, for he is Depew Professor of Public Speaking in the George Washington University.

BERLIN, July 21. -- A good part of the German people took their minds off their political and economic troubles today to watch 1,696 motor vehicles of various kinds from eight countries roar through Central and Southern Germany in the biggest cross-country motor race ever staged.

BARCELONA, July 6. -- The Anarcho-Syndicalists, who maintain general headquarters here, have abandoned their dream of bringing about an immediate workers' revolution in Spain through terrorism. Their general committee, this correspondent is informed, has inaugurated a "new phase" of their movement, thereby making tacit admission that the policy of continuous terrorism and intermittent uprisings which they have pursued during the three years of the republic's life has failed.

ORANGE, Va., July 21. -- Leslie B. Gray, lawyer of New York City and owner of Montebello in Orange, has been selected by the casting committee of the Orange County bicentennial celebration to portray his ancestor, Colonel Claiborne, in the historical pageant which will be held here Sept. 25 to 28.

DUBLIN, July 21. -- Striking tributes to religious freedom enjoyed by all creeds in the Irish Free State, in contrast to the partisan attitude of Northern Ireland against Catholics, was emphasized by the Rt. Rev. J. Godfrey Fitzm. Day, Protestant Bishop of Ossory, at the annual synod held at Carlow today.

SALEM, N.H., July 21 (AP). -- Taking advantage of his light impost, 107 pounds, F.A. Carreaud's Sea Fox, 6-year-old son of Man o' War, scored a surprise victory in the $5,000 Hampton Cup Handicap, run before a crowd of 25,000 at Rockingham Park today.

IT is strange that Graham Seton, the author of so successful a spy story as "The W Plan" -- a form which, to be effective, must be concise -- should be able to bury himself and his message under such a weight of stiff, stilted and apparently inexperienced verbiage.

GLENDALE, Calif., July 21. -- Postmaster General Farley, speaking today at the formal dedication of the new Federal building here, asserted the administration had eliminated widespread waste in the Postal Department.

PROHIBITION made an actor of James Cagney, whose latest picture, "Here Comes the Navy," is being shown at the Strand. His father was a saloon keeper and when prohibition came along it meant that young Cagney had to leave Columbia University and get a job.

CAMP DIX, N.J., July 21. -- While driving to the camp tonight from New York, three reserve officers of the 306th Infantry were injured, one of them critically, when the driver swerved to avoid another car on a curve near Bordentown and hit a tree.

PHILADELPHIA, July 21. -- Five convicts escaped from Cherry Hill, the century-old Philadelphia branch of the Eastern State Penitentiary, by swimming through a prison cesspool and struggling for a half mile through a rat-infested sewer this afternoon.
ASTORMY menacing Summer day with low-hanging clouds, the kind London delights in after a few days of sunshine, the day of Whistler's funeral, July 22, 1903.

OMAHA, July 19. -- Peace lies over the heart of the Corn Belt. Having quite recovered from its spasm of farmer-created violence, it represents for the present a great body of calm almost entirely surrounded by labor disturbances. The labor problem touches only a comparatively small minority of its population.
DETROIT, July 21 -- That supreme defensive achievement, a triple play, helped the Tigers defeat the Athletics, 4 to 1, today and defend their American League leadership.

A LIST of the most successful motion pictures of "all time" from a financial viewpoint has been drawn up by The 1934-1935 Motion Picture Almanac and is contained in the current issue of Motion Picture Herald. Five of the first ten pictures were silent films.

The chairman of the Republican National Committee has started rehearsal for that party's Congressional campaign show, known otherwise as the Fletcher Follies. Publicity dispatches indicate that the theme song will consist of nine or ten verses and a highly pitched chorus concerning the cost and constitutionality of the New Deal.

The story of the theft of a truck containing eleven tone of mixed drugs and cosmetics, valued at about $3,000, was revealed here by the police last night following the sending out of a general alarm for the arrest of four men. The bandits twice provided food for the kidnapped truck driver and his helper.

The controversy over the election of Mrs. Ruth Pratt as a delegate to the Republican State Convention has been settled by an invitation to her to become a candidate from the Fifth Assembly District, it was learned yesterday. The invitation was given by Anthony P. Ludden and William S. Reynolds, leaders of the district, and Mrs. Pratt has accepted.

Already the value of the work of the Historic American Buildings Survey as an insurance against destruction of data on historic structures has been shown in a concrete way, according to Arno B. Cammerer, director of the National Park Service, under whose supervision the survey was made.

LONDON, July 21. -- The banks of the Thames are becoming as uncongenial to the dove of peace as the shores of Lake Geneva, for London is rapidly jeopardizing its claim to being the world's best sanctuary, with special nesting facilities for that harassed and now almost homeless bird.

MEN who love danger for its own sake are both fascinating and irritating for those of us who scurry rabbit-like around cities and face peril only when the jaunty taxi-driver whisks unexpectedly around a corner.

MANILA, June 19. -- Any doubts whether Manuel Quezon is the real leader and real representative spokesman for the Philippine Islands have been dispelled by the recent election. The issue was narrowed down, by his opposition, to the validity of his leadership.

ABOARD U.S.S. HOUSTON WITH PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT, July 22 (Sunday) (AP). -- President Roosevelt, talking today to the crew of the Houston in mid-Pacific, promised a United States Navy up to treaty strength in three or four years.

With a total of 114 players listed in the qualifying round, exclusive of the present titleholder, Gene Sarazen, competition for the national P.G.A. championship will start Tuesday morning at the Park Country Club at Buffalo, N.Y. Sarazen automatically qualifies for the match play, leaving thirty-one places open.

CHICAGO, July 21. -- The Yankees struck their stride against the White Sox today at Comiskey Park and kept pace with the Tigers. Downing the Chicagoans by a count of 6 to 2, the McCarthymen held their position two games back of the league leaders in the pennant fight that still is as hot as the weather here.

AN invention for saving the occupants of a sunken submarine unable to rise from the ocean bed has been successfully tried by the Italian Navy. It is called a "submarine lift" and consists of a strong steel cylinder housed in a hatchway fitted with watertight doors and leading down into the submarine.
The following table shows some of the important dividend meetings scheduled for this week and the distributions ordered by the directors at their last meetings:

TOKYO, July 21. -- The Foreign Office reported tonight that it attached considerable importance to the reported intention of British forces at Tientsin to hold manoeuvres in Manchukuo. Unless Great Britain gives up the idea, the question is likely to develop into a major issue, according to observers here.

FROM Paris comes the news that Professor Emanuel Carvallo pronounces the theory of relativity false on the basis of experiments made by Dr. Ernest Fsclangon, director of the Paris Observatory. Both Carvallo and Esclangon endorse our own Dr. Dayton C. Miller of Cleveland, who made tens of thousands of observations between 1921 and 1925.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 21. -- Removal charges against District Attorney John B. Smith and Sheriff George T. Anderson of Saratoga County and Public Safety Commissioner Arthur J. Leonard of Saratoga Springs, alleging dereliction of duty in failing to prevent gambling, were dismissed today by Governor Lehman without a hearing.

A WORLD-WIDE "trap" is being set by scientists in an organized effort to solve the mystery of long-delayed radio echoes. Just as an echo resounds from some natural sounding board such as a cliff or gorge, so these ethereal reiterations register several seconds after the direct signal is heard.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 21. -- A large factor in bringing organized labor here around to a conservative viewpoint and the gradual settlement of the long continued strike situation has been the mediation of the Federal Government.

AN interesting and valuable book for the student of American history has been prepared by Matthew T. Mellon, who is at the present time a student and a lecturer in the philosophical faculty of the Albert Ludwig University, Freiburg.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- Official Washington has been viewing the troubled labor situation in the country with mingled feelings. Regardless of the outcome of any or every one of the specific disputes sprinkled over the map, all elements are agreed that the new and sharper issues which have developed during the past year between labor and management arise from causes far too fundamental to be settled or even materially diminished by the suggested palliatives.
After the Tennessee Valley Authority has taken over its electric power properties the Tennessee Public Service Company will retain a traction property that figures in its rate base at $4,042,606.

There's only about one thing a yachtsman won't do. He's a good-natured soul normally. He's generous, friendly. He'll wave a cheery greeting as he cruises by in the middle of the Sound and if he sees you again at some rendezvous like Lloyd's he'll act like a long lost brother and put genuine sincerity in his invitation to come aboard.
BUENOS AIRES, July 21. -- A German commercial and financial mission has arrived from Berlin to study how Germany can regain her lost markets in the South American republics.

DUBLIN, July 20. -- Eamon de Valera's government has produced such a heavy program of legislation this year that the Dail has had to forego its usual Summer recess and will sit continuously until well into the Fall. The Cabinet has introduced many important bills that must be enacted before the Deputies will be allowed to rest from their Parliamentary labors.

CLEVELAND, July 21 (AP). - Wesley Ferrell, Red Sex hurler, allowed his former team-mates, the Indians, thirteen hits today, but stayed the full route as Boston won, 7 to 6. By winning, the Red Sex returned to third place and the Indians dropped to fourth.

WHEN G.B. Stern published "The Matriarch" she established a kind off pattern against which subsequent stories of great Jewish clans have been measured. Romantic as her formula was, enough truth and life were contained hi it to make a deep mark.

MADRID, July 21. -- Tiny Andorra, which several months ago refused a Chicagoan's offer of $100,000 for the right to enthrone himself as its King, has just had an even more dramatic experience. Until the Spanish authorities ended the adventure a Dutch protege of a wealthy American woman camped on its mountain frontier and proclaimed himself its "Sovereign Prince."

A young man who was sure that the human race wastes a third of its time in sleeping persuaded psychiatrists to let him show how nicely he could get along without sleep. But he seems to have shown the reverse, that he couldn't get along without it after all, according to The Boston Evening Transcript.

BERLIN, July 21. -- If the German population could for a moment take its eyes off the political situation, which entirely absorbs it, and look into the economic crisis of the country, particularly the cereal shortage that looms ahead, what little optimism remains in this land of kaleidoscopic changes and sudden shifts of sentiment would probably swiftly vanish.

Bitter arguments with Umpire Ernest Quigley, the banishment of Manager Casey Stengel and Hack Wilson and fielding plays both brilliant and erratic featured a long contest at Ebbets Field yesterday, which the Dodgers finally won, 8 to 7.
ALBANY, July 21 (AP). -- Fred Muller, and Vince Barton hit home runs, each with a man on, to feature an early attack by Newark which gave the Bears a 7-to-5 victory over Albany today.

THE WOMAN SHE WAS" is a novel written in the "Cavalcade" manner but with reverse English. It is the beautifully told story of a fine, talented English-woman, set off by a mural background of outstanding events and movements in English history.

RKO RADIO PICTURES, in association with Pioneer Pictures, plans to produce "The Three Musketeers" in the new Technicolor process used in some of the Silly Symphonies. A silent version of the Dumas novel was made in 1921 by Douglas Fairbanks.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 21. -- With martial law threatened and more than 4,000 National Guard troops encamped at the State fair grounds, police convoying of trucks was halted this afternoon as a temporary truce move in the truckmen's strike.
Many dinners and supper parties were given last night at the Atlantic Beach Club, Atlantic Beach, L.I., on its new open-air, candle-lit dining patio. Among the hosts and hostesses were:

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 21. -- The old Seventh Regiment of Manhattan, after establishing records for New York State training camps in rifle, automatic rifle, machine gun and howitzer markmanship, will leave Camp Smith tomorrow under its commander, Colonel Ralph C. Tobin, as will its companion unit in the Fifty-fourth Brigade, the 108th Infantry of Syracuse, commanded by Colonel Samuel H. Merrill.

SUMMER clearances and special promotions held retail trade to a fairly satisfactory level in the week, although comparison figures with a year ago are now beginning to become unfavorable. Low-end furniture seemed most active in sales that have now been launched.

CONSIDERABLE activity, as usual, characterizes the various Summer art colonies this year. News concerning many of the current exhibitions out of town has already appeared on this page and today there are more items of interest to report.

BLUE RIDGE, N.C., July 21 (AP). -- Dr. H.A. Morgan, director of the Tennessee Valley Authority, described the TVA as a "great experimental station for political science and the furtherance of the companionship between agriculture and industry" in an address today to the Southern Conference on Human Relations in Industry.

CAPE MAY, N.J., July 21 (AP). -- Mrs. Laurence C. Glass of Philadelphia knows "King Boris I," the would-be king of Andorra, and says to believe him is to catalogue him as a Russian baron, an army captain, wealthy yachtsman, linguist and vendor of fruit juices.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP). -- Nature, stepping in as unwelcome assistant to the AAA's crop reducing program, has made it overshoot a goal or two.

Many leading women tennis stars of the nation, including several who arrived here during the past week after extensive competition in France and England, will participate this week in one of the East's annual net fixtures, the invitation tournament of the Seabright Lawn Tennis Cricket Club at Seabright, N.J.

Routine trading, with price ranges chiefly of a minor consequence, characterized dealings in bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday during the two-hour period. The turnover, however, was larger than on the previous Saturday, the total being $4,312,700, against $3,828,000. All classifications of bonds were slightly lower on the day.

Announcement of the retirement of two men who have had a total service with the International Mercantile Marine Company and its allied lines of more than n century was made last week by P.A.S. Franklin, president of the company. Horace G. Philips, treasurer, and E. Edgar Heston, assistant treasurer, will leave their posts Oct. 1 after fifty-seven and fifty-two years, respectively, with the organization.

BISLEY CAMP, England, July 21 (Canadian Press). -- Captain J. A. Barlow of the West Yorkshire Regiment today won the King's Prize, the empire's classic of service rifle shooting, as the seventy-fifth annual meeting of the National Rifle Association closed.

Indications grew last week that business efforts in many sections were being exerted to overcome the midsummer dullness. Improvement in wholesale trade was reported in several Federal Reserve districts with retail trade governed largely by weather conditions and continuing to show spotty results.
WIMBLEDON, England, July 21. -- A hurricane from across the Pacific struck America's Davis Cup stars today and all but destroyed their chances of meeting England in the challenge round.

SOUTHAMPSON, L.I., July 21. -- Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Duncan Preston gave a dinner tonight at Miramichi for young members of the Summer colony who will be introduced to society next Winter. They were the Misses Jane Mellon, Josephine Cutting, Margaret Wagner; Nancy Blagden, who is visiting Mr. and Mrs. Courtlandt Nicoll; Genevieve Brady and Rosamund Lee.

HONOLULU, July 21. -- Hawaii's most elaborate welcome will be offered President Roosevelt when he docks here nxt Thursday. Plans, which were approved by secret service men and announced today, revealed details of an "Aloha" program unlike anything ever seen in the territory.

PARIS, July 21. -- Foreign Minister von Neurath's address on Germany's foreign policy tomorrow is being eagerly awaited here as the French expect to learn the Reich's answer to the Eastern Locarno pact proposal.
MOSCOW, July 21. -- While rejecting God and immortality of the soul, the Bolsheviki honor their dead with dignity and pomp.

LONDON, July 10. -- One fine, clear night recently, when there was a moderate temperature, twenty-six officials sent out by the London County Council Public Assistance Committee took a census of homeless persons in the administrative county of London.

Being creatures of the State, municipalities are essentially subject to the dominance of the State Legislature. When the city of New York sought early this year the right to impose emergency taxes for the privilege of carrying on business or the practice of a profession within its limits, the Legislature, in the exercise of its prerogatives, placed very definite restrictions upon the kind of transactions that could be so taxed.

Two men were held in $10,000 bail each on charges of passing forged money orders and their women companions in $1,000 each as material witnesses when arraigned yesterday before Garrett W. Cotter, United States Commissioner, after having been arrested early yesterday in a hotel in the Times Square district.

SHANGHAI, July 21. -- The American State Department's recent transfer of Walter A. Adams, Consul General at Hankow, to Harbin without asking the consent of Manchuko and the action of the United States, Great Britain, France and Italy in holding Summer troop manoeuvres at Chinwangtao and Shanhaikwan, near the Great Wall, have caused the Japanese Government to attempt to force the powers to regularize relations with the Japanese-protected State.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 21. -- The method of dissipating fog over a limited area successfully tried at the research station of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology at Round Hill, South Dartmouth, Mass., was developed by Henry G. Houghton Jr., a member of the institute's research staff, who has been studying the physical characteristics of fog for several years.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 21. -- When the California State Convention of the American Legion meets next month, a plan will be submitted to it for the establishment of a penal colony for undesirable aliens, Communists, agitators and trouble-makers in practically inaccessible lands east of Point Barrow, Alaska.

SALT LAKE CITY, July 21. -- The big "Mormon" celebration next Tuesday commemorating the day Brigham Young brought his trail-worn colonists into the Salt Lake Valley, July 24, 1847, already has produced more beards than were worn by the hardy ox-drivers of the original party.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- Addison E. Southard of Louisville, veteran Foreign Service Officer and Minister resident and Consul General at Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, since 1927, has been assigned as Consul General at Stockholm, Sweden. His duties will be taken over by Charles E. Allen of Maysville, Ky., Consul at Istanbul, who has been designated first secretary of legation and Consul at Addis Ababa.

WITH a world production of 525,093 cars and trucks during the first six months of this year, Chevrolet surpassed its output for the corresponding period of 1933 by 50 per cent, it is announced. During the month of June last the company manufactured 98,147 units, and a high production schedule is being maintained in July.

Speeches were conspicuously missing yesterday at the dedication of Riverside Ballfield, at 147th Street, near the Hudson. The project was broached more than three years ago and finally, with the cooperation of the Department of Docks, the Department of Sanitation, the Community Councils and interested private individuals, the Washington Heights Association for the Protection of Riverside was able to send out formal announcements of the opening.

HAVANA, July 21. -- The Cabinet crisis precipitated by the threatened withdrawal of the Liberal Republicans headed by Dr. Miguel Mariano Gomez, Mayor of Havana and a member of the Cabinet, has been settled. The party will continue to support the provisional administration, according to the Secretary of the Presidency.

SPINOZA is one of those philosophers upon whom no amount of investigation is superfluous and no genuine inquiry without illumination. When the investigation is of such magistral scholarship and pointed clarity as this long-awaited work of Professor Wolfson of Harvard University, it is of moment that it be called to the attention of all laymen with the least pretensions to philosophy.

While Fall purchasing of men's and women's clothing and house-furnishings since the start of July is considerably below last year's inflationary activity, the volume is fairly substantial and presages a much healthier market situation, according to opinions expressed here yesterday by leading executives.

CAMP MOORE, Sea Girt, N.J., July 21. -- The 104th Engineers, special troops of the Forty-fourth Division, and the brigade headquarters companies of the Fifty-seventh Infantry and Sixty-ninth Field Artillery Brigades arrived today, after the 113th Infantry from Northern New Jersey had completed a fortnight of field training under command of Colonel Clyde E. Winterton of East Orange and left.

THE concert group of Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman is making a signal contribution to the dance world by its awakening to the possibility of remedying through organization the baneful economic situation which has long hung over the group dancer like an irremediable fate.

Somebody barely got up in the last stride to nip Deduce at the wire and triumph by a head in the twenty-fifth running of the mile and a sixteenth of the featured Yonkers Handicap at Empire City yesterday.

BAR HARBOR, Me. -- Bar Harbor is looking seaward this week in anticipation of the visit of the friendly natives which annually send their representatives for the International Maritime Tennis Tournament on the courts of the Bar Harbor Club.
CHICAGO, July 21. -- With 206 deaths in three days and thousands of prostrations reported due to blistering heat, the Middle West continued to bake in temperatures above the 100 mark today.
ALBANY, July 21. -- Demands are being made on Governor Lehman to announce whether he will be a candidate for re-election, but thus far he has been adamant in refusal to give his decision.

THE Japanese menace to the British position in Asia makes it imperative for Britain to seek ways and means to preserve existing markets in the East and to open up new ones. This is the reason why importance is attached to the proposal to build a railway from the Mediterranean seaboard in Palestine across the Arabian Desert to the rich plain of the great rivers of the Bible, the Tigris and Euphrates.

COLOR in the garden need not pass with the fading of Summer flowers. There is a whole group of shrubs and small trees which "carry on" into the Winter -- some of them all the way through it -- lending contrast and variety to garden scenes of snow and evergreen foliage.
