WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 24. -- Contending the circus scheduled to be presented Aug. 2, 3 and 4 by the Westchester Country Club of Harrison on its polo field would constitute a violation of law, would be a menace to health and would attract undesirable persons, eighteen neighbors whose homes are on the country club property filed a Supreme Court application today for an injunction to prevent the show from being conducted.

The 20,000 Manhattan commuters who travel on the Staten Island Coach Company's buses experienced little or no inconvenience in getting to and from business yesterday as a result of the strike of the 100 bus drivers on the six lines of the coach company for a pay increase.

The largest number of margin calls in a year have been sent by Stock Exchange firms to their customers in the last two days, a survey by representative firms showed yesterday. The amount of money asked for to strengthen weakened accounts has not been large though, brokers reported.

Registration of visiting buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday showed a drop in comparison with the figures for the preceding week. The total, however, still remained ahead of the number listed in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

The B.B. Stable completed a double at Empire City yesterday when Modern Ace scored decisively in the featured Knollwood Purse after Bird Lore had won the second race. In the Knollwood, which was at a mile and seventy-yards, Modern Ace finished two lengths before P.J. Fouhy's Anna V.L., with Henry Lingelbach's Instigator third.

KAILUA, Hawaii, July 24. -- President Roosevelt reached this small town on the Kona coast at 5 o'clock this morning, ending the longest leg of his 13,000-mile cruise of the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans. He came into port in calm, sunny weather, with excellent prospects ahead for his quest for swordfish off the lava flows nine miles to the north.

LONDON, July 24. -- The Stock Exchange was lifeless today and prices sagged from lack of support. British Government funds benefited from little investment buying. Tobaccos and breweries gained some ground, but rayons, aviations and automobiles were weak.

E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. reported yesterday that for the six months ended June 30, net income was $23,553,598, equivalent to $1.86 a share on 11,062,023 shares of common stock. This compares with $11,277,550, or $1.03 a share on 10,918,063 shares in the first six months of 1933.

Since the legalization of open betting in this State last Spring all figures for attendance, receipts and purses, in comparison with those of 1933, have shown considerable advances, according to statistics released yesterday by the New York State Racing Commission.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 24. -- Sidney B. Wood Jr. managed to capture the first two sets and the initial point of the third from Jack Crawford in the intervals between drizzles today before another spatter of rain caused the umpire to postpone the remainder of the match until tomorrow.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., July 24. -- The fad of women wearing shorts while playing golf took a more definite turn today when more than half the record-breaking field of ninety-five players in the fifth annual Westchester and Fairfield women's golf championship at the Tamarack Country Club appeared in the abbreviated costumes.

BOLTON, LANDING, N.Y., July 24. -- Golfers from all parts of the Empire State had gathered here today for the annual New York State amateur championship, which starts tomorrow on the links of the Sagamore Golf Club on Federal Hill, overlooking Lake George.

TORONTO, July 24 (AP). -- The Henry H. Knight Stake, 2:19 trot valued at $1,000, was won today by All Pep, owned by A.T. Cole of Wheaton, Ill., and driven by the youthful Johnnie Caton of Syracuse. It was All Pep's Second victory of the Grand Circuit meeting at Thorncliffe Park.

The Department of Docks has given a year's contract to private warehouse interests, to operate the four municipal piers, 12, 13, 15 and 16, at Tompkinsville, S.I., for storage purposes, it was announced yesterday. The contract involves no rental, the operators having agreed to turn over to the city all income remaining after the deduction of operating costs.

As the New York City police started a sweeping investigation yesterday into the ownership of all buses operating here except those under municipal franchises, some of the mystery surrounding the ownership of the bus that crashed at Ossining on Sunday was cleared up.

Captain Hans Tauscher, husband of the late Johanna Gadski, opera singer, has brought suit in the Supreme Court for the dissolution of a munitions business in which he asserts he invested more than $25,000.

WESTBURY, L.I, July 24. -- Devereux Milburn's Foxhunters reached the final round, the Wanderers went to the semi-final and the Rangers reached the third round of the Wheatley Cups polo tournament at the Meadow Brook Club today.

HOPEWELL, Va., July 24. -- Announcement today that the strike-closed Tubize-Chatillon plant here would discontinue its operations in the manufacture of artificial silk yarn was received with surprise by the 1,900 workers and the community generally.

HAMILTON, Mass., July 24. -- Augustus F. Goodwin, 61, chairman of the board of First National Stores and one of the most prominent sportsmen in the East, was killed this morning when a horse he was riding reared up, fell backward and crushed him before he could jump from the saddle.
The American Steamship Owners Association refused yesterday to confer with representatives of their employes in the Seafarers' Council of the Port of New York on problems of wages and working hours.

ALBANY, July 24. -- The proposal to appropriate $13,346,000 as additional State aid for education to bring the figure to the full quota set forth in the Friedsam Act will be debated at a public hearing before the Assembly Ways and Means Committee tomorrow.

DETROIT, July 24 (AP). -- Clarence Phillips, young pitcher just up from Beaumont of' the Texas League, made his debut with Detroit today and performed so creditably that the Tigers defeated the Red Sox, 6 to 3.

DANVILLE, Ky., July 24. -- Jack Durham and Wesley Carty, local newspaper men, were sent to jail to serve three hours late today for refusing to tell where they obtained advance information that Representative, J. Sterling Towles was to be hanged in effigy here last week.

New York City's problem of financing unemployment relief moved nearer solution yesterday when Governor Lehman sent a special message to the Legislature asking it to grant additional taxing power to the city to raise relief funds.

All markets were depressed yesterday, but not to the extent that they were on the day before. Nor was the pressure as aggressive. But selling in considerable volume went on in stocks, bonds, grains and cotton, with a consequent reduction in price levels.

BALTIMORE, July 24. -- Dr. Samuel Kent Merrick, one of Baltimore's most prominent physicians, died today at Five Acres, the Ruxton home of his daughter, Mrs. Martin Gillet. He was 86 years old, the son of Samuel Beal and Annie Jane Seymour Merrick, his paternal ancestors having settled in Maryland in 1687.
Streets are a mirror of a city. They tell what type of people live on them. Compare the better sections of Park Avenue with Second or First Avenues and you can gauge the types of tenants.

PARIS, July 24. -- With the full force of the country behind him, from the President of the Republic to the humblest voter, Premier Gaston Doumergue today called his turbulent Cabinet Ministers to order and established a continuation of the political truce for at least several months.

CHICAGO, July 24. -- The identity of the "girl in the red dress," who accompanied John Dillinger to the Biograph Theatre Sunday night and saw him shot dead by Federal agents was established tonight as his body was being taken to Indiana for burial.

ST. ANTHONY, Idaho, July 24. -- Speaking hero today at the Mormon Pioneer Day celebration. Senator William E. Borah renewed his attack on "monopoly" and warned that its defenders "will not be permitted to hide behind the New Deal," but will "have to fight in the open."

Edward M. Lang of New York forwards an interesting account of several recent expeditions to the Catskills. His party fished a posted stretch of Russell Brook, one of the largest feeder brooks that empty into the Beaverkill, near Roscoe.
NEWARK, N.J., July 24. -- Vito Tamulis, left-hander, subdued Rochester tonight in the series opener by the score of 6 -- 1. Tamulis yielded only six hits. He walked two and fanned nine batters.
With no Deans, dizzy or otherwise, about to stage any of their distracting sidelights, the Giants swung sharply back into their normal gait at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 24 (AP). -- Pitching brilliantly despite the intense heat, which sent a thermometer on the mound to 120 degrees, young Les Tietje held Washington to six scattered hits today and the White Sox evened the series with a 4-to-1 victory.

ALBANY, July 24. -- Governor Lehman again has urged the chiefs of his own party in the Senate and Assembly to get the Legislature down to business in this third week of the extraordinary session. The two first weeks have been productive of no legislation at all.

The preliminary report of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation for the fiscal year ended on June 30 shows a consolidated net income of $6,940,819 after taxes, charges, depreciation and minority interest, equal after preferred dividend requirements to $7.40 a share on 735,664 no-par common shares.

In its semi-annual report to stockholders, released yesterday, the Tide Water Associated Oil Company and subsidiaries reported for the half year ended June 30 a net profit of $2,678,385 after depreciation, depletion, interest, amortization, Federal taxes, minority interest and other charges.

Dead men and ex-convicts have been elected to office in this country, and Oklahoma and Louisiana political feuds have been not without merit as public entertainment. But when the battle royal has been completed among the standing Governor of North Dakota, the sitting Governor and the Supreme Court of that State and the Federal Government, it may be that North Dakota will take first rank for freak American politics.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- About 400,000 families, including some 1,600,000 individuals, in a drought area comprising more than half of the United States, are being supported by Federal emergency relief projects, Lawrence Westbrook, who has charge of drought relief, stated today.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 24. -- Sidney B. Wood Jr. held a commanding lead of 2 sets to 0 over Jack Crawford in the first of the two remaining singles matches of the interzone final round of Davis Cup play when rain caused the matches to be held over till tomorrow.

CHICAGO, July 24. -- Dillinger's body was taken to his birthplace, Mooresville, Ind., today. Riding on the seat of the hearse for the 200-mile journey with the driver were John Dillinger Sr., 70 years old, and a brother of the desperado, Hubert Dillinger. The hearse was followed by automobiles carrying photographers.

The Tubize Chatillon Corporation, third largest Manufacturer of rayon yarns in the United States, announced yesterday at its offices, 2 Park Avenue, that it would permanently shut down its rayon yarn plant at Hopewell, Va., because of the strike of 1,800 employes, which has closed the yarn and finishing plants since June 29.

A 68-year-old woman's charge of theft against her 17-year-old grandnephew led yesterday to the disclosure that the body of the youth's mother. Mrs. Elizabeth St. George Cocke Thomas, member of an old Southern family, had lain unclaimed in the morgue since its removal from Flower Hospital, where she died of cancer Sunday night.

All operations in the share market yesterday were apparently based upon the belief that Wall Street was "thumbs down" on speculative activity. The market simply pointed downward, with no more inspiration than was supplied on the previous day.

BERLIN, July 24. -- The Propaganda Ministry, in a semi-official declaration issued today, gives sharp warning to those persons in the National Socialist party or the government who have recently been so fearless as to express publicly any opinions of their own.

CAMP DIX, N.J., July 24. -- Walter Lamb Hopkins, son of the late Walter Lane Hopkins, prominent New York architect, has been elected the outstanding student among the 908 young men from New York, New Jersey and Delaware attending the 1934 citizens' military training camp here.
A version of John Gilpin's Ride, in modern dress, threw Columbus Circle and all of Eighth Avenue south to Fifty-second Street into high excitement last night and caused a rush-hour traffic snarl.

How would you like to beard the stoker in the hold of a coal-burning tramp and give him your views on the political situation? While the mercury is on a spree, many or most of us feel about as kindly to political missionary effort as that stoker might be expected to.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- Tentative plans for an international polo series between teams representing the United States and Mexican Armies, scheduled to be played here on Sept. 19, 22 and 26, were discussed today by a committee of army officers.

Now that the ministers of all denominations are being supported by millions of the members of their various congregations to join the boycott for clean movies, it has been suggested that the film companies seriously consider a plan to produce a series of films for children.

BERLIN, July 24. -- The Boerse was uneven today with a tendency toward strength. Speculators were taking profit. Heavy industrials were stronger, with gains of 1 to 1 1/2 points. Machineries and metals were weaker, electricals were strong, chemicals irregular and shippings slightly stronger,
I write to congratulate your readers upon the admirable letter respecting "regulation of industries" by Richard R. Martin in your issue of today.
OXFORD, Kan., July 24. -- Three men were shot here today when four machine-gun bandits shot up the town, robbed the Oxford Bank of $5,000 and kidnapped five hostages.

HOUSTON, Texas, July 24. -- Confronted with the body of his 4-year-old daughter, Dortha, whom he had previously reported kidnapped, E.H. Stuart confessed today, police said, that he killed the blue-eyed, flaxen-haired child.

BERLIN, July 24. -- Viktor Lutze, who succeeded Ernst Roehm as chief of the Storm Troops, today appointed a successor to Karl Ernst, executed chieftain of the Berlin-Brandenburg group. He is Dietrich von Jago, former submarine officer.

The Joseph Conrad Memorial Library at the Seaman's Church Institute of New York, 25 South Street, has been visited by 1,588 merchant seamen since it was opened on June 18. The library, dedicated to the great sea novelist, Joseph Conrad, contains about 5,000 volumes, ranging from late fiction and biography to ancient books of exploration and travel.
PITTSBURGH, July 24 (AP). -- A strike of about 30,000 aluminum workers, threatened for midnight tomorrow was averted tonight at a conference of workers and their employers.

A committee headed by Milton W. Harrison, president of the Security Owners Association, announced yesterday a plan of reorganization for the Vicksburg Bridge and Terminal Company which would wipe out the company's $2,000,000 of twenty-year 7 per cent sinking fund debentures and 60,000 no-par common shares.

PHILADELPHIA, July 24 (AP). -- The Phillies tied for sixth place today by blanking the Pirates, 9 to 0, as Brooklyn was losing to Chicago. Pittsburgh dropped to fifth, yielding fourth position to the Braves.

Last Monday the Controller promulgated a set of rules and regulations pertaining to the tax imposed for the privilege of carrying on trade or business and of practicing a profession in the City of New York, enacted by Local Law No. 9 of 1934 by authority of the State enabling act contained in Chapter 302 of the Laws of 1934.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 24. -- A 25-year-old Massachusetts professional, Bob Crowley of Dedham, equaled the low-scoring record in the National Professional Golfers' Association championship when he won the qualifying medal today with a thirty-six-hole aggregate of 138.
BISMARCK, N.D., July 24 (AP). -A way, satisfactory to itself, was cleared today by the North Dakota House of Representatives for impeachment proceedings against "State officers."
WASHINGTON, July 24. -- The Federal Trade Commission today made public ten additional registration statements amounting to about $5,900,000 in proposed securities issues. They are listed as follows:

Briefs protesting the proposed code for the duplicating and mailing industry have been filed with the National Recovery Administration at Washington by the Consolidated Gas Company of New York and its affiliated companies, by the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation and its associated companies, and by the code committees of the electric light and power industry and the manufactured gas industry.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- J. Edgar Hoover, chief of the Division of Investigation of the Department of Justice, will go to Chicago within ten days to aid in the reinvigorated campaign to round up the remaining members of the Dillinger band of outlaws. A strong force of Federal agents is being kept in and around Chicago in the belief that some of the band are in hiding there. Picked men constitute this force.
SANTIAGO, Chile, July 24. -- Legislation affecting foreign banks in Chile will soon undergo important changes, according to the opinion of Deputies supporting a bill sent to Congress today.

I suppose there are in the world today no other two journals which, on their editorial pages, combine comment upon the interpretation of current events with, as occasion requires, a dissertation on this or that wrote in the classical manner, as happily as THE NEW YORK TIMES and The Times of London.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 24. -- Miss Frances Starr, who was the star in the Casino Theatre play, "Bill of Divorcement," this evening, and other members of the company were entertained after the performance, which marked the opening of the third week of the season, with a supper party given by Mrs. Skirvin Adams and her sister, Mrs. George Mesta, at their home, Beachmound.

A continued gain in chain store sales in June in the New York Federal Reserve District was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. A summary of the study issued by the bank follows in part:

RUMSON, N.J., July 24. -- Only four strokes separated the leading five players today at the conclusion of the second round in the sixth annual New Jersey shore tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the Rumson Country Club.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 24. -- Surrogate Leone D. Howell indicated here today that he might surcharge the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company with losses of about $48,000 represented in the holding of "non-legal" securities by the bank as executor of the estate of Alan Harriman.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 24 (AP). -- The touring American track team scheduled to compete in the Scandinavian countries this Summer won six first places today in the annual "elite" games opening the big stadium here.

LONDON, July 24. -- Last night's simulated air attack was resumed tonight, but was soon called off. It was found the defending squadrons could not use their radio sets and the clouds were too low to permit bombing planes to operate over the city with safety.

Edwin Grelis, 32-year-old Philadelphian, who had been studying chemistry at the Sorbonne, Paris, was reported yesterday to have been mysteriously lost at sea from the deck of the French liner Ile de France last Thursday night. The disappearance was announced when the liner arrived from Plymouth and Havre.

CHICAGO, July 24. -- Sharp differences of opinion are reported to have arisen among railroad traffic executives who have been seeking at closed sessions here for a way to raise $360,000,000 of additional revenue without driving business to their competitors.
LEEDS, England, July 24 (AP). -- Rain came to the aid of England today to force a draw in the fourth test cricket match with Australia.

VIENNA, July 24. -- The Dollfuss government struck tonight at the intensified terrorism under which Austria has suffered for the last three months. A 20-year-old Czechoslovak Socialist workman, Joseph Gerl, was hanged in the courtyard of the Vienna Assize Court within three hours after a hurried trial.

Business in the zaoneN market was listless. Aside from replacements little new funds were taken in any section of the market. Quotations for all classifications were carried forward without change. Call Loans. New 3[ork Stock Exchange.

Owen Madden, paroled convict and former gang leader, who knew during prohibition days what it was to have plenty of money, told Assistant District Attorney Maurice G. Wahl yesterday that he was "broke" and dependent on the generosity of friends for maintenance.

Coast Guard officials on the Atlantic Coast are alarmed over the apparent intention of the navy to absorb the communications service perfected by the Coast Guard during prohibition years as the country's best defense against coast smuggling.

Peter Lorre, European stage and screen actor, who played the part of the murderer in the film "M," arrived in New York yesterday aboard the Majestic on his way to Hollywood to begin work for Columbia Pictures.

SALEM, N.H., July 24 (AP). -- Khamseen, which carried the silks of S.W. Labrot earlier in the season, today won his third straight race for J.D. Mikel in accounting for the mile and a sixteenth event, which topped an ordinary card at Rockingham Park.

Mayor LaGuardia was asked by a committee of act0rs:yesterday to widen the theatrical /ltvlion. 0f the CqVA to give more', work to, unemplQyed actors and actresses. I-Ie received three members of the emergency nnemployment committee of the American Federation of Actors.

LONDON, July 24. -- Prepared in anticipation of the next general election and accompanied by an appeal to the nation, the Labor party's "program of action" was issued tonight with the major title "For Socialism and Peace." It will be reviewed by the Parliamentary Labor party before the issuance of an election manifesto.

Featuring the establishment of a bureau which will register designs for a period of six months, comprehensive proposals for the protection of original styles in the dress industry were submitted yesterday to the National Recovery Administration in Washington by the Dress Code Authority, it was announced here by Byres H. Gitchell, chairman of the Authority.

A new play by Hatcher Hughes entitled "The Lord Blesses the Bishop" has been acquired by the recently organized firm of Glen N. W. McNaughton and Richard Ceough for production this Fall. Mr. Ceough will direct.

The New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday that twenty-two architects or firms of architects had qualified in a public competition as the best available to design the low-price housing that the Authority will undertake with the $25,000,000 allocated recently by the Federal Public Works Administration for slum clearance in this city.

In negotiating trade agreements, as Secretary HULL is already proceeding to do, the treaties containing the most-favored-nation clause will be a distinct hindrance. Where such treatment is promised unconditionally, it tends to destroy Bargaining power. When we are obliged to give to nation A, which gives us nothing in return, whatever we give to nation B in consideration of special favors, the whole case for reciprocal trade agreements is in danger of breaking down.

Governor LEHMAN has done the proper thing in ordering the State Motor Vehicle Commissioner to make a thorough investigation of the fatal bus crash at Ossining. Was the bus properly registered and licensed? Was its equipment defective? Were any of the laws covering interstate or intrastate operations violated?
The New York City Charter Revision Commission swung into direct action at its meeting last night in the County Court House.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 24. -- Favorites fared poorly in the second day's play of the annual New Jersey centre tennis championships for juniors and boys today at the Montclair Athletic Club. In the boys' division only one of the four seeded players remained in the running.

In the July issue of Harpers Magazine John T. Flynn undertakes to castigate THE NEW YORK TIMES for its comparison of the recent Stock Exchange investigation carried on by Mr. Pecora, with the assistance of Mr. Saperstein, Mr. Cohen, Mr. Flynn and others, with the investigation made under the direction of Charles E. Hughes in New York State.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- Commissioner George E. Allen, one of the three "Mayors" of the capital city, who returned today from a private inspection of relief operations in several parts of the country, declares that relief is being administered by "snooty" persons who are doing more to antagonize the destitute than to help them.

LOS ANGELES, July 24. -- Terming as "contemptible if not contumacious" the conduct of Henry Grief, the attorney who handled the divorce case in which Eleanor Wilson McAdoo obtained freedow from Senator William Gibbs McAdoo last week, presiding Judge Collier of the Superior Court completed his investigation today and announced that the matter had been referred to the State Bar Association.

REHOBOTH, Del., July 24. -- Allen L. Lauritsen, a Wilmington building contractor and sportsman, was killed tonight when his airplane crashed into the ocean near here. The plane was wrecked and the fuel tanks and parts of the fuselage were washed ashore. The body was recovered.

To a syndicate headed by Lehman Brothers was awarded yesterday a new issue of $1,581,000 Boston Metropolitan District, Mass., bonds, at a price of 95.086 for the bonds as 2 1/2s, with the proviso that the bonds mature from Aug. 1, 1935 to 1949, as against the option of having the bonds mature up to 1959.

TOKYO, Wednesday, July 25. -- Japan's determination to retain her South Sea mandate after her withdrawal from the League of Nations becomes effective was reiterated in instructions accompanying the annual report of the islands' administration, which Foreign Minister Kokis Hirota mailed yesterday to Counsul General Yokoyama at Geneva to submit to the League.
VIENNA, July 24. -- "One terrorist for a cook" is the humble demand which Austria makes of Adolf Hitler today.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 24. -- Dog racing, Camden county's newest sport, attracted more than $500,000 in bets in the first ten days of its existence. Andrew Stewart, chairman of the finance and revenue committee of the Pennsauken Township Committee, said today that $508,232 had been wagered through the pari-mutuel machines and that 85 per cent of that sum, or $431,997, had gone back to the winning bettors.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- Preliminary discussions involving the administration of the Securities and Exchange Law were held today by New York Stock Exchange officials and the Securities and Exchange Commission.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 24. -- A proclamation for establishment of a military dictatorship or martial law in Minneapolis was reported drawn up late today at a conference between Governor Olson, Adjt. Gen. Walsh and other National Guard officers.
Manager Charley Grimm of the Cubs has hit only three home runs this year, but he has fashioned two of them in two days off Brooklyn pitching and his third won the ball game yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 24 (AP). -The Examiner says "striking Pacific Coast longshoremen have voted by an overwhelming majority" to accede to arbitration of their dispute with employers by the National Longshoremen's Board.

Supreme Court Justice Albert Cohn has signed an order approving the report of John W. Clancy, appointed referee to report on the plan of reorganization of the financial structure of the Chanin Building, Forty-second Street and Lexington Avenue, it was announced yesterday.

Daily average gross crude oil production of the United States last week was 2,592,800 barrels, compared with 2,600,750 in the preceding week, a decrease of 7,950 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A drop of 17,350 barrels in Oklahoma and a gain of 10,800 barrels in Texas were among the important changes.

BALBOA, C.Z., July 24. -- Secretary Of War George Dern plans to fly from the Canal Zone to Puerto Armuelles tomorrow morning, following a review at Albrook Field. He will board the United Fruit liner Talamanca for Portland, Ore., where he will meet President Roosevelt, accompanying the Executive as far as Fort Peck, where he will inspect the Ninth Corps Area.

Death as the wages of sin is not the most effective moral lesson which DILLINGER offers. A more powerful deterrent is the reminder that the wages of sin are betrayal. Susceptible youth will not always be frightened by the prospect of death in battle against the minions of the law.

ST. LOUIS, July 24. -- Earle Combs, veteran, outfielder of the Yankees, was carried from the field unconscious today and was later sent to St. John's Hospital, following an accident in the seventh inning of a game the McCarthymen lost to the Browns, 4 to 2.

Public opinion marshaled against objectionable films, rather than censorship, is favored by the Most Rev. John T. McNicholas, Archbishop of Cincinnati, in a report on "The Problem of Evil Motion Pictures" appearing in the August issue of The Ecclesiastical Review.

The retirement from Congress of Representative BLACK of Brooklyn suggests once more that it is dangerous for public men to be as funny as they can. In some respects Mr. BLACK had the brightest, and certainly the most truly satirical, mind in the House. He was active in serious legislation.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 25. -- Invitations were sent out today for the concert to be given at De La Salle Academy auditorium on next Wednesday evening in honor of Admiral Joseph Mason Reeves, Commander-in-Chief of the United States Fleet.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP). -- Impetus to the Federal drive to smash the remnants of the Dillinger gang gathered momentum here tonight as J. Edgar Hoover, head of the Bureau of Investigation of the Department of Justice, conferred with Melvin H. Purvis, agent in charge of the Chicago office, who engineered the capture and death of John Dillinger.

HOUSTON, Texas, July 25 (AP). -- A Gulf hurricane vented its fury on a 125-mile sector of the South Texas coast today, causing at least eleven deaths, crops destruction mounting into millions of dollars, and widespread damage to buildings, communications lines, boats and highways.

BAIREUTH, July 25. -- A fair-to-middling "Rheingold" opened the first of the Baireuth festival's two "Ring" cycles this evening. The performance did not reach the level of Monday's "Meistersinger," but even at that its best element was again the conducting of Karl Elmendorff, into whom something of a new spirit appears to have entered since last year.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 25. -- Pacific Coast longshoremen voted 6,378 to 1,471 to arbitrate their differences with employers, President Roosevelt's National Longshoremen's Board announced late today. Immediately after the announcement an early return to work was predicted by O.K. Cushing, acting as spokesman for the board.
A good demand for housing properties in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx yesterday was featured by activity in the latter borough, where operators and builders participated in several deals.

Three men were held as material witnesses and Westchester County authorities were told of a threat to one witness and an order to another to commit perjury as the grand jury opened at White Plains yesterday its investigation of the Ossining bus disaster.

This morning we waved farewell to 126 happy mothers and children leaving the Cedar Street pier for a ten-day stay at our free seaside home at North Long Branch, N.J. I spent yesterday with 190 laughing, excited boys camped beside the twin lakes on the 320 acres of woodland comprising our Star Lake Fresh Air Camp near Butler, N.J.

SALEM, N.H., July 25 (AP). -- Stepping six furlongs in the fast time of 1:11 2-5, B.F. Ratti's Black Hand, a consistent son of the famous Flying Ebony, today drove to a head decision over C.V. Whitney's High Glee in the $2,500 Dartmouth Handicap at Rockingham Park.

BRATISLAVA, Czechoslovakia, July 25. -- I had to cross the Austrian frontier, because the Austrian authorities severed all telegraphic and telephonic communication and are severely censoring telegrams. I can tell the astounding story of how fewer than 200 Nazis held the Austrian Cabinet prisoners all day long in the Chancellor's office.

Varying trends appeared yesterday in commodity futures here with gains in cocoa, silk, cottonseed oil and tin, as copper, lead, hides, sugar and coffee weakened. In the cash markets, wheat, corn, oats, coffee, cocoa and lard eased, while silk advanced.

SEA GIRT, N.J., July 25. -- Chancery Court action against a group of New Jersey's leading industries will be instituted immediately for violations of State codes. Eight bills against "chiselers" will be filed.

MOSCOW, July 25. -- The foreign political situation, particularly the attitude of Germany and Poland toward the proposed Eastern Locarno pact, remains the principal topic of interest here, although there is no direct comment or discussion of the subject in the Soviet press.

Three-quarters of a century of activity of the Equitable Life Assurance Society was marked yesterday at the opening of its two-day diamond jubilee conference in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. Executive officers and directors of the society reviewed its history before 1,138 agents from all over the United States, who with their families brought the attendance to 1,800.

The Democratic leaders of the five counties of New York City met in conference yesterday at the National Democratic Club and failed to name a candidate for Controller, but indicated clearly that they had no thought of endorsing Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick, Fusionist, whom Mayor LaGuardia appointed to succeed the late W. Arthur Cunningham.
Lakeside Publishing Co., in 462 4th AT.; Hecht C-old. in 15g W. 27th St.; I. larkman, in 315 W. 36th St.; J. (2[. White Co., brokers.

BUENOS AIRES, July 25. -- The United States is increasing her sales to Argentina faster than any other selling nation except Canada, according to the report of the National Statistical Bureau for the first half of this year, just published.
ROME, July 25. -- A statement emanating from official sources tonight said the Austrian Government had requested intervention by European powers to guarantee Austria's integrity.

Radu Florescu, Charge d'Affaires of Rumania, announced here yesterday at the Ritz Carlton Hotel that he had been authorized by his government to offer to the American holders of Rumanian monopolies bonds the same partial payment of interest which was accepted by European holders of these bonds in an agreement signed last Saturday in Paris.
WASHINGTON, July 25. -- The speech of Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, at the National Press Club today was as follows:

The Columbia Pictures Corporation has been authorized to list 31,536 additional voting trust certificates for common stock on the New York Stock Exchange and to cancel the listing authority for 66,510 certificates previously granted. The net result is that the certificates authorized for listing will be reduced from 235,869 to 200,895.
Advocates of the single chamber council plan in charter revision were confident yesterday that the plan would be adopted by the New York City Charter Revision Commission.

PARIS, July 25. -- All pretense that the political settlement reached by Premier Doumergue yesterday, whereby his government remains intact, is anything more than an armed truce disappeared today when the Parliamentary members of the Radical Socialist party met and adopted a sharply worded resolution attacking Andre Tardieu, Minister of State.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- A list of 186 registration statements covering proposed financial issues, filed under the Securities Act between July 27, 1933, and June 30 of this year, was made public today by the Federal Trade Commission.

Having just finished a tour which included Chicago, Toronto, Montreal, Quebec, Boston, Philadelphia and New York, I have had the impression forced upon me that, generally speaking, New York is the most discourteous city in the United States.

CANBERRA, July 25. -- Prime Minister Joseph A. Lyons announced in a budget speech yesterday a surplus of 1,380,100 [the pound is currently worth about $5.04], compared to a 1,301,000 surplus last year, and he promised that last year's extensive taxation concessions would be extended.

BERLIN, July 25. -- Prices on the Boerse were weaker today as the public took less interest in the market and the speculators made realization sales. Just before the closing fresh weakness developed all along the line. The heavy industrials were weaker, but the electricals resisted the general tendency, although they had an irregular tone.

The realty brokerage business of William A. White Sons during the first six months of this year increased 117 per cent over that in the same period of 1933, Peter Grimm, president of the firm, reported yesterday. The company's office in the financial district gained 85 per cent in business and the office renting department in midtown had a 113 per cent rise.

Mishel Piastro, concertmaster of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, was last night's soloist at the Lewisohn Stadium, Eugene Ormandy conducting. The vehicle was Tchaikovsky's Violin Concerto, which was played as the second half of the program.
The East River waterfront is to have its "Riverside Drive" under plans of the Triborough Bridge Authority announced yesterday.

During my years in Washington I frequently discussed economic or monetary matters with Senator Owen and I do not recall that we were ever in very close agreement. He belongs to what has been called the monetary school, and believes apparently that depressions and booms are due wholly or almost wholly to monetary matters.

DETROIT, July 25 (AP). -- After getting away to a six-run lead in the first two innings, the Red Sox finally were forced to come from behind to defeat the Tigers, 9 to 7, today and register their first victory of the season at Navin Field.

Borough President Palma of Richmond announced last night that negotiations for a settlement of the strike begun Monday afternoon by 100 drivers of the Staten Island Coach Company had reached a deadlock. Mr. Palma made the announcement after conferring for four and a half hours, first with a strikers' committee and then with Samuel H. Serene, president of the bus company.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 25. -- Finding himself 2 down at the twenty-seventh hole to Herman Barron of Port Chester, N.Y., Gene Sarazen, the defending titleholder, smashed through on the next seven holes today go win his first-round match in the P.G.A. championship by 3 and 2.

BERLIN, July 25. -- Germany's answer to the United States note of July 16 demanding "early remedial measures" to assure American holders of German bonds the same treatment accorded to bondholders in Britain and in other countries was delivered to Ambassador William E. Dodd late this afternoon. Pending transmission of the reply to Washington, both the German Government and the United States Embassy kept silence on its contents.
HILO, Hawaii, July 25. -- President Roosevelt had a close-range look today at the melting pot which is Hawaii.
The first eleven railroads to report showed net operating income of $10,999,000 in June against $13,378,000 in June last year, a decrease of 17.7 per cent.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 25. -- The superior hitting power of Frank Shields and the miraculous defense, magnificent fighting qualities and brilliant tactics of Sidney B. Wood Jr. carried the United States into the challenge round of Davis Cup play by virtue of their victories over the Australian stars, Vivian McGrath and Jack Crawford, in the final singles matches.

CHICAGO, July 25. -- Traders who sold grains early today and caused a drop of about a cent or more in wheat from Tuesday's closing prices, were active buyers a good part of the rest of the session, causing a finish around the top figures and creating a more bullish sentiment.

LONDON, July 25. -- According to The London Daily Express, Dr. Jona Frankel, grand rabbi of Germany, who escaped from Berlin after being shot in the head by Nazi Storm Troopers, is in Brixton Jail, London, awaiting the British Government's decision whether he should be deported.
BERLIN, July 25 (AP). -- Alfred Frauenfeld, exiled Austrian Nazi leader, said over the telephone from his Munich office today:

CHICAGO, July 25. -- While John Dillinger was being buried today, Federal and police officials here searched for a cache which they believe exists and contains some of the $300,000 taken in the last fourteen months by the outlaw's band of gunmen in bank hold-ups.

TORONTO, July 25. -- Hollyrood Sara, owned by Ben F. White of Lexington, Ky., and driven by Harry Stokes of Goshen, N.Y., won the featured Sir William Mulock Stake, 2:17 pace, valued at $1,000, as the Grand Circuit meeting at Thorncliffe Park closed today.

Payment of all awards for property taken by the city, which are payable from corporate stock funds, will be begun soon and within six weeks all awards entered before Jan. 1, when the Fusion administration took office, will be cleared up, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick announced yesterday.

MATAWAN, N.J., July 25. -- Two rabbis were killed and the wife and stepson of one of them seriously injured this morning when the automobile in which they were riding was in collision with a truck on Route 4 between here and South Amboy.

FEARLESS FRED PERRY had better sharpen up his racquet. The Yanks are coming! In the early stages of the interzone final it was feared that our tennis expeditionary force was about to be surrounded and captured by the Australians, but our men fought their way out of the trap and swept over the enemy position to a thrilling victory after all had seemed lost.

ALBANY, July 25. -- Governor Lehman was requested today by Senator Fearon to send a special message to the Legislature paving the way for legislation to facilitate distribution of free milk to needy mothers and children.

MAYWOOD, July 25. -- Even in death the eyes of the State's law-enforcement officers were on John Dillinger, for among those who passed by his coffin was Attorney General Philip Lutz Jr. who went to Tucson, Ariz., following the outlaw's capture there last January and directed the fight for his return to the Crown Point jail.

Premier DOUMERGUE resumes his vacation today, stronger than ever in public confidence. He has spoken with tact and acted with calmness. He regrets M. TARDIEU'S "vehement ardor." The expression recalls or translates "the perfervid temperament of the Celts."

CAMP DIX, N.J., July 25. -- Twelve residents of New York City and Long Island are among twenty-five "Blue" or final year candidates promoted to the grade of student captains or lieutenants in the Camp Dix citizens military training camp regiment, in orders issued today by Brig. Gen. H.L. Laubach, camp commander. The C.M.T.C. regiment at present is being trained by officers of the 306th Infantry, commanded by Colonel Julius Ochs Adler of New York.

The New York Stock Exchange has again altered its rules on contracts with customers' men, this time giving the committee on quotations and commissions supervision and eliminating the previous provision that renewal contracts must be for at least one month.

Dr. Engelbert Dollfuss, small of stature but endowed with grim determination and enormous capacity for work, virtually walked on the brim of a volcano while he was Chancellor and dictator of Austria for two years and two months.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 25. -- Members of the Summer colony filled Parrish Memorial Hall tonight when the Hampton Players, under the direction and management of Henry Codman Potter and George Haight opened their second production this season with the presentation of "Kind Lady," a new drama by Edward Chodorov, adapted from a story by Hugh Walpole.

Television images, clearly visible in a brilliantly lighted room, and capable of being viewed simultaneously by an audience of several dozen persons through a novel system of wide-angle projection achieved without lenses or prisms, were shown yesterday in New York by the National Television Corporation at 52 Vanderbilt Avenue.
BERLIN, July 25 (AP). -- The Reichsbank statement as of July 23 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

Expressing concern over the shortage of hospital facilities in the city, Mayor LaGuardia asked Hospital Commissioner Goldwater yesterday to make a survey of all such facilities, with the object of welding them into a coordinated system.

Professional ethics may become a strange and wonderful thing. A letter from DILLINGER to a lawyer in Tucson, Ariz., arrived at its destination ten hours after the outlaw's death in Chicago. In itself that would be merely a curious news item.

A new issue of $995,000 city of Minneapolis, Minn., various improvement bonds, dated Aug. 1, 1934, and due from 1935 to 1954, was awarded at auction yesterday to a syndicate comprising Phelps, Fenn Co., the Wells-Dickey Company of Minneapolis and the Milwaukee Company.

Holders of mortgages on five properties in Manhattan and five in the Bronx were represented at the bidding on the ten parcels at auctioneers' stands yesterday. All the mortgagees, as plaintiffs in the foreclosure actions leading up to the forced sales, bought in the properties to protect their liens.

New York City had a heavier rainfall yesterday than any other place in the United States, but instead of being a boon to the city's millions it proved to be another weather burden, because it caused stifling humidity.

The official report of the total balance of international payments of the United States in 1933 is unusually interesting, because it reflects, in addition to other maladjustments brought about by the world economic crisis, the consequences of our abandonment of the gold standard.

FARGO, N.D., July 25. -- Mrs. Edith M. Hamilton today awaited the homecoming of her daughter, Mrs. Roy Keele, also known as Polly Hamilton. She was apparently dazed by the news that her daughter had been a friend of John Dillinger.

Dr. Kurt Schuschnigg, who assumed the Chancellorship of Austria yesterday, has been prominent in the political life of that nation for many years. Catholic by faith and a member of the Christian-Social party, he was associated closely with Dr. Seipel, the outstanding clerical leader in Austria since the end of the World War.
BISMARCK, July 25. -- A sweeping debt moratorium was proclaimed today by Acting Governor Ole H. Olson as the first outstanding public act of his eight-day-old administration.

An amendment to the code of fair competition of the dress industry, providing for a permissive open-price system of registering quotations on dresses, was filed yesterday with the NRA by the Dress Code Authority, it was announced here by Byres H. Gitchell, chairman of the Authority.
CHICAGO, July 25. -- Apparently John Dillinger led a free and easy life here, buying beer, playing cards and going to movies while the police of the nation were looking for him.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- A step by the government to bring about radical reductions in ocean and foreign air mail contracts was taken today when Acting Postmaster General Howes notified the thirty-two ocean mail and four foreign air mail contractors to appear at a hearing at the Postoffice Department Oct. 1, "to show cause why their contracts should not be modified or cancelled."

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- The Federal Housing Administration, under the direction of James A. Moffett, is making every effort to complete regulations early next week for obtaining government insurance on loans for improving homes and other small properties.

CHICAGO, July 25. -- Packing and livestock interests are working to clean up the congestion of livestock caused mainly by the strike of stock yards employes. New men have been employed and every effort is being made to bring about an adjustment.
A compromise ruling which will materially lessen the business tax which brokerage firms must pay the city was made public yesterday by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick.

SAN JUAN, P.R., July 25. -- After thirty-six years of question as to their benefits, the United States tariff laws in operation in the island will be under consideration for study as a relief measure, the Relief Administration announced today on the anniversary of the landing of the first American troops under Major Gen. Nelson A. Miles in the Spanish War.

Business on the Stock Exchange yesterday was dull and price movements were irregular, with no noteworthy movement in either direction. The combined averages lost about 1/2 point and the total volume on the Stock Exchange was considerably smaller than on the day before.

Cotton goods executives, who returned from the South this week, expressed themselves as concerned yesterday over the drought situation. If rain does not appear in the next two weeks, particularly in the Texas area, they felt, crop damages will retard business seriously.

Titus de Bobula, who has been sued by his partner, Captain Hans Tauscher, for the dissolution of the B. T. Munitions and for the appointment of a receiver for the concern, asserted in an affidavit yesterday that the receivership should be denied.

VIENNA, July 25. -- A group of Austrian Nazis today seized the federal Chancellery, killed their bitter enemy, Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss, and held the government building until they received a guarantee of safe conduct to Germany, a guarantee which was revoked when it was discovered that Dr. Dollfuss was dead.
NEWARK, N.J., July 25. -- The Bears made it two in a row over Rochester today in a 4-to-1 victory featured by Marvin Duke's pitching.
VIENNA, July 25. -- The text of the radio speech made today by Mayor Emil Fey, Commissar for Emergency, follows:

A plan for the reorganization of the National Surety Company and providing comparatively quick payment of some money to holders of guaranteed mortgage certificates was filed with Referee James A. Martin in Supreme Court yesterday. The plan is designed to make full payment of all creditors practicable ultimately.
Nervous fluctuations were frequent on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, and after several rallies, one of about $1 a bale, the list ended unchanged to 3 points higher.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- Negotiations looking to a settlement of financial and commercial questions between the United States and Russia were undertaken today at a two-hour conference between Secretary of State Cordell Hull and R. Walton Moore, Assistant Secretary of State, on the one side, and Ambassador Alexander Troyanovsky on the other.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 25. -- Many Berkshire colonists motored this afternoon to the matinee concert by the Jacques Gordon String Quartet at Music Mountain, Falls Village, Conn. Compositions by Borodin, Bloch and Griffes were played.

Bernard S. Deutsch, president of the Board of Aldermen, sailed with his wife yesterday on the Ward liner Orizaba for Havana and Mexico to spend his month's payless furlough. Mayor LaGuardia, who had been expected at the pier at Wall Street, could not come, but sent his colleague a bon voyage gift of calling cards printed in Spanish.

PARIS, July 25. -- As soon as the death of Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss of Austria was confirmed the French Foreign Office tonight began to take measures that are believed here to point to a protest to Berlin against the Nazi action in Austria.

WESTFIELD, N. J., July 25. -- Eliminating another seeded player today, Charles R. Harris of Palm Beach, Fla., who won the Delaware State title last week but was unseeded here, reached the semi-final round of the Northern New Jersey tennis championship, defeating Frank O'Connell of Chicago. third in the draw, at the Westfield Tennis Club, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2.

Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan, sole Tammany member of the Board of Estimate, covered his Fusion colleagues with confusion yesterday when he upset their plan to buy the Police Department annex at 398 Broome Street at private sale for $499,000.
KIEV, July 24. -- The struggle which is producing this year's Soviet harvest in the face of an early drought is of a nature and intensity probably never before seen in the world.
CHICAGO, July 25 (AP). -- C.V. Whitney's Today, one of the chief hopes from the East in the $25,000 added Arlington Futurity to be run Saturday, failed dismally in his trial at Arlington Park today.

Although the volume of bond trading on the Stock Exchange fell off somewhat yesterday, the market continued lower. Bonds of all classifications were lower on the day, although the undertone was firmer than earlier in the week. Total transactions amounted to $10,678,800, against $11,766,900 on the previous day.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
ALBANY, July 25. -- Urged on by Governor Lehman, former Governor Smith and James J. Dooling, Tammany leader, the Senate approved today four resolutions for county reform.
Several multi-family houses were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., July 25. -- For the third time in a row, Miss Rosalie Knapp of the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club annexed a Long Island women's one-day golf tournament today. She covered the soggy, wind-swept Piping Rock course in 84.

The preliminary statement of the General Motors Corporation for the first half of 1934, including equity in undivided profits or losses of subsidiary and affiliated companies not consolidated, showed a net profit of $69,586,613 after depreciation, interest, Federal taxes and other charges.

The possibility of a one-day shutdown of service industries in the State, including barbers, beauty parlors, cleaners and dyers, garages, restaurants, laundries, shoe repair shops and tailors, was presented yesterday at a meeting of the New York State Emergency Committee of the Service Trades at the Merchants Association rooms in the Woolworth Building.

EVELYN HARRIS'S autobiographical "Barter Lady: A Woman Farmer Sees It Through" (Doubleday, Doran, $2.50) has many flaws and is often unreasonable; but it is almost alive enough to walk. It grew out of frustration and worry, but even these weights do not hold it down, so strong was the energy and the indignation that went into its writing.

STOCKHOLM, July 25 (AP). -- Bill Bonthron and Ben Eastman, stars of the touring American track and field team, scored sensational victories today in the second day of the international meet under Swedish auspices.

RAPID CITY, S.D., July 25. -- Major William E. Kepner, commanding the National Geographic Army Air Corps stratosphere flight, held out little hope this afternoon that there would be weather conditions suitable for the flight for at least another twenty-four hours.
CLEVELAND, July 25 (AP). -- The Athletics built up a lead in the early innings against the Indians today, but their pitchers weakened and Cleveland triumphed, 8 to 3.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 25. -- The first American production of Janos Vacsary's Hungarian comedy, "I Married An Angel," was given tonight in the John Drew Memorial Theatre of Guild Hall before a large and enthusiastic audience.

TORONTO, July 25 (Canadian Press). -- Ross Wilson, Toronto and district champion, whose erratic streaks have kept him from the top, scored the only upset on the third day of the Canadian tennis, championships today by defeating Donald Leahong, Jamaican title-holder, to gain the quarter finals with a select field.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., July 25. -- Duplicating her second-round score of 83 after an 88 for the opening eighteen holes for a 54-hole aggregate of 254, Miss Marion Fisher of Oak Ridge today won the fifth annual Westchester and Fairfield women's golf championship at the Tamarack Country Club.

BERLIN, July 25. -- Throughout the day there has been the keenest interest as to what was happening in Vienna. And information to the public has been correspondingly meager and inaccurate and dictated by the National Socialist interest.

MUNICH, July 25. -- Truckloads of Austrian legionaires, who are included in the Nazi storm troops, all wearing trench helmets and carrying army rifles, are driving through the streets of Munich tonight. Their destination is unknown.

Winfred B. Holton Jr. and the Irving Trust Company were appointed permanent trustees of the Spreckels Sugar Corporation of Yonkers by Federal Judge John C. Knox yesterday pending the outcome of reorganization proceedings under the Bankruptcy Act.

By special order of General Sessions Judge Otto A. Rosalsky, Henry Harris Thomas Jr., charged by his 68-year-old grandaunt with the theft of jewelry worth 650, was enabled yesterday to see the body of his mother, whose death had been disclosed at his arraignment in West Side Court Tuesday.

The American Davis Cup squad in its brilliant victory over Australia showed such nerve and gameness in the face of what seemed almost certain defeat that every patriotic spine over here must have tingled when the result was known. Few detached commentators would have given two cents for the Americans' chances after their two dismal defeats last Saturday.
ST. LOUIS, July 25. -- Sammy Byrd hit a home run today that downed the Browns, 5 to 4, and moved the Yankees to within one game of the league-leading Tigers, who lost to the Red Sox.

LONDON, July 25. -- As heard in London, Major Emil Fey, Austrian Commissar for Emergency Measures for the Defense of the State, was speaking with intense emotion when he announced the death of Chancellor Dollfuss over the radio from Vienna tonight.

Wind and rain combined forces to afford some slight relief to people on the Atlantic, Pacific and Gulf coasts yesterday, but there was no relief for the parched fields, panting beasts and the perspiring populace of the Middle West where the toll of death and damage continued to mount.

Information concerning the four Scottish yachts and their crews that will participate in the British-American Cup six-meter team match off Oyster Bay late in September was received yesterday by Vice Commodore Van Santvoord Merle-Smith of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club, chairman of that club's committee on international racing.

The bondholders' protective committee for R. Hoe Co., Inc., first mortgage 6 1/2 per cent bonds, series A, announced yesterday that it will oppose the company's plan of reorganization that is expected to be filed on July 30 in the United States District Court.
OKLAHOMA CITY, July 25 (AP). -- Just four of Oklahoma's nine Democratic Representatives were in line tonight to go back to Washington.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.
VIENNA, Thursday, July 26 (London Times Dispatch). -- The chief of the Austrian Propaganda Department broadcast after midnight a dramatic account of how Chancellor Dollfuss died.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick B. Rentschler gave a dinner last night in the roof garden of the St. Regis. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. E. Kent Hubbard, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Ripley, Thomas F. Hamilton and D.L. Brown.

Queues strung out from windows in the Federal Reserve Banks these days are composed of those business men who seek to take advantage of the Loans-to-Industry Act passed by the Seventy-third Congress. They are largely representatives of medium-sized and small concerns on their first errand under the act -- to receive loan application forms in exchange for the names of their companies.
VATICAN CITY, July 25 (AP). -- The news of Chancellor Dollfuss's assassination came as a distinct shock to Vatican circles, where he was held in great esteem.

The Clean City Committee, organized last year, has formed a subdivision called the Clean City Crusaders for public school children between the ages of 10 and 14. Colonel Ralph C. Tobin, commanding officer of the 107th Infantry, will be the leader of the group.

The clash in Austria yesterday was a climactic development in the bitter struggle that has been waged with arms and political weapons ever since Adolf Hitler came into power in Germany on Jan. 30, 1933. Aiming at the coordination of their country with Germany, Austrian Nazis, supported by Herr Hitler now openly and now secretly, have been unremitting in their attempts to win control of the Vienna government.

As further evidence of the care with which the West polo team is planning its campaign here this year, there is the announcement made yesterday that Thomas C. Nelson of Argentina will be in charge of the invaders' pony string when it arrives at Mitchel Field. The Army polo centre, adjoining the Meadow Brook Club, will be the West's headquarters.

The will of Mrs. Anne Elizabeth Whelan Kahn, former wife of Gilbert H. Kahn and daughter of Charles A. Whelan, former head of the United Cigar Stores, who died on last Nov. 19 of injuries received in a fall from her apartment, will be filed today in Surrogates' Court.

DEAL, N.J., July 25. -- Mrs. George Viebrock of Queens Valley, who has come to the fore rapidly in her two years of golf competition, today won the New Jersey Shore tournament with a fifty-four hole medal play total of 263 at the Hollywood Golf Club.

Billy Montgomery, whose body was found in a vacant tot in Paterson, N.J., on Tuesday, had gone a long way from the days when as a vaudeville headliner on Broadway the team of Montgomery and Moore got $2,500 a week. The dead vaudevillian, who was identified from fingerprints by the police, had played in burlesque, been half of the best-paid act in Broadway vaudeville and starred in musical comedy.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 25 (AP). -- "It's another of those teams of destiny," said George M. Lott Jr. after today's matches. With Lester Stoefen, Lott started the American comeback with a doubles victory Monday after Shields and Wood had lost the opening singles matches Saturday.

Steel operations have fallen this week to 27 1/2 per cent of capacity from an average of 28 per cent a week ago, according to The Iron Age, which observes that "with the passing of the recent spurt in sheet and strip orders from the automotive industry, the Summer lull in the iron and steel market has become more pronounced."
CHICAGO, July 25 (AP). -- George Earnshaw today turned in the first regulation shutout accomplished by a White Sox pitcher this season, blanking Washington, 4 to 0.

Operations on the Stock Exchange were conducted so cautiously yesterday that little was said about the poor results. The tendency everywhere was to emphasize the fact that traders were standing by, with no inclination to take a position.

Seventy small printing shops in the Bronx turned back their Blue Eagles last night to the National Recovery Administration as a protest against the wage scale fixed for such shops in the Graphic Arts Code, in which they were included.

Bank loans of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation were reduced from $12,300,000 to $6,000,000 in the first six months of 1934, Alfred H. Schoellkopf, president, announced yesterday. At the end of 1931 the loans stood at $25,000,000.

MAYWOOD, Ind., July 25. -- John Dillinger was buried late today in Crown Hill Cemetery, although the funeral had been announced for tomorrow. Gathering at the home of his sister, Mrs. Audrey Hancock, this afternoon, the members of the immediate family joined in a simple service led by the Rev. Charles F. Fillmore.

The Regional Labor Board conferred yesterday at 45 Broadway with executives of the Seafarers' Council of the Port of New York on labor conditions among seamen in the Port but made no progress in its attempt to avert a strike vote which the seamen have threatened to take.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., July 25. -- With three titles already credited to him this season, Richard D. Chapman of the Blind Brook Club began his quest for a fourth under most favorable circumstances today.

Liquidation of most of the seventeen title and mortgages companies now in rehabilitation was recommended to Governor Lehman yesterday by George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, in his fifth interim report on his rehabilitation program.

ALBANY, July 25. -- Overwhelming sentiment in favor of the State making its full contribution to the common schools under the formula embodied in the Friedsam Education Act developed at a public hearing on the Porter bill held this afternoon before the Senate Finance and Assembly Ways and Means Committees.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- With a force of eighty special investigators and public accountants busy delving into the books and other records of the American munitions industry, Senator Nye, chairman of the Senate Munitions Industry Investigating Committee, declared today that "startling facts" awaited disclosure when public hearings of the inquiry got under way the first week in September.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 25. -- The United States Davis Cup team today achieved one of the finest comebacks ever made on any court by defeating Australia in the last two matches of the interzone final to reach the challenge round.

Consolidated net income of the North American Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on June 30 amounted to $10,713,048, equal, after $1,820,034 preferred dividends, to $1.08 a share earned on the average number of common shares outstanding in the period, comparing with $13,019,936, or $1.47 a common share, in the preceding year.
Winfield Sheehan, vice president and general manager of production for Fox, is scheduled to arrive here from Hollywood this morning. He will sail for Europe on Saturday.

About 30,000 home owners in New York State received $161,504,427 on mortgages which faced foreclosure during the first year, ended July 20, of the Federal Home Owners Loan Corporation, according to a report made public yesterday by Vincent Daily, State manager.

One hundred and ninety-six New York University students attained the honor roll for the second semester of the 1933-34 academic year in the university's School of Commerce evening division, Dean John T. Madden announced yesterday.

Meteorologists must have raised a skeptical eyebrow when they read of HENRY G. HOUGHTON'S fog-dispelling experiments at the Round Hill Station, Massachusetts. What if the composition of his moisture-precipitating chemical which is sprayed from a 100-foot pipe is kept secret?

PHILADELPHIA, July 25. -- In the keynote address of his campaign for Governor, Attorney General William A. Schnader, the Republican nominee, severely criticized the Federal Government today for its treatment of Pennsylvania in unemployment relief.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 25. -- Governor Floyd B. Olson issued an ultimatum in the truck strike here today, warning both the employers and drivers' union officials that he would declare martial law at noon tomorrow unless they had made a settlement by that time on the basis of revised recommendations advanced by the Rev. Francis J. Haas and E.H. Dunnigan, Federal conciliators.

ST. LOUIS, July 25. -- Earle Combs, Yankee outfielder, was reported resting comfortably at St. John's Hospital today, where he is confined suffering from a fractured skull, broken collar bone and minor bruises following a crash into the concrete wall at Sportsman's Park yesterday.
The most serious spill of the current New York racing season occurred in the fifth race at Empire City yesterday. Four horses and their jockeys were involved.

In regard to your editorial, "The Railroad Dilemma," it seems to me that it would be of greater benefit to the railroads if they adopted more strategic methods of increasing revenues, rather than trying to overcome wage increases and operating costs by increasing freight rates.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 25. -- A 19-year-old youth who worked his way through Princeton University by waiting on tables and who was graduated last Spring a year ahead of his class received high praise yesterday from Professor Albert Einstein for his senior thesis in the field of mathematical physics.

HARRISON, N.Y., July 25. -- At a special meeting hero tonight the Town Council voted to authorize Corporation Counsel Winfred C. Allen to bring injunction proceedings in the Supreme Court against the Westchester Country Club in an effort to prevent the club from presenting a circus on its grounds next month.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- Ambassador Alexander Troyanovsky and Secretary of State Cordell Hull joined in expressing satisfaction with preliminary progress made today in discussing financial and commercial questions involving the future of American trade with Soviet Russia.

The Federal Council of Churches made clear yesterday its position with respect to censorship of motion pictures in a statement by the Rev. Dr. Worth M. Tippy, executive head of the national campaign of the Protestant churches for better films.

BERLIN, July 25. -- Chancellor Hitler's 120,000 black special guards were taken from the command of the storm troop chief by an order issued today. They were made into a distinct corps responsible only to the direction of Hitler. Thus far this is the strongest evidence of loss of prestige suffered by 2,500,000 brown shirt troopers.

C.V. Whitney's handicap champion Equipoise must carry the top weight of 132 pounds in the Saratoga Handicap, which will be renewed on Saturday, Aug. 4, at the Saratoga track, according to the scale of weights released yesterday by Walter S. Vosburgh, official handicapper for Jockey Club tracks.

LONDON, July 25. -- News of the Austrian outbreak reached London today when the British Cabinet was in its weekly meeting, but the early details were too scanty to justify any formal discussion of the new situation.

A robber waited several hours yesterday to hold up Mrs. Edith Bobe Hague when she returned to her apartment at 14 Sutton Place South at 3:40 A.M. As she stepped through the doorway with her escort, Frank Pratt, a jeweler, of 54 East Fifty-sixth Street, she was accosted by an armed man, who ordered her and Mr. Pratt to step into a closet and tied their wrists and ankles with picture wire.

Rear Admiral Richard Leigh, United States Navy (retired), and Commander Theodore Wilkinson, are returning today on the Washington of the United States Lines after attending the preliminary meetings to the Naval Disarmament Conference in London.

BERLIN, July 25. -- A German semi-official news agency issued a statement today attributed to "Austrian sources," which was one continuous and fullsome eulogy of the attempted putsch. "The people's judgment has been passed on Dollfuss and his government," says the statement, "and the German people in Austria have risen against a torturer and a jailor.

TORONTO, July 25 (Canadian Press). -- The English team of dinghy sailors today decisively defeated the Canadian quartet in the last of a series of international tests, 22 1/4 points to 14. The English team finished the series with six victories and one loss for first place.

A conference of attorneys will be held in Surrogate Foley's chambers this morning as the result of an application by Mrs. Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt, widow of Reginald C. Vanderbilt, to be appointed general guardian of the person and estate of her daughter, Gloria Laura Morgan Vanderbilt, now 10 years old.

The Pacific Lighting Corporation and subsidiaries report net income of $4,803,105 for the twelve months ended on June 30, 1934, equal, after $1,154,505 preferred dividends, to $2.27 a share earned on the common stock, comparing with $2.94 for the preceding year.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- The NRA proceeded with a revived policy of "cracking down" today, withdrawing from L. Greif Brother of Baltimore, second largest men's clothing manufacturers in the United States, the privilege of using NRA labels, and withdrawing also from the Bear Brand Hosiery Company of Chicago the Blue Eagle.

Overnight coast-to-coast air service for passengers, mail and express will be begun within ten days, it was disclosed yesterday by Captain E.V. Rickenbacker at a luncheon of the Kiwanis Club at the Hotel McAlpin. The flier did not give details of the service, but said that the dream of uniting the coasts without the loss of business time was to come true through use of the new 200-mile-an-hour Douglas airliners.

OKLAHOMA CITY, July 25. -- Oklahoma is rapidly becoming a land of scarcity. Suffering is increasing hourly from the relentless heat. Prairie and forest fires have become destructive companions of the drought.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- A sharp decline in expenditures by American tourists abroad, due largely to the business depression, was cited today by the Department of Commerce as a principal factor in the attainment by this country of favorable position in international transactions last year.

MEXICO, D.F., July 25. -- The State must control education from its primary to its professional termination in Mexico, in the opinion of experts named to prepare a report for presentation to Congress, which will open Sept. 1.

Unable to reach a verdict after deliberating nearly nine hours at the mail-fraud trial of James C. McKay and William J. Graham of Reno, Nev., politically powerful gaming-house owners, and John J. Egleston of Worcester, Mass., a jury in the Federal Court was ordered locked up late last night to continue its deliberations today.

Allegations that Charles M. Schwab and other officers and directors of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation have delayed more than a year in answering a $46,000,000 accounting suit by stockholders were made before Supreme Court Justice Black yesterday when the majority of the defendants applied for a further delay until after the case has been heard by the Appellate Division next Fall.

Further weakness in the reichsmark was the principal feature of the foreign exchange market yesterday. The mark dropped 31 points to 38.49 cents. The Austrian schilling, which has been nominally quoted at 19 cents for many months, with an occasional slight shading of price, remained unchanged.

ROME, July 25. -- The Austrian Nazi outburst caused profound consternation in Italy today, but no particular surprise, as it had been felt for several days that things were rapidly approaching a crisis there as a result of the government's energetic repressive measures.

BERLIN, Thursday, July 26. -- The German Government at 2 o'clock this morning announced the recall of Dr. Kurt Rieth, German Minister to Austria, and Germany's intention of arresting the assassins of Chancellor Dollfuss, on behalf of whom Dr. Rieth intervened, should they reach German territory.

The city of Newark, N.J., plans to offer next month a new issue of $12,225,000 of funding bonds in connection with the recently announced $24,000,000 funding program for the city's floating debt. The Board of Commissioners held yesterday the first reading of the ordinances authorizing the new bonds.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- The State Department was informed today by George S. Messersmith, Minister to Austria, that no American in Vienna was believed to be in danger. The dispatch, filed at 5 P.M., Vienna time, was the only one received from Mr. Messersmith today.

A flexible combination of lip-reading, the sign language and manual alphabet, suited to the needs of the particular child, was urged for the schooling of the deaf by Dr. Percival Hall, president of Gallaudet College, who spoke yesterday morning at the convention of the National Association of the Deaf at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
The use of "hydrogymnastics" in the treatment of children crippled by infantile paralysis was demonstrated yesterday in the swimming pool at Christodora House.

CHICAGO, July 25. -- Efforts of Federal conciliators to end the strike of 800 stock handlers which has tied up the stock yards since early Tuesday failed of immediate success tonight. However, the conference broke up in a hopeful spirit, with further meetings arranged.

LITTLE AMERICA, Antarctica, July 25. -- The tractor party which put out from here last Friday in an attempt to relieve Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd at Bolling Advance Weather Base has safely returned to Little America. The machine rolled into camp Monday night after traveling 186 miles and surpassing all records for Winter journeys in the Antarctic.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- Joseph P. Kennedy spoke words of reassurance today to both capital and investors in connection with the new Securities Act. As chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission he delivered his first speech since assuming office when he appeared at a luncheon of the National Press Club.

Detectives and employes of the Welfare Department, under Detective William Loeffler of District Attorney Dodge's special squad, arrested eleven men yesterday in raids connected with the activities of the United Relief Association, which the authorities suspect has been running a "charity racket."

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- Banks will be able to buy up to $100,000,000 of preferred stock debentures from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, Chairman Jones announced today as he prepared to leave for a business and vacation trip through the Middle West.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- Continuance of the drought over the mid-West for another fortnight will "create a very real situation," Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture, told newspaper men at a press conference today as he displayed to them reports showing graphically the unprecedented scope of the blistering heat unmitigated by rainfall.

A 13-year-old angler, Charles T. Church 2d of Locust Valley, L.I., experienced the keenest thrill of his fishing career yesterday afternoon when he landed a 7-foot, 60-pound white marlin seventeen miles off Montauk.

Twenty years ago today newspapers all over the world were blazoning the announcement that Austria-Hungary and Serbia had broken off diplomatic relations and that martial law had been proclaimed throughout Austria Hungary.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 25. -- With Gregory Mangin of Newark, fifth in the national ranking, and John Van Ryn listed among the casualties and Wilmer Allison sorely pressed to stand off the punishing challenge of Wilmer Hines, another notable session of tennis passed into history today at the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club.
BOSTON, July 25 (AP). -- With Pinkey Whitney and Marty McManus hitting timely home runs, the Braves swept today's double-header with the Reds, winning the first game, 2 to 1, and the second, 7 to 3.

The Manhattan organization of the Recovery party, formed last year to support Joseph V. McKee for Mayor, which many had expected to go out of existence with the election of James J. Dooling as leader of Tammany, started legal action yesterday to compel the election of members of the Democratic County Committee at the primary election this year.

There shall be a Borough President elected by direct vote of the people in each borough. He shall be a member of the city legislative body, with a vote on all questions coming before it. He shall be chairman of the local improvement board or borough council and have an office in the Borough Hall.
